Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Anterior Canal BPPV: The Rare Variant.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Can anterior canal BPPV be confused with neck-related dizziness?

 Yes, this is a common differential diagnosis. A positive response to the Supine Head Hanging Test with characteristic downbeat nystagmus suggests anterior canal BPPV. Cervicogenic dizziness typically produces no specific nystagmus.

 

 
 Why is anterior canal BPPV so rare?

 The anterior canal's vertical orientation makes it difficult for crystals to enter the canal against gravity. The same orientation also promotes spontaneous drainage of any crystals.

 

 
 Is downbeat nystagmus always anterior canal BPPV?

 No. Downbeat nystagmus can also be caused by central causes (cerebellar disease), apogeotropic posterior canal BPPV, or vestibular migraine. Correct differential diagnosis is essential.

 

 
 Can I get anterior canal BPPV after treatment for posterior canal BPPV?

 Yes, this is called canal conversion and can occur when crystals move to another canal during treatment.

Describe What Can You Do Yourself? for Foot and Ankle Problems.

What Can You Do Yourself?

 

 Activity and targeted exercises are often the most important treatment for foot problems. Here are evidence-based exercises for common conditions:

 
 1. Calf Stretching (Plantar Fasciopathy)

 Stand with your forefoot on a step, letting the heel hang over the edge. Lower slowly until you feel a stretch in the calf and Achilles. Hold 30-60 seconds. Repeat 3 times on each side. Do twice daily.

 

 
 2. Eccentric Heel Raises (Achilles Tendinopathy)

 Stand on tiptoes with both feet. Lift one foot and lower slowly on the affected side until the heel is below the step. Use the healthy leg to push up again. 3 sets of 15 repetitions, twice daily for 12 weeks.

 

 
 3. Balance Training (Ankle Instability)

 Stand on one leg with eyes open. Progress to: eyes closed, unstable surface, catching/throwing a ball. 3 sets of 30 seconds on each leg, daily. Reduces re-injury risk by 35%.

 

 
 4. Towel Scrunches (General Foot Strength)

 Sit with a towel under your foot. Use your toes to scrunch the towel towards you. Repeat 10-15 times, 2-3 sets. Strengthens the intrinsic muscles of the foot.

 

 
 The Key: Optimal Loading

 The goal is "optimal loading": enough load to stimulate healing, but not so much that you worsen the injury. Complete rest is rarely the solution. I provide specific advice tailored to your situation.

Explain treatment for Ankylosing Spondylitis.

Treatment

 The treatment of ankylosing spondylitis has undergone a revolution in the last 20 years with the
 introduction of biologic medications. The goal is to control inflammation, relieve symptoms, maintain
 function, and prevent structural damage.

 Exercise - the cornerstone

 Why exercise is so important

 Maintains mobility in spine and chest

 Strengthens muscles that support the back

 Improves posture and prevents kyphosis

 Reduces pain and stiffness

 Improves sleep quality and reduces fatigue

 Recommended activities

 Swimming: Particularly beneficial - supports joints and provides all-round
 training

 Water aerobics: Combines movement and relaxation

 Yoga and pilates: Mobility and core strength

 Walking and cycling: Light aerobic exercise

 Specific exercises: Daily stretching and mobility exercises

 Medication

 NSAIDs (anti-inflammatory)

 First choice 

 Ibuprofen, naproxen, diclofenac. Often provide good effect on pain and stiffness. In inflammatory
 spinal disease, continuous use may be considered to slow disease progression.

 Biologic medications

 When NSAIDs insufficient 

 TNF inhibitors (adalimumab, etanercept, infliximab) and IL-17 inhibitors (secukinumab, ixekizumab).
 Highly effective for controlling inflammation and preventing damage.

 JAK inhibitors

 Newer class of medication (tofacitinib, upadacitinib) taken as tablets. Alternative for those who
 don't respond to or tolerate biologic medications.

Differential diagnoses for POTS and Orthostatic Dizziness?

Viral Infection (most common)

 About 50% of POTS cases start after a viral infection - especially mononucleosis (glandular fever), influenza and COVID-19. Among patients with long COVID, 2-14% report POTS symptoms.

Physical Trauma

 Whiplash injuries , concussion and other trauma to head and neck are known triggers. There is a documented connection between neck injuries and POTS development.

Associated Conditions

 POTS often occurs together with other conditions: Hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (25% of POTS patients), mast cell activation syndrome (MCAS), migraine (40%), irritable bowel (30%), and ME/CFS (21%).

Diagnostikk

 En grundig klinisk undersøkelse er avgjørende. Kiropraktoren vil typisk vurdere
 Kliniske tester

 Ettbensknebøy (single-leg squat): Viser dynamisk knevalgus og hoftekontroll. Hoy spesifisitet (86%) men lav sensitivitet (23%) - fungerer best som "utelukkelses-test" med 92% negativ prediktiv verdi.

 Trendelenburg test: 55% sensitivitet og 70% spesifisitet for hoftepatologi.

 Log roll test: Den mest spesifikke enkelttesten for å vurdere hofteleddet.

 Hoftestyrketesting: Maling av abduksjons- og utoverrotasjonsstyrke, gjerne med handholdt dynamometer.

 Bildediagnostikk

 MR eller røntgen av kneet viser ofte "normalfunn" eller aldersrelaterte forandringer som ikke forklarer symptomene. Klinisk undersøkelse - inkludert vurdering av hele den kinetiske kjeden - er ofte mer informativ enn bilder alene.

Explain treatment for Shin Splints.

Treatment

 Acute Phase

 Relative rest: Reduce running, don't stop completely

 Cross-train: Swimming, cycling, elliptical (if pain-free)

 Ice: After activity if helpful

 NSAIDs: Short-term if needed for pain

 Rehabilitation

 Calf strengthening: Heel raises, single-leg variations

 Hip strengthening: Reduces tibial stress through better mechanics

 Running form: Increase cadence by 5-10%

 Gradual return: 10% increase per week maximum

 Do Orthotics Help?

 Evidence is Mixed

 Shock-absorbing insoles may help some people with shin splints, but they're not a cure-all. If you
 have significant overpronation, custom orthotics could be considered. But strengthening and training
 modification are more important.

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Musearm og kontorplager: Hva som faktisk virker.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hjelper ergonomisk mus?

 En ergonomisk mus kan redusere belastningen på handleddet, men forskning viser at den alene ikke forebygger eller behandler musearm. Den bør kombineres med styrketrening og pauser.

 

 
 Hvor ofte bør jeg ta pauser?

 Ideelt sett en kort mikropause (30-60 sekunder) hver 20-30 minutter, og en lengre pause (5-10 minutter) hver time. Beveg deg og rist ut armene i pausene.

 

 
 Hvilke Øvelser hjelper?

 StyrkeØvelser for nakke, skuldre og armer er viktigst. Eksempler: skulderhev, roØvelser, grip-Øvelser, og eksentriske Øvelser for underarmene.

 

 
 Kan jeg fortsette å jobbe?

 Ja, med tilpasninger. Hyppigere pauser, variasjon i arbeidsoppgaver, og et treningsprogram kan gjøre at du kan jobbe uten å forverre plagene.

 

 
 Når bør jeg søke hjelp?

 Hvis plagene vedvarer over 2-3 uker til tross for pauser og tilpasninger, eller hvis du opplever nummenhet, svakhet eller tiltagende symptomer.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Knee and Leg Pain.

Anatomy: The knee is the body's largest joint and connects the thigh bone to the shin bone. Stability depends on
 an interaction between four main ligaments (anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments, medial and lateral
 collateral ligaments), two crescent-shaped cartilage discs (the menisci), and the kneecap which increases
 muscle force when straightening.

Symptoms and Causes: Overuse injuries occur when tissue is exposed to more repetitive load than it can tolerate. Typical
 examples: runner's knee, jumper's knee, IT band syndrome and shin splints. Rapid increase in training
 volume is a common risk factor.

What Does Research Say?: Research shows that active treatment with exercise is the cornerstone for most knee and leg pain. Manual
 therapy can be a useful supplement.

Treatment at the Chiropractor: At the first consultation you get a thorough examination with
Prevention and Self-Care: The most important prevention strategy is to avoid sudden increases in load. Increase training volume
 by maximum 10% per week. When starting a new activity - begin carefully and give the body time to adapt.

Frequently Asked Questions: Not necessarily. MRI often shows findings that don't explain your pain - 61% of meniscus injuries on
 MRI are asymptomatic. A thorough clinical examination often provides sufficient information to start
 treatment. MRI may be relevant if serious injury is suspected or if there's no improvement.

Need Help with Knee or Leg Pain?: Are you experiencing knee or leg pain that affects your daily life? Book an assessment with a
 chiropractor for an individual examination and treatment plan.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Trigger Finger: Complete Guide.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Does trigger finger go away on its own?

 Yes, studies show that 52% of mild cases resolve spontaneously, especially with
 rest and time.

 

 
 Does cortisone help?

 Yes, cortisone injection has 63-80% success rate. This is often the first choice
 when rest alone is not enough.

 

 
 Is shockwave treatment effective?

 No. A new systematic review from 2024 (Brancaccio et al.) shows ESWT has no proven
 effect for trigger finger. This is in contrast to conditions like tennis
 elbow where there is some support.

 

 
 Do I need surgery?

 Most people don't. But for those who don't respond to cortisone, surgery (A1
 release) has over 90% success rate.

Vurder røde flagg: 28 år mann med ensidig leggsmerte etter fotballkamp. Øm i gastrocnemius. Lett hevelse vs. frisk side. Ingen rødme. Kan gå på tå. Smerter ved belastning.

HASTEGRAD: TRYGT

Ingen røde flagg identifisert.

Klinisk resonnering — hvorfor dette sannsynligvis IKKE er DVT:
- Klar traumatisk/overbelastningsmekanisme (fotball)
- Ung mann uten DVT-risikofaktorer (ingen immobilisering, ingen p-piller, ingen familieanamnese)
- Øm i muskelbuken (gastrocnemius) = muskelstrekk
- Kan gå på tå = intakt muskel-sene-enhet
- Ingen rødme (DVT gir typisk rubor og calor)
- Lett hevelse = muskulær hevelse etter skade

OBS: Ved ØKENDE hevelse, rødme og varme uten bedring → revurder for DVT.

Klinisk bilde: Gastrocnemius muskelstrekk grad I.

Describe symptoms of c5-c6 disc herniation for C5.

Symptoms of C5-C6 Disc Herniation

 The symptoms of C5-C6 disc herniation are quite specific and follow the distribution of the C6 nerve.
 They can vary in intensity from mild numbness to significant pain and weakness.

 Typical C6 Symptoms

 Pain: Radiates from the neck, out to the shoulder, down the outer upper arm to
 the thumb and index finger

 Numbness /tingling: Thumb and index finger,
 sometimes the middle finger

 Weakness: Difficulty bending the elbow (biceps) or extending the wrist

 Reflex change: Reduced brachioradialis reflex

 Pain Provocation

 Symptoms typically worsen with
 Turning the head toward the affected side

 Bending the neck backward (extension)

 Coughing or sneezing

 Pressing down on the head (Spurling's test)

 Bakody's Sign - Relief from Raising the Arm

 A characteristic finding in cervical radiculopathy is that pain is relieved when you place your hand
 on your head. This reduces tension on the nerve root and is a useful diagnostic sign.

 Pain Pattern Throughout the Day

 With cervical radiculopathy, pain is often worst at night and early morning. This is because the neck
 remains in a static position for a long time, and any swelling around the nerve has time to accumulate.

Describe Why Is This So Confusing? for Sciatica, Disc Herniation or Lumbago?.

Why Is This So Confusing?

 

 
 Most people with back pain google their symptoms. The terms "lumbago", "disc herniation" and "sciatica" appear interchangeably - often used as if they mean the same thing. They don't.
 

 
 The problem is that symptoms can overlap, and many believe they have a serious injury when the pain is actually caused by something far less dramatic. Around 85-95% of all back pain is non-specific, meaning without a detectable structural cause (WHO, 2023). True disc herniation with nerve involvement accounts for less than 5% of cases (StatPearls, 2024).

Explain research on combined treatment for TMD and Neck Pain: Why Jaw and Neck Are Connected.

Research on Combined Treatment

 There is solid research supporting that neck and jaw should be treated together
 Armijo-Olivo et al. (2016)

 Treatment of the neck gave significant reduction in jaw pain.

 La Touche et al. (2009)

 Manipulation of upper cervical vertebrae improved opening range and reduced jaw pain.

 von Piekartz & Ludtke (2011)

 Combined treatment of neck and jaw gave better results than jaw treatment alone.

 Conclusion from Research

 Treating only the jaw in TMD is often insufficient. The most suitable approach is to examine and treat the entire system: jaw joint, jaw muscles, upper cervical vertebrae, and neck muscles. Posture guidance and ergonomic adaptation are important additional components.

Explain medical treatment for Trigeminal Neuralgia.

Medical Treatment

 Pharmacological treatment is the first-line approach for trigeminal neuralgia.

 Carbamazepine (Tegretol) - the gold standard

 NNT 1.7-1.8 for at least 50% pain relief - one of the best numbers in pain medicine (WHO EML 2024; PMC MA 2024)

 70-80% achieve relief with carbamazepine (NHI.no; Legemiddelhåndboka)

 Blocks sodium channels in the nerve and dampens the erroneous firing

 Requires regular blood test monitoring (liver, blood values)

 Dose adjustments are common - efficacy may decrease over time and require increase

 Oxcarbazepine (Trileptal)

 An alternative to carbamazepine with a potentially better side-effect profile and fewer drug interactions. Often used when carbamazepine causes too many side effects.

 Second-line and adjunctive treatments

 Lamotrigine: As add-on or monotherapy

 Baclofen: As adjunctive treatment

 Gabapentin/pregabalin: Limited evidence specifically for TN

 Botulinum toxin type A: Promising for treatment-resistant cases

 Important note about medical treatment

 Response to carbamazepine often confirms the diagnosis. Lack of response to carbamazepine should raise suspicion of an incorrect diagnosis and warrants further evaluation by a neurologist.

Describe causes and risk factors for Athletic Pubalgia.

Causes and risk factors

 Sports with highest risk

 Soccer (highest incidence)

 A systematic review showed 32.5% season prevalence for groin pain, and up to 19% of professional
 players sustain injuries requiring absence from training or matches per season.

 Ice Hockey

 Groin strains represent 10-11% of all injuries and 43% of all muscle strains in the sport.

 American Football

 4.2% prevalence of athletic pubalgia repair among NFL Combine participants. Soccer, hockey, and
 American football together account for over 70% of all cases.

 Other risk factors

 Reduced hip mobility, especially internal rotation

 Femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) - found in about 32% of
 patients who undergo surgery

 One-sided training without focus on core stability

 Previous groin injury

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Stressfrakturer i Idrett.

Hva er en stressfraktur?: En stressfraktur er et mikroskopisk brudd i bein som utvikler seg gradvis som følge av gjentatt mekanisk belastning. I motsetning til et akutt brudd som skyldes en enkelt kraftig hendelse, oppstår stressfrakturer når den kumulative belastningen overstiger beinets evne til å reparere seg selv.

Hvor oppstår stressfrakturer?: Ifølge en stor systematisk oversikt av Hoenig et al. (2023) som inkluderte 2 974 beinstressskader, er tibia og metatarser de vanligste lokalisasjonene. Hvilken lokalisasjon som rammes avhenger av idrettstype og belastningsmønster.

Risikofaktorer for stressfraktur: Stressfrakturer oppstår når belastningen overstiger beinets kapasitet. Flere faktorer kan øke denne risikoen, og de deles inn i treningsrelaterte, biologiske og ernæringsmessige faktorer.

Symptomer og diagnostikk: Stressfraktur gir et karakteristisk symptombilde som utvikler seg gradvis over dager til uker
Behandling av stressfrakturer: Behandlingen avhenger kritisk av om stressfrakturen klassifiseres som lav-risiko eller høy-risiko. Denne forskjellen styrer alt fra belastningsnivå til tilhelingshorisonter.

Tilbake til idrett etter stressfraktur: For tidlig retur til full belastning er den vanligste årsaken til tilbakefall. En scoping review fra Sports Medicine (2024) identifiserte fem sentrale kriterier for sikker tilbakevending til idrett etter tibial stressfraktur
Kiropraktorens rolle ved stressfrakturer: Kiropraktorens primære rolle ved stressfrakturer er tidlig identifikasjon, henvisning til riktig bildediagnostikk og biomekanisk optimalisering - ikke direkte behandling av selve frakturen.

Explain balance exercises for Knee Exercises Home Program Complete Guide.

Balance exercises

 Balance and proprioception are central to knee function, particularly after injury. Balance training improves joint position sense and can help reduce the risk of new injuries. These exercises should be included from week 1 but progressed in difficulty.

 Single-leg stand

 Stand on one leg with a slightly bent knee

 Hold your balance for 30 seconds

 Switch sides

 Dosage: 3 x 30 seconds per side

 Progression: Eyes open eyes closed stand on a cushion or unstable surface.

 Tandem stand (heel-to-toe)

 Place one foot directly in front of the other (heel to toe)

 Hold your balance for 30 seconds

 Switch which foot is in front

 Dosage: 3 x 30 seconds per side

 Single-leg mini-squat

 Advanced 

 Stand on one leg with light support from a chair

 Slowly bend the knee to approximately 30 degrees

 Keep the knee in line with the second toe

 Rise slowly back up

 Dosage: 3 x 8 repetitions per side

 Important: This exercise requires good baseline strength. Introduce it in weeks 34 of the program.

Describe diagnosis for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

Diagnosis

 Calcific tendinitis is usually easily diagnosed with X-ray, which clearly shows the calcium deposits.

 X-ray

 X-ray is the first choice and shows calcium deposits well. The appearance of the calcium can provide
 information about which phase the condition is in
 Formative phase: Unclear, "fluffy" calcium

 Resting phase: Dense, well-defined calcium with sharp borders

 Resorptive phase: The calcium becomes "fluffy" with unclear borders again

 Ultrasound

 Ultrasound can also detect calcium deposits and assess the condition of the tendon. The advantage is
 that you can assess the entire rotator cuff without radiation.

 MRI

 MRI is rarely necessary, but may be useful for
 Uncertain diagnosis

 Suspected concurrent rotator cuff tear

 Preparation for possible surgery

 Incidental findings

 Calcium deposits are found incidentally in many people without symptoms. Studies show that up to 20%
 of asymptomatic individuals have calcium in the shoulder on X-ray. Not all calcium causes problems.

Assess red flags: 40-year-old female with pain in both buttock regions and back of both thighs. Worse with prolonged sitting. Tender piriformis bilaterally. Normal SLR. Normal perineal sensation. Normal urination.

URGENCY: SAFE

No red flags identified.

Clinical reasoning — why bilateral buttock pain is NOT CES:
- Bilateral buttock pain is common with piriformis/gluteal dysfunction, especially with prolonged sitting
- Pain stops at THIGH, not down to foot (CES typically causes bilateral sciatica TO FOOT)
- Normal SLR bilaterally = no nerve root irritation
- CRITICAL: Normal perineal sensation and normal urination rules out CES
- Saddle anesthesia = numbness in groin/anus, NOT in gluteal muscles
- Bilateral piriformis syndrome is common with sedentary work

Clinical picture: Bilateral piriformis syndrome / deep gluteal pain.

Safe to treat with piriformis stretching, gluteal strengthening, sitting ergonomics.

Treatment and What You Can Do

 Although the degeneration itself cannot be reversed, symptoms can often be treated very effectively.
 Focus should be on function and symptoms - not on the MRI images.

 Better mobility: Mobilization of stiff joints

 Pain relief: Treatment of muscular components

 Posture correction: Reduce strain on the neck

 Exercise instruction: Strength and stretching exercises

 Proper information: Reduce unnecessary fear

 Exercises and Lifestyle

 Stay active: Regular movement is important for the neck

 Strength training: Strong neck and shoulder support muscles protect

 Good posture: Avoid prolonged forward head position

 Screen breaks: Vary positions throughout the day

 Prognosis

 Most people with neck pain and degenerative changes experience good
 improvement with treatment. The degeneration doesn't disappear, but symptoms can be effectively
 controlled. Many live symptom-free for long periods.

Patient asks: "What's the difference between SI joint pain and sciatica?"

SI joint pain typically radiates to the buttocks and thigh, but rarely below the knee. No neurological deficits. Sciatica is caused by nerve root involvement and often causes pain all the way to the foot, with numbness, tingling or weakness.

Red Flags - When to See a Doctor

 

 
 Seek medical attention immediately for:

 
 Sudden, intense foot pain without obvious cause

 Swelling, redness and warmth combined with fever

 Numbness or tingling that doesn't go away

 Foot ulcers that don't heal (especially with diabetes)

 Significant worsening of pain during or after training

 Cracking or crunching sounds followed by acute pain

 
 

 Mild muscle soreness after foot training is normal, especially at the start. But sharp pain, numbness, or swelling are signs that you should take a break and possibly seek evaluation.

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for PIFP: Persistent Idiopatisk Ansiktssmerte.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hva er PIFP?

 PIFP (Persistent Idiopatisk Ansiktssmerte) er vedvarende ansiktssmerte som varer mer enn 2 timer daglig i over 3 måneder, uten identifiserbar Årsak. Det er en eksklusjonsdiagnose som stilles når andre Årsaker er utelukket.

 

 
 Kan PIFP kureres?

 PIFP er ofte en kronisk tilstand, men de fleste oppnår betydelig bedring med riktig behandling. Målet er smertelindring og forbedret livskvalitet, ikke nødvendigvis fullstendig smertefrihet.

 

 
 Hva er forskjellen mellom PIFP og trigeminal nevralgi?

 Trigeminal nevralgi gir korte, intense smerteattakker (sekunder til minutter) langs trigeminusnervens baner. PIFP gir vedvarende, dov smerte som ikke følger nerveanatomi og mangler de skarpe attackene.

 

 
 Kan kiropraktor hjelpe ved PIFP?

 Kiropraktoren kan bidra til å utelukke TMD og behandle eventuelle medfølgende nakke- eller kjevekomponenter. PIFP responderer imidlertid ofte ikke godt på manuell behandling alene og krever vanligvis tverrfaglig tilnærming.

 

 
 Hvorfor får jeg ikke diagnose etter mange undersøkelser?

 PIFP er en eksklusjonsdiagnose som krever at andre Årsaker utelukkes først. Dette kan ta tid og mange undersøkelser. Mange pasienter har vårt hos flere spesialister får de får riktig diagnose.

 

 
 Er smerten min "innbilt"?

 Nei, PIFP er en reell biologisk smertetilstand med forandringer i nervesystemets smerteprosessering. At vi ikke finner en strukturell Årsak betyr ikke at smerten ikke er ekte.

 

 
 Bør je...

Provide a structured clinical overview of Cervical Foraminal Stenosis.

What is Cervical Foraminal Stenosis?: Cervical foraminal stenosis means that the nerve openings on the sides of the cervical vertebrae have
 become narrower. These openings are called "foramen" (plural: foramina) and are where the spinal nerves
 leave the spine to supply the arms and hands with sensation and movement.

Causes of Foraminal Stenosis: The most common cause. Over time, the vertebrae can develop bone spurs (osteophytes) that grow into
 the foramen and make the opening narrower.

Symptoms: A classic test for foraminal stenosis: The head
 is bent backward and rotated toward the painful side, then light pressure is applied downward. A
 positive test reproduces radiation to the arm. This "closes" the foramen and provokes symptoms.

Treatment: Most people with cervical foraminal stenosis respond well to conservative treatment. Studies show that
 75-90% achieve good symptom control without surgery.

Red Flags - When Should You See a Doctor?: These symptoms may indicate cervical myelopathy (spinal
 cord involvement) or other serious conditions requiring prompt evaluation.

Frequently Asked Questions: Foraminal stenosis affects the
 nerve openings on the sides of the spine where nerves exit, causing symptoms in the arm/hand. Central
 stenosis affects the spinal canal itself and can cause symptoms in both arms and legs, as well as gait
 disturbances.

Hva er migrene?: Migrene er en nevrologisk tilstand - ikke "bare hodepine ". Det er en kompleks forstyrrelse i hjernens funksjon som gir gjentatte anfall av moderat til sterk hodepine. Smerten er ofte ensidig og pulserende, og forverres typisk av fysisk aktivitet.

Typer migrene: Migrene er ikke en tilstand, men en gruppe relaterte tilstander. Her er de vanligste typene, rangert fra vanligst til sjeldnest
Triggere og risikofaktorer: De fleste med migrene har individuelle triggere som kan utløse anfall. En stor studie (Kelman, Cephalalgia 2007) kartla de vanligste
De fire fasene i et migreneanfall: Et migreneanfall forløper typisk gjennom fire faser, selv om ikke alle opplever samtlige
Hvordan stilles diagnosen?: Migrenediagnosen stilles klinisk - det finnes ingen blodprøver eller bildediagnostikk som bekrefter migrene. Diagnosen baseres på sykehistorien og at symptomene oppfyller kriteriene i International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD-3, 2018).

Røde flagg - når du må søke lege: Basert på SNNOOP10-kriteriene (Do et al., Neurology 2019)

Behandling: Det er viktig å være årlig om hva forskningen viser: Evidensen for spinal manipulasjonsbehandling ved migrene er klassifisert som lav til svært lav sikkerhet ifølge GRADE-kriterier (Posadzki et al., Systematic Reviews 2024).

Prognose - hvordan går det?: Migrene er en kronisk tilstand - målet er å redusere anfallsfrekvens og intensitet, ikke nødvendigvis å fjerne alle anfall. Data fra den amerikanske AMPP-studien (Lipton et al., 2007) viser at ved 1-Ørs oppfølging

Provide a structured clinical overview of Foot Exercises That Work: Exercises for Stronger Feet.

Why Foot Training?: Foot training is not just for athletes or those with existing problems. Research shows impressive results for everyone who invests time in their feet
What Does the Research Say?: In recent years, several groundbreaking studies have documented the effectiveness of foot training
Exercise 1: Short Foot: Short foot is the most fundamental exercise for foot health. It activates the intrinsic muscles that support the arch - muscles that are often "switched off" after years in supportive shoes.

Exercise 2: Toe Spreading: After years in narrow shoes, many have lost the ability to actively spread their toes. Toe spreading reactivates the abductor muscles and improves forefoot stability.

Exercise 3: Towel Curls: A classic exercise that strengthens the flexor muscles under the foot. This exercise is particularly useful for those with plantar fasciitis.

Exercise 4: Focused Heel Raises: Heel raises (calf raises) are a well-known exercise, but with proper focus they become powerful foot training. The key is to keep the arch active throughout the movement.

Exercise 5: Single-Leg Balance: Functional training that dynamically challenges the entire foot. This exercise bridges the gap between isolated foot exercises and daily function.

Suggested Weekly Program: Here is a simple program you can follow. Adjust according to your level and available time.

Barefoot Walking and Minimalist Shoes: The Liverpool study (Curtis 2021) showed that 6 months in minimalist shoes increased foot strength by 57% - without specific exercises . Simply by letting the foot work naturally.

When Can You Expect Results?: Foot training requires patience, but results come gradually
Red Flags - When to See a Doctor: Mild muscle soreness after foot training is normal, especially at the start. But sharp pain, numbness, or swelling are signs that you should take a break and possibly seek evaluation.

Differential diagnoses for Shoulder Impingement?

Overuse and repetitive movements

 Most common 

 Repetitive overhead arm movements are the most frequent trigger. This applies to both occupations (painters, electricians, plumbers) and sports (swimming, tennis, handball, volleyball).

Muscular imbalance

 Weakness in the rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers (the muscles that control the shoulder blade) causes the upper arm bone to migrate upward, narrowing the subacromial space. This is one of the most important modifiable risk factors.

Posture-related factors

 A forward-leaning posture with protracted shoulders (rounded upper back) alters shoulder biomechanics and can contribute to irritation of subacromial structures.

Describe causes and risk factors for Metatarsalgia.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Metatarsalgia develops when the forefoot is exposed to abnormally high or prolonged loading.

 Common Causes

 Improper Footwear Most common cause 

 High-heeled shoes, too tight shoes, or shoes without adequate cushioning significantly increase the
 load on the forefoot.

 Biomechanical Factors

 High arch (pes cavus), stiff ankle, long 2nd toe (Morton's toe), or hypermobile joints can lead to
 uneven load distribution.

 Overuse

 Too rapid increase in activity, prolonged standing work, or intensive running training can overload the
 forefoot.

 Hallux Valgus Often
 concurrent 

 A crooked big toe causes weight to shift to the 2nd and 3rd metatarsal, which become overloaded. Hallux rigidus can cause similar loading changes.

 Risk Factors

 Overweight (increased load per step)

 Age over 50 (thinner fat pads under the foot)

 High heels (shift weight forward)

 Diabetes (altered sensation and blood flow)

 Rheumatoid arthritis

 Sports with lots of running and jumping - can also lead to Achilles tendinopathy or stress fracture

Differential diagnoses for Foot and Ankle Problems?

Plantar Fasciopathy (Heel Pain)

 10% lifetime risk 

 Go to full article on plantar fasciopathy 

 The most common cause of heel pain. Affects approx. 10% of the population during their lifetime. Most common between 40-60 years. Women have 2.5 times higher risk than men.

 What is it? Degenerative changes in the plantar fascia - the connective tissue band
 that stretches from the heel to the toes. Despite the name "fasciitis", it's not inflammation but
 breakdown of collagen fibres. Therefore the term "fasciopathy" is now used.

 Characteristics: Intense stabbing heel pain with the first steps in the morning
 ("start pain"). The pain often improves after a few minutes, but can return after prolonged activity.

 Most important risk factors
 Limited ankle mobility ( 23x increased risk at zero degrees dorsiflexion)

 Overweight (BMI >30 gives 5-6x increased risk )

 Occupations with lots of standing

 Prognosis: 80-90% improve with conservative treatment within 12 months. Shockwave treatment has the strongest long-term evidence for persistent cases.

Ankle Sprains and Chronic Instability

 19-27 per 1000/year 

 Go to full article on ankle sprains 

 One of the most common musculoskeletal injuries. Annual incidence of 19-27 per 1000 people . 85% affect the lateral (outer) ligaments. Among athletes, the incidence is even higher - up to 11.55 per 1000 training sessions.

 Serious complication: 40% develop chronic ankle instability within 12
 months after first-time sprain if rehabilitation isn't done properly. Among athletes in high-risk
 sports, the numbers are even higher - up to 75% in gymnastics and trampoline.

Achilles Tendinopathy

 6% of active people 

 Go to full article on Achilles tendinopathy 

 The body's thickest and strongest tendon. Affects approx. 6% of physically active people . Lifetime risk for elite runners can be as high as 52%. Important: 65% of cases occur independently of sports activity.

 Numbness in both hands/feet simultaneously 

 Progressive weakness in arm or hand

 Bladder or bowel problems 

 Numbness after injury (fall, car accident)

 Combination with headache, vision disturbances or speech difficulties 

 Rapid worsening over hours to days

 These symptoms may indicate more serious conditions requiring faster evaluation, such as spinal cord
 compression, stroke, or multiple sclerosis.

Explain breathing exercises that actually work for Breathing, Stress and Back.

Breathing Exercises That Actually Work

 What Does the Research Say?

 A meta-analysis from 2023 (Fincham et al., Scientific Reports) analyzed 12 randomized studies with 785
 participants. Conclusion: Breathing exercises provide significant stress reduction with
 an effect size of Hedges' g = -0.35 compared to control groups.

 The Stanford study (Yilmaz Balban et al., 2023) compared four techniques in 108 participants over 28
 days. The surprise: Cyclic sighing (extended exhalation) was more effective than mindfulness
 meditation for improving mood and reducing stress.

 Practical Techniques

 Diaphragmatic Breathing

 Place one hand on your belly and one on your chest. Breathe in through your nose so that your belly
 rises while your chest stays relatively still. Breathe out slowly through your mouth.

 Frequency: 4-6 breaths per minute

 Duration: Minimum 5 minutes

 Frequency: Daily, preferably several short sessions

 Cyclic Sighing (from the Stanford Study)

 Breathe in through your nose until your lungs feel full

 Take another small breath to fill up completely

 Breathe out slowly and completely through your mouth

 Repeat for 5 minutes

 4-4-4-4 (Box Breathing)

 Breathe in for 4 seconds, hold for 4 seconds, breathe out for 4 seconds, hold for 4 seconds. Repeat.

 This technique is used by US Navy SEALs for stress management, but the Stanford study showed that
 cyclic sighing was more effective.

Describe causes of neck pain in pregnant women for Neck Pain During Pregnancy.

Causes of neck pain in pregnant women

 Neck pain during pregnancy is caused by a combination of factors
 Hormonal changes (affects all pregnant women)

 During pregnancy, the body produces the hormone relaxin , which loosens ligaments and connective tissue to prepare the body for childbirth. Relaxin levels are highest in the first trimester, but the hormone remains in the body throughout pregnancy and for several months after delivery.

 Postural changes and center of gravity shift

 As the belly grows, the body's center of gravity shifts forward. To compensate, many pregnant women lean backward, leading to increased curvature in the lower back. This postural change propagates up the spine and affects the neck.

 Weight gain and breast enlargement

 The natural weight gain during pregnancy - typically 10-16 kilograms - puts extra strain on all weight-bearing joints. Breasts can increase significantly in size, pulling shoulders forward and creating tension in the upper back and neck.

 Sleep disturbances

 Good sleep becomes more difficult as pregnancy progresses. Many pregnant women struggle to find a comfortable sleeping position, need to get up multiple times during the night, and generally have restless sleep. Poor sleeping positions can lead to stiff and painful neck in the morning.

Explain prognosis and expected course for Hallux Rigidus.

Prognosis and Expected Course

 Hallux rigidus is a progressive condition, but the rate of progression varies significantly. Many live
 well with the condition for many years with proper treatment.

 Early Phase (Grade 1)

 Periodic pain, good response to conservative treatment

 Moderate Phase (Grade 2)

 More constant symptoms, need for adapted footwear

 Severe Phase (Grades 3-4)

 Significant functional limitation, surgery may be appropriate

 Factors Affecting Prognosis

 Early treatment is associated with better outcomes

 Activity adaptation can slow progression

 Proper footwear is essential for reducing load

 Maintaining movement is important as long as it's pain-free

Rehabiliteringsvurdering - 6 uker post ACL-rekonstruksjon

Forventede milepæler 6 uker:
- Full ekstensjon (lik kontralateral side)
- Fleksjon 90-110°
- Gange uten krykker og uten halting
- God quadriceps-aktivering (straight leg raise uten lag)
- Redusert hevelse

Undersøkelse:
- ROM: Aktiv/passiv fleksjon og ekstensjon, sammenlign sider
- Hevelse: Omkretsemåling 1cm over patella
- Muskelaktivering: SLR, quadriceps setting, VMO kontroll
- Gangmønster: Observere for antalgisk mønster
- Arr: Vurder tilheling, mobilitet

Behandlingsfokus (Uke 6-12):
- ROM: Oppnå full fleksjon gradvis
- Styrke: Lukkede kjede-øvelser (squat, leg press, step-up)
- Propriosepsjon: Balansebrett, ettbensbalanse
- Gangtrening: Normalisere gangmønster
- Sykkel (lav motstand)
- Arrmobilisering

Ikke tillatt ennå:
- Løping (vanligvis fra 12-16 uker)
- Pivotering/retningsendring
- Kontaktsport (6-9 mnd minimum)

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Triggerpunkter i Hofte og Bekken.

1 Hva er triggerpunkter?: Triggerpunkter er hyperirriterte områder i muskelvev å ofte beskrevet som "knuter" eller
 stramme bénd i muskelen. Det som gjør triggerpunkter spesielle er deres evne til å gi
 referert smerte : smerte som kjennes et helt annet sted enn der
 triggerpunktet faktisk sitter.

2 Vanlige triggerpunkter i hofte og bekken: Hofte- og bekkenregionen har flere muskler som er spesielt utsatt for å utvikle triggerpunkter. Her er de viktigste
3 Hvorfor utvikles triggerpunkter?: Hvis triggerpunkter ikke behandles, kan de bli kroniske og bidra til
 sentral sensitivisering å en tilstand der nervesystemet blir
 overfølsomt for smerte. Dette gjør behandlingen mer kompleks og tidkrevende.

4 Triggerpunkter vs. andre diagnoser: Triggerpunkter i hofte og bekken kan gi symptomer som lett forveksles med andre tilstander
5 Hvordan diagnostiseres triggerpunkter?: Diagnostisering av triggerpunkter krever grundig klinisk undersøkelse. Det finnes ingen
 bildediagnostikk som kan påvise triggerpunkter direkte – MR og CT vil være normale.

Describe symptoms and signs of Chronic Dizziness and PPPD.

Symptoms and Characteristics

 

 Main Symptoms:

 
 Non-rotational dizziness: It doesn't spin, but it rocks, sways or feels like being on a boat

 Brain fog: Concentration difficulties, mental fatigue - reported by about 81%

 Exhaustion: Extreme tiredness, worst in the afternoon - reported by about 85%

 Visual hypersensitivity: Worsening in busy environments (shopping centers, supermarkets)

 Movement intolerance: Symptoms worsen with both active and passive movements (car, bus)

 

 Mental Health and PPPD

 60% of PPPD patients have clinically significant anxiety and 45% have depression, but 25% have no psychiatric condition at all. This underscores that PPPD is a neurological condition - not "just anxiety." Similar mental health challenges are also seen in other chronic dizziness conditions like Meniere's disease and MdDS.

 
 Red Flags - Call 113 or go to emergency room for:

 
 Acute dizziness with headache - especially "the worst headache ever"

 Double vision, visual disturbances or visual field loss

 Speech difficulties or swallowing problems

 Numbness, weakness or paralysis in face, arm or leg

 Sudden one-sided hearing loss

 Dizziness with chest pain or palpitations

Diskogen smerte

 Skivene mellom ryggvirvlene kan våre en smertekilde, selv uten at det foreligger prolaps. Trykk på skivens ytterste lag (annulus) kan gi lokal korsryggsmerte.

 

 Risikofaktorer:

 
 Stillasittende livsstil eller fysisk krevende arbeid

 Tidligere episoder med korsryggsmerter

 Dårlig kjernemuskulatur

 Røyking Øker risikoen for ryggsmerter

 Overvekt

 
 

 
 
 
 3
 Symptomer på hekseskudd

 

 Symptomene ved hekseskudd er typisk lokalisert til korsryggen og kan variere i intensitet:

 Karakteristiske symptomer:

 
 Akutt smerte: Plutselig innsettende, ofte beskrevet som "stikkende" eller "lammende"

 Stivhet: Betydelig redusert bevegelighet i ryggen

 Muskelspenning: Ofte palbar spenning i ryggmuskulaturen

 Smerteførsterking: Bevegelse, hosting, nysing og anstrengelse forverrer smertene

 Lettelse i hvile: Smertene avtar ofte i stillestende stillinger

 

 
 Viktig skille: Ukomplisert vs. komplisert

 Ved ukomplisert hekseskudd er smertene begrenset til korsryggen uten utstrålende symptomer til beina. Dersom du opplever utstrålende smerter, nummenhet eller kraftsvikt i beina, kan dette tyde på nerveaffeksjon (isjias) og bør vurderes av helsepersonell.

What is the prognosis for T4 Syndrome: When Upper Thoracic Spine Causes Hand Symptoms?

Prognosis

 

 There are no published data on long-term prognosis or recurrence rates for T4 syndrome. What is known is
 based on case reports and clinical experience:

 
 What We Know

 
 Short-term Prognosis

 Case reports often describe rapid symptom relief after manual treatment - some patients experience
 immediate improvement, others gradual improvement over weeks. Hirai & Thomson (2016) reported
 complete symptom resolution after manipulation treatment.

 

 
 Recurrence Risk

 NHS Scotland suggests that the clinical course probably resembles back and neck complaints in general
 - meaning recurrence is common, and symptoms may have an episodic pattern. Continued attention to
 posture and ergonomics is probably important for preventing recurrence.

 

 
 Realistic Expectations

 Most patients who actually have T4 syndrome respond well to treatment. But it's important to remember
 that the diagnosis is uncertain - if treatment doesn't produce results, it may be because the symptoms
 have another cause.

Beskriv Cervikal radikulopati - nerverotsmerter for Nakkesmerter - Komplett guide til Årsaker, behandling og røde flagg.

Cervikal radikulopati - nerverotsmerter

 

 Gå til full artikkel om nakkeprolaps ?

 Når en nerve i nakken kommer i klem, kan det gi utstraling ned i armen, ofte med prikking, nummenhet eller svakhet. Dette kalles cervikal radikulopati og rammer omtrent 0,8-1,8 per 1000 personer Årlig (StatPearls, 2026).

 Til sammenligning har over 30% av befolkningen nakkesmerter hvert Ør, så nerverotaffeksjon er relativt sjelden. Det positive er at prognosen er god: 75-90% blir bedre med konservativ behandling.

 
 Hvilken nerve er påvirket? Symptomguide

 
 C6-nerven (tommel og pekefinger): Nummenhet/prikking i tommel og pekefinger, svakhet ved å bøye albuen (biceps), redusert biceps-refleks

 C7-nerven (langfinger): Vanligst - 60-70% av tilfellene. Nummenhet i langfinger, svakhet ved å strekke albuen (triceps), redusert triceps-refleks

 C8-nerven (ring- og lillefinger): Nummenhet i ring- og lillefinger, svak gripekraft, problemer med fingerbevegelser

 
 

 Karpaltunnel eller nakke? Slik skiller du

 Nummenhet i handen kan komme fra nakken (cervikal radikulopati) eller fra handleddet (karpaltunnelsyndrom). Interessant nok viser en studie at 62,2% av pasienter med cervikal radikulopati også har karpaltunnelsyndrom - sakalt "double crush syndrome".

 
 
 
 Kjennetegn
 Karpaltunnelsyndrom
 Cervikal radikulopati
 
 
 
 
 Hvilke fingre?
 Tommel, pekefinger, langfinger
 Avhenger av nerverot
 
 
 Når verst?
 Om natten, vakner av nummenhet
 Ved nakkebevegelse
 
 
 Hva gir lindring?
 Riste han...

Describe Can You See Both? for Chiropractor vs Physiotherapist: What's the Difference?.

Can You See Both?

 

 Absolutely! Many patients combine treatment from both a chiropractor and physiotherapist. For example, a chiropractor can help with acute joint problems, while a physiotherapist follows up with longer-term exercise programs.

 
 The Most Important Thing

 The most important thing is not what title the practitioner has, but that you find a skilled and evidence-based practitioner who takes the time to examine you thoroughly and create a good treatment plan.

 

 Feel free to ask about:

 
 The practitioner's experience with your type of condition

 What you can expect from the treatment

 How many treatments are typically needed

 What you can do yourself between treatments

How is GTPS - Pain on the Outside of the Hip diagnosed?

Diagnosis

 

 The diagnosis is primarily made clinically through history and physical examination.

 Clinical Tests

 
 Palpation of the greater trochanter - tenderness over the bony prominence

 FABER test - reproduces lateral hip pain

 Single leg stance - pain after 30 seconds

 Resisted hip abduction - pain with resistance

 

 Imaging

 MRI can show tendon degeneration, partial tears, or bursitis, but is rarely necessary
 to make the diagnosis. Clinical examination is often sufficient.

 X-ray can rule out osteoarthritis and other bone changes.

Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 

 Her må man våre Årlig om evidensgrunnlaget: Det finnes per i dag ingen randomiserte kontrollerte studier på kiropraktisk behandling spesifikt for Scheuermanns sykdom. Den tilgjengelige forskningen bestar av kasuistikker (enkeltstående case-rapporter).

 Det betyr ikke at behandling er uten verdi. Basert på klinisk erfaring og generell ryggforskning kan kiropraktisk behandling bidra til:

 
 Kiropraktisk behandling kan bidra til

 
 Forbedret mobilitet i stive brystryggssegmenter

 Reduksjon av muskelspenninger og triggerpunkter

 Bedret ribbebevegelse og pustemekanikk

 Smertelindring gjennom leddmobilisering

 Veiledning om Øvelser og ergonomi

 Funksjonell forbedring selv om strukturen består

 
 

 
 Viktig forventningsavklaring

 Kiropraktisk behandling kan IKKE "rette ut" en strukturell kyfose hos voksne. Målet er symptomlindring og bedre funksjon, ikke strukturell endring.

 

 Behandlingsforløp

 For voksne med symptomgivende Scheuermanns sykdom vil et typisk forløp innebøre en prøveperiode på 6-8 behandlinger over 4-6 uker for å vurdere respons.  Responsen varierer betydelig fra person til person. Noen har god og varig effekt, andre opplever kun kortvarig lindring, og noen responderer ikke merkbart. En Årlig evaluering etter prøveperioden er vik...

Describe the three types of tos for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS): Numb Arm and Tingling.

The Three Types of TOS

 TOS is classified into three types based on which structures are compressed
 1. Neurogenic TOS (nTOS)

 90-97% of cases 

 By far the most common form. The nerves in the brachial plexus (the nerve network supplying the arm)
 become compressed.

 Typical symptoms
 Pain in neck, shoulder and arm

 Numbness and tingling in fingers (often 4th and 5th finger)

 Weakness in hand/grip strength

 Symptoms worsen with overhead work

 "Numb arm" at night

 2. Venous TOS (vTOS)

 2-3% of cases 

 Compression of the subclavian vein (the vein that carries blood from the arm).

 Typical symptoms
 Swelling in arm and hand

 Bluish discoloration (cyanosis)

 Heaviness sensation in the arm

 Visible dilated veins on shoulder/chest

 Can lead to blood clot (Paget-Schroetter syndrome)

 3. Arterial TOS (aTOS)

 1% of cases 

 Compression of the subclavian artery (the artery that supplies blood to the arm). Rare but
 potentially serious.

 Typical symptoms
 Cold, pale arm/hand

 Pain with activity (claudication)

 Weak or absent pulse in the wrist

 Can lead to embolism or aneurysm

 Red Flags - Seek Medical Attention Immediately

 Sudden cold, pale or blue arm

 Severe swelling in the arm that develops rapidly

 Severe chest or arm pain without clear cause

 Weak or absent pulse in the wrist

 Vascular TOS (venous and arterial) requires prompt medical evaluation and may need acute
 treatment.

Hva forårsaker Vestibularisnevritt?

Årsaker og mekanismer

 

 Den eksakte Årsaken er ikke fullstendig klarlagt, men flere faktorer er identifisert:

 
 Viral Årsak (hovedhypotese)

 Reaktivering av herpes simplex-virus type 1 (HSV-1) i balansenervegangliet er den mest aksepterte teorien. HSV-1 - det samme viruset som gir munnsar - er påvist i omtrent to tredjedeler av menneskers Vestibulære ganglier ved obduksjonsstudier. Viruset kan ligge latent i nerven i arevis, for så å reaktiveres og skape betennelse og hevelse.

 

 Siden balansenerven går gjennom en trang benkanal i skallen, kan selv moderat hevelse klemme av nervefibrene og stoppe signaloverforingen. De fleste pasienter har hatt en virusinfeksjon i ukene for symptomdebut.

Explain treatment of neck-jaw problems for TMD and Neck Pain: Why Jaw and Neck Are Connected.

Treatment of Neck-Jaw Problems

 A holistic approach gives the good results
 Neck Treatment

 Mobilization/manipulation: Of stiff joints, especially C0-C2

 Soft tissue treatment: Suboccipital muscles, SCM, trapezius

 Trigger point therapy: Focus on referred pain patterns

 Jaw Treatment

 Jaw joint mobilization: Distraction and glide techniques

 Intraoral treatment: Lateral pterygoid, masseter from inside

 Masseter treatment: External trigger point therapy

 Posture Work

 Ergonomic guidance: Screen height, chair adjustment

 Chin tucks: Exercise to reduce FHP

 Shoulder blade exercises: Retraction and depression

 Thoracic mobility: Stretches and exercises for upper back

 Exercises for Home Use

 Chin Tuck

 Sit or stand with neutral posture

 Draw chin straight back (as if making a "double chin")

 Hold 5 seconds, release gently

 Repeat 10 times, 3-5 times daily

 Neck Stretch

 Tilt head gently to the side (ear toward shoulder)

 Hold 20-30 seconds

 Repeat on opposite side

 Add gentle rotation for variation

 Chest Muscle Stretch

 Stand in a doorway with forearms against the frame

 Take a step forward until you feel stretch in the chest

 Hold 30 seconds

 Important for counteracting forward-leaning shoulders

Beskriv Hvorfor hjernen "glemmer" å skru av alarmen for Kronisk Svimmelhet og PPPD.

Hvorfor hjernen "glemmer" å skru av alarmen

 

 Tenk deg et innbruddsalarm i huset. Etter et faktisk innbrudd (en akutt svimmelhetsepisode), justerer du fålsomheten til maks. Plutselig går alarmen hver gang vinden bløser. Slik fungerer PPPD.

 Etter en akutt hendelse - som krystallsyke, vestibularisnevritt, hjernerystelse eller en periode med intens stress - går hjernen inn i en "krisemodus". Ved PPPD glemmer hjernen å skru av denne krisemodusen.

 Tre ting skjer:

 
 Visuell avhengighet

 Hjernen stoler ikke lenger på balansesystemet i Øret, så den klamrer seg til synet. Derfor blir du svimmel på supermarkedet eller når du scroller på mobilen. Dette er også vanlig ved vestibulær migrene.

 

 
 Kroppslig stivhet

 Du spenner ubevisst muskler i nakke og ben for å "holde deg fast". Dette gir sekundære nakkesmerter og en stiv gange, lignende det man ser ved nakkesvimmelhet.

 

 
 Angst-loop

 Hver gang du kjenner ustøhet, tenker hjernen "Fare!" og skrur opp alarmen enda mer.

 

 
 Hva skjer i hjernen ved PPPD?

 Nevroavbildningsstudier har vist at dette ikke er "innbilning" - det er målbare endringer i hjernens funksjon. Redusert aktivitet i den parietoinsulære vestibulære cortex (PIVC), og Økt aktivitet i visuelle områder. Den gode nyheten er at hjernen er plastisk - med riktig behandling kan disse mønstrene reverseres.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Thoracic Back Pain: Causes, Symptoms and Treatment.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Is it dangerous when my back cracks?

 No. The sound during manipulation is due to the release of gas bubbles in the joint fluid - completely harmless and usually painless.

 

 
 Can thoracic back pain come from the heart?

 Pain from the heart can be felt in the chest and back, but is usually accompanied by other symptoms such as breathing difficulties, nausea or radiation to arm/jaw. When in doubt, contact a doctor.

 

 
 Do I need X-ray or MRI?

 Rarely. Imaging is only necessary when there's suspicion of serious underlying cause (red flags). For most musculoskeletal complaints, clinical examination provides sufficient information.

 

 
 How long do the complaints last?

 Acute complaints often improve within 2-6 weeks. For chronic complaints (over 12 weeks), it may take longer, and a combination of treatment and self-effort is important.

 

 
 Can stress cause back pain?

 Yes, absolutely. Mental stress leads to increased muscle tension and altered breathing patterns, which in turn can cause physical pain in the neck and thoracic spine. The connection is well documented.

 

 
 Should I rest or be active?

 Moderate activity is usually better than bed rest. Movement promotes blood circulation and prevents muscles from stiffening further.

Hvordan diagnostiseres Superior Kanal Dehiscens Syndrom (SCDS)?

Differensialdiagnoser - hva kan ligne?

 

 SCDS kalles "orets store etterligner" fordi symptomene kan ligne flere andre tilstander:

 
 Menieres sykdom

 Gir også Hørselstap og svimmelhet, men anfallene kommer spontant og varer 20 minutter til flere timer. Ved SCDS er symptomene tidsrelatert til spesifikke lyd- eller trykkutlosere.

 

 
 BPPV (krystallsyke)

 Utloses av hodebevegelser og gir kortvarig roterende svimmelhet som avtar ved gjentatte bevegelser. SCDS utloses av lyd og trykk, ikke hodestilling.

 

 
 Otosklerose

 Gir også Hørselstap i lave frekvenser, men ved otosklerose er stapediusrefleksen borte - ved SCDS er den normal. Denne forskjellen er viktig fordi stapedektomi (operasjon for otosklerose) er kontraindisert ved SCDS.

Describe symptoms and signs of SLAP Lesion: Everything You Need to Know.

Symptoms

 

 Symptoms of SLAP lesion can be vague and overlap with many other shoulder conditions:

 Common symptoms

 
 Deep pain: Often difficult to localize, "inside" the shoulder

 Pain during overhead activity: Especially when throwing or hitting above the head
 

 Clicking or snapping: Mechanical symptoms during movement (see clicking in the shoulder)

 Pain in "late cocking" position: Arm back and up, ready to throw

 Feeling of instability: Shoulder feels "loose" or "gives way"

 Reduced throwing velocity/distance: In athletes

 

 
 Symptoms that may point to SLAP

 
 Pain at the end of the throwing motion

 Clicking at specific shoulder positions

 Pain during biceps loading combined with overhead pain

 Feeling of "dead arm" after throwing

 
 

 
 Diagnostic challenge

 SLAP lesions are notoriously difficult to diagnose clinically. Symptoms overlap with many conditions
 (impingement, rotator cuff problems, biceps tendinopathy), and no single test is sufficiently
 reliable. Shoulder pain can also be worsened by poor ergonomics.

Describe Why do headache and dizziness often occur together? in the context of Headache and Dizziness.

Why do headache and dizziness often occur together?

 Headache and dizziness occur together three times more often than by chance. Over 51% of people with recurring headaches also experience dizziness. The most common causes are vestibular migraine and cervicogenic dizziness from the neck.

Describe how is the diagnosis made? for Thrower's Shoulder and GIRD: When Throwing Causes Shoulder Pain.

How is the Diagnosis Made?

 The diagnosis is made primarily through clinical examination focusing on movement patterns and
 provocation tests.

 Movement assessment

 Rotation measurement

 Both shoulders are measured at 90 degrees abduction
 Internal rotation (IR): Normally about 70-90 degrees

 External rotation (ER): Normally about 90-110 degrees

 Total ROM: IR + ER should be approximately equal on both sides

 GIRD criteria

 Asymptomatic GIRD: Reduced IR on dominant side, but total ROM is preserved
 (increased ER compensates).

 Symptomatic GIRD: Reduced total ROM (>5 degrees) compared to opposite side, or pain
 during testing.

 Clinical tests

 Posterior impingement test

 The arm is brought into maximum external rotation and abduction. Pain in the back of the shoulder
 indicates internal impingement.

 Sleeper stretch position

 Test internal rotation with patient lying on side. Compare with opposite side.

 SLAP tests 

 O'Brien's test, anterior slide, biceps load II to assess labral pathology.

 Imaging

 Imaging is rarely necessary to diagnose GIRD, but may be relevant for
 Suspected structural damage (SLAP, rotator cuff tear)

 Lack of response to conservative treatment

 Acute injury or trauma

 MR arthrography is best for assessing labrum and rotator cuff in throwing athletes.

What is the prognosis for Costochondritis and Chest Pain?

Prognosis

 

 Costochondritis generally has a good prognosis. Over 90% of patients experience symptom relief within 3-4
 weeks with conservative treatment (StatPearls, 2024). Most cases last from a few weeks to 1-2 months.

 
 
 90%+
 improve within 3-4 weeks
 

 
 4%
 recurrence risk
 

 
 50%
 may have some discomfort after 1 year
 

 

 Recurrence risk: The study by Disla et al. (1994) found a recurrence rate of only 4%
 after two years. This is relatively low compared to many other musculoskeletal conditions.

 Long-term prognosis: About 50% of patients may still have some discomfort after 1 year,
 and about 33% still have tenderness on palpation at 12-month follow-up (Medscape; Spalding et al., 2003).
 Chronic or treatment-resistant cases may require evaluation by a rheumatologist to rule out inflammatory
 diseases.

Forklar T4 for en pasient.

T4-syndrom er en klinisk diagnose som beskriver et symptommønster der dysfunksjon i øvre brystrygg - særlig rundt fjerde brystvirvel (T4) - gir symptomer som stråler ut i armene og hendene. Typisk opplever pasienten prikking, nummenhet eller en "hanske-lignende" følelse i begge hender, ofte uten at bildediagnostikk eller nervemalinger viser noe unormalt.

 Tilstanden ble først beskrevet i 1986 av den australske fysioterapeuten Geoffrey Maitland og N. McGuckin, som observerte at disse pasienter med øvre brystryggplager hadde et karakteristisk symptommønster som responderte på mobilisering av thoracalcolumna.

Oppsøk lege ved

 BPPV is the most common cause of dizziness and accounts for 17-42% of all cases. The condition occurs when small calcium crystals dislodge from their normal place in the inner ear and end up in the semicircular canals.

 
 Brief, intense spinning episodes (10-60 seconds)

 Triggered by specific head movements (turning in bed, looking up)

 Nausea and involuntary eye movements (nystagmus)

 Symptoms come and go, can last for months

 
 Treatment: The Epley maneuver has a success rate of 80-90% and can provide immediate improvement.

Describe What Can You Do Yourself? for Kyphosis and Poor Posture.

What Can You Do Yourself?

 

 Self-effort is crucial for lasting improvement. Here are three exercises with documented effect:

 
 1. Thoracic Extension on Roller

 Yoo (2018) documented 5.8 degrees reduction in kyphosis angle over just 12 days with this exercise.

 
 Lie on your back with a foam roller placed crosswise under your upper back. Support your head with your
 hands and gently lean back over the roller. Hold for 5-10 seconds, repeat 5-10 times. Move the roller
 slightly up or down to target different levels.
 

 

 
 2. Wall Angels

 Activates the weak muscles between the shoulder blades.

 
 Stand with your back against the wall, back of head, shoulder blades and lower back in contact with the
 wall. Hold your arms at 90 degree angles ("hands up" position) against the wall. Slowly slide your arms
 up and down along the wall while maintaining contact. 3 sets x 10 repetitions.
 

 

 
 3. Doorway Chest Stretch

 Tokita et al. (2021) showed that this stretch significantly increased pectoral muscle length and
 improved shoulder position.

 
 Stand in a doorway with forearms against the door frame, elbows at shoulder height. Take a small step
 forward and lean your chest through the opening until you feel a stretch in front of your shoulders.
 Hold 15-30 seconds, repeat 3-5 times.

Explain stretching exercises for Shoulder Exercises.

Stretching exercises

 Stretching maintains shoulder mobility and counteracts tight muscles that can contribute to poor alignment and pain.

 Pectoralis stretch in doorway

 Stand in a doorway with your forearm against the frame, elbow at shoulder height

 Take a small step forward with one foot

 Lean gently forward until you feel a stretch across the chest

 Dosing: Hold 30-60 seconds, 3 repetitions per side.

 Posterior capsule (cross-body stretch)

 Pull one arm across your chest with the opposite hand

 Feel the stretch at the back of the shoulder

 Keep the shoulder down — do not let it ride up toward your ear

 Dosing: Hold 30 seconds, 3 repetitions per side.

 Upper trapezius stretch

 Sit upright, hold onto the bottom of your chair with one hand

 Gently tilt your head to the opposite side — ear toward shoulder

 Apply gentle overpressure with the free hand

 Dosing: Hold 30 seconds, 3 repetitions per side.

What is the prognosis for BPPV (Crystal Disease)?

Prognosis

 

 BPPV is a benign condition with very good prognosis. Repositioning maneuvers provide immediate improvement for most.

 Residual Dizziness After Treatment

 31-61% of patients report persistent mild dizziness or unsteadiness after successful treatment, even though nystagmus and positional vertigo are gone. This residual dizziness usually lasts a median of 10 days and typically resolves within 3 months. In some cases, this can develop into PPPD (Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness).

 Recurrence Is Common

 
 Approximately 15-23% experience recurrence within the first year

 5-year recurrence rate is around 40%

 Up to 50% may experience a new episode within 5 years

 

 Prevention of Recurrence

 Vitamin D supplementation in patients with documented deficiency can reduce the risk of new episodes. A meta-analysis showed significant reduction in recurrence rate (relative risk 0.37).

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Horizontal Canal BPPV.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Why is horizontal canal BPPV worse than posterior canal?

 Many patients experience the symptoms as more intense. This may be due to the horizontal canal's larger diameter and stronger response to head movements.

 

 
 Can I do exercises at home?

 Some home exercises can be useful as a supplement, but initial diagnosis and treatment should be performed by qualified healthcare professionals. It is important to know which variant you have.

 The condition itself is not dangerous, but the intense dizziness significantly increases fall risk. It is important to get a correct diagnosis to rule out other causes.

Describe What Is Lumbago? for Sciatica, Disc Herniation or Lumbago?.

What Is Lumbago?

 

 
 Lumbago is what most people have when their back "locks up". The medical term is acute lumbago or non-specific low back pain. The pain comes suddenly, often after an awkward movement, lift or twist - but can also occur seemingly without reason.
 

 
 Characteristics of lumbago:

 
 Localized pain in the lower back

 Pain may radiate diffusely to the buttocks or thighs, but never below the knee

 Stiff back with limited mobility

 Worst in the first few days, then gradual improvement

 No tingling, numbness or muscle weakness

 
 

 
 With lumbago, no specific structural cause is found. MRI or X-ray often shows "normal" age-related changes that don't explain the pain. This is actually good news: it means your body isn't damaged.
 

 
 Most people improve significantly within 6 weeks. Pain scores typically fall from around 56/100 to 26/100 during this period (Pengel et al., BMJ 2003). However, we must be honest: 33-73% experience recurrence within one year, and some develop chronic symptoms.

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 

 Den eksakte Årsaken er ikke fullstendig forstått, men flere faktorer ser ut til å spille inn:

 
 Hovedfaktorer

 
 Genetikk (vanligst): Med 74% arvelighet er genetiske faktorer den dominerende risikofaktoren. Tilstanden går ofte i familier.

 Mekanisk belastning: Teori om traction apophysitis - drag på vekstplatene under rask vekst.

 Vaskulare faktorer: Mulig nedsatt blodtilførsel til deler av virvlene under vekst.

 Biomekaniske forhold: Stram muskulatur i baksiden av lærene (hamstrings) kan forsterke belastningen.

 
 

 
 Viktig å vite

 Scheuermanns sykdom skyldes IKKE dårlig holdning - det er en strukturell tilstand, ikke et resultat av vaner.

Describe Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis) for Shoulder Pain - Complete Guide.

Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis)

 

 Frozen shoulder is a condition where the joint capsule around the shoulder becomes thick, inflamed and tight. This leads to gradually increasing stiffness and pain. The condition goes through three characteristic phases:

 
 Freezing Phase (2-9 months)

 Gradually increasing pain and stiffness. Night pain can be intense.

 

 
 Frozen Phase (4-12 months)

 Pain decreases somewhat, but stiffness is at its worst. Daily activities become difficult.

 

 
 Thawing Phase (6-24 months)

 Movement gradually returns. Full recovery can take 1-3 years.

 

 
 Who gets frozen shoulder?

 Diabetes significantly increases the risk - diabetics have 5 times higher probability of developing frozen shoulder. Other risk factors are thyroid disorders and prolonged inactivity after injury or surgery.

 

 
 Prognosis: Although it takes time, 80% of patients regain good shoulder function with proper follow-up. Early treatment can reduce severity and duration.

You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Identify red flags, provide differential diagnosis and clinical reasoning. Always prioritize patient safety. Classify urgency: URGENT (call ambulance), REFER SAME-DAY, REFER ROUTINE, MONITOR, or SAFE.

Assess red flags: 60-year-old male with known spinal stenosis. Has had bilateral claudication for years. Today reports reduced ability to control bowel movements over past few days. No change in back pain.

URGENCY: URGENT — Call emergency services

RED FLAGS IDENTIFIED: Possible cauda equina syndrome — sphincter involvement in known stenosis.

Clinical reasoning:
- Patient has KNOWN stenosis with longstanding claudication — this is his "baseline"
- NEW sphincter dysfunction (fecal incontinence) = new neurological deterioration
- Fecal incontinence is a LATE sign of CES (more alarming than urinary retention alone)
- That back pain is UNCHANGED is irrelevant — CES can progress without pain worsening
- Known stenosis = anatomical substrate for acute compression

Key lesson: New sphincter dysfunction in patient with known stenosis = CES regardless of pain level.

ACTION: Call emergency services. Urgent MRI. Neurosurgical consultation for decompression.

Explain treatment - how to break the cycle for Medication Overuse Headache.

Treatment - How to Break the Cycle

 The most important treatment for MOH is discontinuation of the overused medications. This can be done abruptly or gradually, depending on which medications are being used.

 Step 1: Recognition and Preparation

 Many do not know they have MOH. The first step is to understand the connection between medication use and headache. Keep a headache diary for 4-8 weeks documenting
 Headache days and intensity

 All medications (type, dose, timing)

 Other factors (sleep, stress, menstruation)

 Step 2: Discontinuation

 Methods for Discontinuation

 Abrupt discontinuation: Recommended for triptans and common painkillers. Safe to do at home with good planning

 Gradual tapering: Recommended for opioids and combination preparations. Should be done under doctor supervision

 Hospitalization: For severe dependence or previous failed attempts

 Expect Rebound Headache

 The first 1-2 weeks after discontinuation, the headache will typically worsen significantly. This is normal and temporary. Other symptoms may include
 Nausea and vomiting

 Sleep difficulties

 Anxiety and restlessness

 Agitation

 These symptoms gradually subside and most notice clear improvement after 6-8 weeks.

 Step 3: Support Treatment During Discontinuation

 Fluids and rest: Drink plenty, rest when necessary

 Limited "rescue" medications: The doctor may prescribe a limited number for the worst days

 Preventive medication: Can be started at the same time as discontinuation

 Non-pharmacological measures: Ice/heat, relaxation, light activity

 Step 4: Relapse Prevention

 Lifestyle Changes to Prevent Relapse

 Headache diary: Continue keeping a diary to catch increased use early

 The 10-day rule: Never use acute painkillers more than 10 days per month

 The 2-3 day rule: Ideally max 2-3 days per week

 Regular sleep and meals 

 Physical activity: Has preventive effect on headache

 Stress management

Beskriv nakkeårsaker (cervikal radikulopati) for Nummenhet i fingrene.

Nakkeårsaker (Cervikal radikulopati)

 Når en nerverot i nakken blir klemt eller irritert, kalles det cervikal radikulopati. Dette kan skyldes diskusprolaps , foraminal stenose (trang nervekanal), eller degenerative forandringer.

 Kjennetegn på nakkeårsak

 Nakkesmerte som ofte forverres ved bevegelse

 Utstraling fra nakken, ned i skulder og arm

 Symptomene følger et dermatom-mønster (se under)

 Kan forverres ved å lene hodet bakover eller mot den syke siden

 Ofte bedre om natten sammenlignet med karpaltunnel

 Dermatomfordeling - Hvilken nerverot er påvirket?

 C5: Nummenhet over skulder og overarm (yttersiden)

 C6: Nummenhet i tommel og pekefinger, yttersiden av underarmen

 C7: Nummenhet i langfinger, ofte med svakhet ved strekking av albue

 C8: Nummenhet i ringfinger og lillefinger (ligner ulnarisnerve)

 Th1: Nummenhet på innsiden av underarmen

 Typisk presentasjon ved C6-radikulopati

 Smerte fra nakken som stråler ned i skulder, overarm og underarm til tommel og pekefinger. Nummenhet i disse fingrene. Kan ha svakhet i biceps og handleddstrekking. Bicepsrefleks kan være svekket.

 Typisk presentasjon ved C7-radikulopati

 Den vanligste cervikale radikulopatien. Smerte og nummenhet i langfinger. Kan ha svakhet ved strekking av albue (triceps). Tricepsrefleks kan være svekket.

Forklar behandling for Kostokondritt og Brystsmerter.

Behandling

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 Manuell behandling for kostokondritt har begrenset, men lovende evidensgrunnlag. Den eneste randomiserte kontrollerte studien på muskuloskeletale brystsmerter (Stochkendahl et al., Danmark, 2012, n=115) sammenlignet kiropraktisk behandling med egenbehandling. Resultatene viste signifikant bedring etter 4 og 12 uker i kiropraktorgruppen. En oppfølgingsstudie (2016) fant at kiropraktisk behandling var kostnadseffektiv.

 Behandlingen retter seg mot hele den biomekaniske kjeden

 Mobilisering av brystryggen - gjenoppretter bevegelighet i T1-T6-området (relatert til T4-syndrom )

 Ribbemobilisering - behandler stivhet i kostovertebrale og kostotransverse ledd

 Bløtvevsbehandling - løsner spenninger i intercostale muskler og brystmuskulatur

 Holdningsveiledning - forebygger tilbakefall, viktig ved krum rygg eller flat rygg 

 En kasusserie (Zaruba & Wilson, International Journal of Sports Physical Therapy, 2017, n=8) på pasienter med kronisk kostokondritt (gjennomsnittlig 6,3 måneders varighet) viste gjennomsnittlig smertereduksjon på 5,1 poeng på en 10-punkts skala etter i snitt 4,8 behandlinger over 3-4 uker.

 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 Unngå aktiviteter som forverrer smerten - gi brusken tid til å roe seg

 Varme kan lindre - varmepute eller varm dusj over det ømme området

 Forsiktig tøyning av brystmuskulaturen, for eksempel i en døråpning

 NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen) kan hjelpe på kort sikt - snakk med lege/apotek

 Pusteøvelser - rolig diafragmatisk pust kan redusere spenning i brystkassen

 Behandlingsforløp

 Basert på tilgjengelig litteratur kan du forvente
 Akutt kostokondritt (<6 uker): De fleste opplever betydelig bedring innen 2-4 behandlinger når brystryggen inkluderes i behandlingen.

 Kronisk kostokondritt (>12 uker): Studien av Zaruba & Wilson (2017) viste at selv langvarige tilfeller (gjennomsnitt 6+ måneder) responderte godt på 4-5 behandlinger over 3-4 uker.

Explain treatment for Headache After Whiplash.

Treatment

 What can the chiropractor do?

 A Cochrane review from 2007 reviewed 23 studies with over 2,300 participants. The main conclusion was
 clear: Early active mobilization is clearly better than rest and neck collar.

 We use gentle techniques adapted to the injury phase
 Mobilization: Soft techniques to restore movement in locked joints. In acute
 whiplash, we avoid forceful manipulation.

 Soft tissue treatment: Treatment of tight muscles that try to "protect" the neck.

 Vestibular rehabilitation: Many become dizzy after whiplash. We provide exercises
 to train balance and coordination between eyes, ears and neck.

 A meta-analysis from 2022 (Bini et al., Chiropractic & Manual Therapies) showed moderate to large
 short-term effects on headache intensity in cervicogenic headache treated with manual therapy.

 What can you do yourself?

 Norwegian health authorities recommend that exercise should start within 4 days after the injury. Neck
 collar is unnecessary in most cases and can actually prolong symptoms if used for more than 48 hours.

 Early movement

 Repeated, gentle neck and head movements provide more relief than rest.

 Deep neck muscles

 Exercises for the deep neck flexors are important. These muscles often "shut off" after whiplash, and
 the larger superficial muscles take over - which can cause more headache.

 Avoid inactivity

 Those who rest and use collar have twice the risk of persistent symptoms as those who move early
 (McKinney et al., 1989).

 Treatment course

 There are no clear guidelines for exact number of treatments for whiplash. A systematic review
 (American Journal of PM&R, 2024) found good results with at least 2 sessions per week for minimum 6
 weeks.

Forklar to tilnærminger til manuell behandling for Kiropraktor vs osteopat: Hva er forskjellen?.

To tilnærminger til manuell behandling

 Kiropraktikk og osteopati oppstod begge i USA på 1800-tallet, men har utviklet seg i ulike retninger. I dag er forskjellene viktigere enn likhetene, spesielt i norsk sammenheng.

 Kiropraktikk

 Grunnlagt av D.D. Palmer i 1895 i Davenport, Iowa. Fokus på ryggsøylen og nervesystemet. Moderne kiropraktikk er en evidensbasert helseprofesjon med spesialkompetanse på muskel-skjelettsystemet. Kiropraktorer har vært autorisert helsepersonell i Norge siden 1988 og er fullt integrert i det offentlige helsevesenet.

 Osteopati

 Grunnlagt av Andrew Taylor Still i 1874 i Missouri, USA. Fokus på kroppens selvhelbredende mekanismer og prinsippet om at struktur styrer funksjon. I USA utviklet osteopater seg til fullverdige leger (DO), men i Europa ble osteopati en egen manuell terapiretning. Osteopater ble autorisert helsepersonell i Norge i 2022.

Beskriv symptomer ved myelopati for Røde flagg ved Nakkesmerter.

Symptomer ved myelopati

 Cervical myelopati har en karakteristisk symptomtriade (AAFP, 2020)
 De tre hovedsymptomene

 Gangforstyrrelser: Det viktigste symptomet. Ustøhet, balanseproblemer, vansker i trapper, uforklarlige fall

 Klossethet i hendene («myelopatihånd»): Vansker med å kneppe knapper, problemer med å skrive, mister ting

 Bilateral nummenhet : Symptomer på begge sider, ofte i både hender og føtter

 Viktig

 Nakkesmerter er overraskende sjeldent det dominerende symptomet ved myelopati. Mange pasienter har lite eller ingen smerter, noe som kan forsinke diagnosen. Rundt 50% feildiagnostiseres initialt som karpaltunnelsyndrom (Kim et al., 2013).

 Kliniske funn

 Ved undersøkelse ser vi etter øvre motorneuron-tegn
 Hoffmanns tegn: Sensitivitet 48-59%, spesifisitet 67-78%

 Babinskis tegn: Lav sensitivitet (13%), men når 100% spesifisitet

 Hyperrefleksi: Økte reflekser i armer og bein

 Klonus: Vedvarende rytmiske muskelsammentrekninger

 Viktig klinisk poeng: Normale funn ved undersøkelsen utelukker ikke myelopati. Testene er spesifikke men ikke sensitive å positive funn gir sterk mistanke, men negative funn gir ikke trygghet.

Behandling i vekstfasen

 

 Behandling under vekst har som mål å bremse eller stoppe progresjon av kurven. Når skjelettet er ferdig utviklet (typisk 16-18 Ør), er mulighetene for å påvirke strukturen betydelig redusert.

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over PIFP: Persistent Idiopatisk Ansiktssmerte.

Definisjon og terminologi: Persistent Idiopatisk Ansiktssmerte (PIFP) defineres av ICHD-3 (International Classification of Headache Disorders) som
ICHD-3 Diagnostiske kriterier: For diagnose må alle følgende kriterier våre oppfylt
Hvem rammes?: PIFP er en relativt sjelden tilstand, men er trolig underdiagnostisert fordi mange pasienter går lange løp hos ulike spesialister for de får riktig diagnose.

Patofysiologi - Hvorfor oppstår PIFP?: Den eksakte mekanismen bak PIFP er ukjent, men flere teorier finnes
Klinisk presentasjon: Mange pasienter har en karakteristisk bakgrunn med smertedebut etter dental prosedyre (ekstraksjon, rotfylling, implantat), ofte multiple tannbehandlinger i forsøk på lindring, gjentatte konsultasjoner uten diagnose, og frustrasjon over å ikke bli trodd.

Differensialdiagnoser: PIFP er en eksklusjonsdiagnose. Følgende må utelukkes
Behandling: Unngå ytterligere invasive prosedyrer! Tannekstraksjoner eller kirurgi gjør ofte situasjonen verre, ikke bedre. Mange PIFP-pasienter har allerede gjennomgått multiple unødvendige inngrep.

Kiropraktorens rolle: PIFP responderer vanligvis ikke godt på manuell behandling alene. Medikamentell behandling er ofte nødvendig, og psykologisk støtte er viktig for mange pasienter.

Prognose: PIFP er ofte en kronisk tilstand, men med riktig behandling kan de fleste oppnå betydelig bedring.

Describe causes and risk factors for Popliteus Syndrome.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Popliteus syndrome usually develops gradually as a result of overuse
 Downhill Running
 Most common
 cause 

 During downhill running, the popliteus must work hard to control knee flexion and prevent
 hyperextension. Trail running and hiking are typical triggers.

 Overload

 Too rapid increase in training volume, intensity, or change in surface can overload the popliteus
 before it has time to adapt.

 Biomechanical Factors

 Overpronation

 Weak hip muscles

 Tight hamstrings or calves

 Poor knee control

Provide a structured clinical overview of Ankle Sprains.

Anatomy and Incidence: The ankle has three main ligaments on the outside
Injury Grading: Ankle sprains are classified into three grades based on severity
Treatment: The POLICE Protocol: In 2012, Bleakley and colleagues published a paradigm shift in acute treatment: The POLICE
 protocol replaces traditional RICE . The main difference is that "rest" is replaced with
 "protection" and "optimal loading".

Rehabilitation: Three Phases: Proprioceptive training reduces the risk of new sprains by 35% according to a
 meta-analysis of 7 studies with 3726 participants. Continue with balance exercises even after the pain
 is gone.

Prognosis: With proper rehabilitation, most ankle sprains have a good prognosis. Approximately 90% of grade
 III injuries achieve good results with conservative treatment. Surgery is reserved for
 persistent instability after 3-6 months of failed conservative treatment.
