Provide a structured clinical overview of Neck Pain.

What Causes Neck Pain?: Between 80 and 90 percent of all neck pain has no specific cause detectable on X-ray or MRI. This doesn't mean the pain is imaginary - it can be very troublesome.

Cervical Radiculopathy - Nerve Root Pain: When a nerve in the neck gets pinched, it can cause radiation down the arm with tingling, numbness or weakness. This affects approximately 0.8-1.8 per 1000 people annually . The good news: 75-90% improve with conservative treatment .

Conditions That Often Accompany Neck Pain: 43% of patients with prolonged neck pain also report dizziness. The neck has a high density of position sensors - when these malfunction due to muscle tightness or joint dysfunction, a sensory conflict occurs creating dizziness.

MRI and Degeneration - "Gray Hair for the Spine": Many become worried when MRI shows "wear and tear" or "degeneration". But such findings are normal in adults and rarely explain your pain.

Treatment of Neck Pain: The combination of manual treatment and exercises has documented effect for neck pain. A 2023 meta-analysis found that manipulative therapy gave better results on pain and function compared to control groups.

Frequently Asked Questions: Most acute episodes resolve within 2-6 weeks. Improvement happens fastest in the first 6-12 weeks.

Need Help With Neck Pain?: At TheBackROM in Majorstua, I have experience with all types of neck pain - from acute torticollis to long-term problems, from nerve root pain to cervicogenic headache.

Describe symptoms of true sciatica for Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know.

Symptoms of True Sciatica

 Classic symptoms include pain from the lower back/buttock, down the back of the thigh, below the knee,
 potentially to the foot and toes. The pain pattern depends on which nerve root is affected
 L4 root

 Pain to the front of the thigh and inner calf

 Weakened knee extension

 L5 root (L4-L5 herniation)

 Pain to the outer calf and top of the foot

 Weakened toe dorsiflexion

 S1 root (L5-S1 herniation)

 Pain to the back of the calf and outer foot

 Weakened toe plantar flexion, reduced Achilles reflex

 Pain quality and provocation

 Pain quality: Sharp, burning, electric. Often described as "current" through the leg.

 Worsening: Coughing, sneezing, straining, sitting, forward bending typically
 increases pain.

 Relief: Lying on your back with bent knees, gentle movement.

Forklar fra hard trening til overtrening — et spektrum for Overtrening og Overbelastning.

Fra hard trening til overtrening — et spektrum

 Ikke all tretthet etter trening er overtrening. Kroppen er laget for å bli sliten, restituere og komme sterkere tilbake. Problemet oppstår når restitusjonen ikke holder tritt med belastningen. Den europeiske og amerikanske idrettsmedisinforeningen (ECSS/ACSM) deler overtrening inn i tre nivåer (Meeusen et al., 2013)
 1. Funksjonell overreaching (FOR)

 Kortvarig prestasjonsfall etter en hard treningsperiode. Kroppen restituerer på dager til uker, og du kommer tilbake sterkere. Dette er planlagt og ønskelig — det er slik superkompensasjon fungerer. De fleste utøvere har opplevd dette uten å vite at det har et navn.

 2. Ikke-funksjonell overreaching (NFOR)

 Prestasjonen faller, og kroppen trenger uker til måneder for å hente seg inn. Du merker at noe er galt — søvnen er dårlig, motivasjonen synker, og du føler deg konstant sliten. NFOR er grensen der overbelastning går fra ubehagelig til problematisk. Restitusjon krever typisk 3–8 uker med betydelig treningsreduksjon.

 3. Overtreningssyndrom (OTS)

 Full stopp. Kroppen er i ubalanse over tid. Prestasjonen faller drastisk, og det tar måneder — noen ganger lengre — å komme tilbake. OTS er en eksklusjonsdiagnose : andre årsaker til symptomene må utelukkes først (Meeusen et al., 2013). Full restitusjon kan ta 3–12 måneder, og noen utøvere blir aldri helt de samme.

 Skillet mellom nivåene er glidende. Du vet sjelden hvor du befinner deg før i ettertid. Det er nettopp derfor forebygging er viktigere enn behandling.

What causes Thoracic Back Pain – Causes, Symptoms and Treatment?

4 Less Common Causes

 Some conditions are rarer but important to be aware of:

 
 Scheuermann's Disease

 A developmental disorder causing increased kyphosis (rounding) in the thoracic spine, usually discovered in adolescence.

 
 Abnormal rounding of the upper back

 Stiffness and aching pain

 Wedged vertebrae visible on X-ray

 Can be treated conservatively in most cases

 
 

 
 Thoracic Disc Herniation

 Rarer than in the neck and lower back, but can occur. Accounts for only 1-2% of all disc herniations.

 
 Often asymptomatic even when found on MRI

 Can cause radiation around the ribs

 Rarely requires surgery

 
 

 
 Ankylosing Spondylitis

 Rheumatic disease causing inflammation and gradual stiffening of the spine.

 
 Morning stiffness over 30 minutes

 Improves with activity

 Often onset before age 40

 Requires referral to rheumatologist

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Overpronasjon: Myte eller medisinsk faktum?.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Er all pronasjon normalt?

 Ja, pronasjon er en helt naturlig bevegelse. Foten er designet for å pronere ved landing - det er kroppens innebygde støtdemping. Problemet oppstar når normal variasjon blir patologisert som overpronasjon. Det finnes ingen vitenskapelig definert grense for hva som er for mye pronasjon.

 

 
 Trenger barn med plattfot innleggssaler?

 Nei, i de aller fleste tilfeller. Helsebiblioteket (2022) konkluderer at det ikke finnes evidensgrunnlag for innleggssaler hos barn med plattfot. Fleksibel plattfot hos barn er en normalvariant som vanligvis utvikler seg normalt. Unødvendig behandling kan faktisk hindre naturlig fotutvikling.

 

 
 Hvorfor forskriver behandlere fortsatt for overpronasjon?

 Flere faktØrer spiller inn: tradisjon fra utdanning, Økonomiske insentiver (ortosemarkedet er verdt milliarder), visuell logikk (det ser feil ut), og manglende oppdatering på nyere forskning. Mange behandlere er genuint overbevist fordi de lærte dette som etablert vitenskap.

 

 
 Bør jeg slutte med bevegelseskontrollskoene mine?

 Hvis de er komfortable og du ikke har problemer, er det ingen grunn til å bytte umiddelbart. Men hvis du vurderer nye sko, tyder forskningen på at komfort er en bedre guide enn pronasjonsmåling. Gradvis overgang til mer nøytrale sko kan våre aktuelt for mange.

 

 
 Kan kiropraktor hjelpe med fotproblemer?

 Ja. Kiropraktorer vurderer hele bevegelsesapparatet og kan identifisere om fotplagene skyldes lokal...

Diagnostikk

 Kliniske spørsmål som kan avslore SCDS

 Ved mistanke om SCDS kan folgende spørsmål vare avslorende
 "Kan du hore oynene dine bevege seg?"

 "Blir du svimmel når du presser eller har avforing?"

 "Gir nesepussing deg følelse av å snurre rundt?"

 "HØrer du din egen stemme unormalt høyt i ett øre?"

 Diagnostiske kriterier (Barany Society, 2021)

 For diagnosen SCDS kreves alle tre folgende
 A. Minst ett karakteristisk symptom

 Benledningsoverfølsomhet (autofoni for indre kroppslyder), lydinduert svimmelhet/oscillopsi, trykkutlost svimmelhet/oscillopsi, eller pulserende tinnitus.

 B. Minst ett fysiologisk funn

 Nystagmus i den øvre buegangens plan utlost av lyd eller trykk, negative benledningsskriftsverdier på audiometri i lave frekvenser, eller førsterkede VEMP-responser.

 C. Hoyopploselig CT

 Som viser dehiscens med =0,5-0,63 mm snitttykkelse og reformaterte bilder i Poschl- og Stenvers-plan.

 Røde flagg - når du bør kontakte ONH-spesialist

 Svimmelhet utlost av høye lyder

 Du hører egne øyebevegelser, fottrinn eller hjerteslag unormalt tydelig

 Svimmelhet ved pressing, hosting eller nesepussing

 Pulserende øresus kombinert med balanseproblemer

 Hørselstap med bevarte akustiske reflekser

 Posisjonsutlost svimmelhet som ikke responderer på Epley-manover

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 Should I stretch my hamstrings?

 NO - this is a common mistake. Stretching compresses the tendon against the sit
 bone and often makes things worse. Focus on strength training instead. Gentle dynamic mobility is fine,
 but avoid prolonged static stretching.

 

 
 Can I continue running?

 Often you need to significantly reduce volume initially. Flat running at low
 intensity is tolerated better than hills and intervals. Build up gradually as pain subsides. Running
 should not cause more than 3/10 pain.

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 PHT is often long-lasting. Expect 3-6 months of proper treatment for significant
 improvement. Some need up to 12 months. Early diagnosis and treatment give better prognosis. Patience is
 key.

 

 
 Does cortisone help?

 Cortisone injection can provide short-term pain relief, but is not first choice.
 Research shows it does not improve long-term outcomes and can weaken tendon tissue. Strength training is
 more effective for lasting improvement.

 

 
 How should I sit?

 Avoid hard chairs. Use a seat cushion that relieves the sit bone - either a
 wedge-shaped cushion or one with a cutout at the back. Get up and move regularly. Consider a standing
 desk for periods.

Beskriv symptomer ved cad for Røde flagg ved Nakkesmerter.

Symptomer ved CAD

 Det vanligste symptomet er hodepine og/eller nakkesmerte (65-95% av pasientene). Men CAD-relatert smerte har kjennetegn som skiller den fra vanlige muskelplager
 Varseltegn ved CAD

 Plutselig debut: Smerten kommer bratt, ofte over minutter

 Ensidig: 74% har smerte på samme side som disseksjonen (Thomas et al., 2023)

 «Annerledes enn alt annet»: 75% beskriver smerten som ulik tidligere hodepine (Mayer-Suess et al., 2022)

 Responderer ikke på behandling: Smerten letter ikke med bevegelse, stilling eller smertestillende

 Kan ikke gjenskapes: Undersøkelse av nakken provoserer ikke smerten

 Nevrologiske tegn ved CAD

 Horners syndrom (25-44%): Trang pupille og hengende øyelokk på en side

 Hjernenerveutfall (12%): Tungeavvik, heshet, svelgevansker

 Pulserende øresus (8-10%): Rytmisk lyd i året synkront med pulsen

 Det kritiske tidsvinduet

 Data fra Biousse et al. (Stroke 1995) viste at 82% av hjerneslag skjer innen 7 dager etter at symptomene startet. Dette betyr at tidlig gjenkjennelse kan forhindre hjerneslag.

Describe What Are Trigger Points? for Trigger Points in Hip and Pelvis.

What Are Trigger Points?

 

 Trigger points are localized, hyperirritable spots within taut bands of skeletal
 muscle. They are characterized by local tenderness and can produce referred pain in predictable patterns
 when compressed.

 In the hip and pelvic region, trigger points can cause pain that mimics other conditions such as piriformis syndrome, sciatica, hip osteoarthritis, or GTPS. This makes accurate diagnosis important.

Explain treatment for Cervical Foraminal Stenosis.

Treatment

 Most people with cervical foraminal stenosis respond well to conservative treatment. Studies show that
 75-90% achieve good symptom control without surgery.

 Chiropractic treatment may include
 Manual mobilization: Gentle mobilization of neck joints to improve mobility

 Manual traction: "Stretching" of the neck that opens the foramen and provides
 nerve relief

 Soft tissue treatment: Treatment of tight muscles around neck and shoulder

 Nerve mobilization: Gentle techniques to improve nerve gliding

 Posture correction: Advice on ergonomics and positional changes

 Exercises That Often Help

 Cervical Retractions (Chin Tuck)

 Pull your chin straight back as if making a "double chin." Hold for 5 seconds. This exercise
 centralizes neck discs and can open the foramen.

 Side Bend Away from Painful Side

 Gently bend your head toward the shoulder on the pain-free side. This opens the foramen on the
 painful side and can provide immediate relief.

 Prognosis

 With proper treatment and exercises, most achieve
 significant improvement within 6-12 weeks. Some experience periods of worsening, but the long-term
 prognosis is generally good with conservative treatment.

Describe symptoms for Trigger Points in the Neck.

Symptoms

 Trigger points in the neck produce a characteristic symptom pattern
 Local Tenderness

 A distinct point that is very tender to pressure.

 Referred Pain

 Pain radiates in a predictable pattern. Upper trapezius often causes pain toward the back of the head
 and temple. Sternocleidomastoid can cause pain around the eye and forehead.

 Stiffness and Reduced Mobility

 Difficulty turning the head or looking up.

 Headache 

 80% of patients with chronic tension headache have active trigger points in the upper trapezius
 (Alonso-Blanco 2011).

 "Stiff Neck" Sensation

 Typical with trigger points in levator scapulae, with pain at the angle between neck and shoulder.

Explain prognosis for Trigger Points in the Neck.

Prognosis

 Most people with trigger points in the neck experience good improvement with treatment and self-exercise.
 Short-term treatment effects are well documented in research.

 Recurrence is common

 Without addressing underlying factors like ergonomics, stress, inactivity and potential nutritional
 deficiencies, trigger points often return. This is why we place great emphasis on self-exercise and
 lifestyle factors.

 At 6-12 months, long-term results are often similar regardless of which specific treatment method was
 used. What appears most important for lasting improvement is the combination of treatment, exercises and
 adjustment of activity and ergonomics.

 How to recognize trigger points in arm and forearm:

Describe causes and risk factors for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: Complete Guide.

Causes and risk factors

 Carpal tunnel syndrome occurs when pressure in the tunnel becomes too high. This can be caused by
 Swelling of the tendons (most common)

 Repetitive strain or overuse can cause swelling in the tendon sheaths passing through the tunnel,
 reducing space for the nerve.

 Hormonal factors

 Pregnancy, menopause, hypothyroidism and diabetes increase risk through fluid retention and tissue
 swelling.

 Anatomical factors

 Some people naturally have narrower carpal tunnels. Previous wrist fractures can also narrow the
 tunnel.

 Repetitive work

 Office work, cashier work, production work - anything with repeated hand movements over time. See also
 mouse arm .

 Important risk factors

 Gender: Women are affected 3 times more often than men

 Pregnancy: Common in the last trimester (fluid retention)

 Diabetes: Increased risk of nerve disease in general

 Obesity: BMI over 30 significantly increases risk

 Arthritis: Inflammation can affect the tendon sheaths

 Hereditary: Tends to run in families

Tidligere skade

 

 En AC-leddsforskyvning (AC-ledd separasjon) eller kragebeinbrudd Øker risikoen for senere artrose i leddet.

 

 Vektløfterskulder (Distal clavicular osteolysis)

 
 Spesiell tilstand hos styrketrenende

 Vektløfterskulder er en tilstand der enden av kragebenet brytes ned på grunn av repeterende mikrotraumer. Vanlig hos de som trener tungt benkpress, skulderpress og dips.

 
 Smerte på toppen av skulderen

 93% blir bedre med aktivitetsmodifisering

 
 

 Risikofaktorer

 
 Alder over 40 Ør

 Tungt fysisk arbeid eller styrketrening

 Tidligere AC-leddskade

 Overhead-idretter

 Tidligere brudd i kragebein eller skulder

 
 

 
 
 
 3
 Symptomer

 

 Symptomene ved AC-ledd-artrose er ofte karakteristiske og lokalisert:

 Typiske symptomer

 
 Lokalisert smerte: Pa toppen av skulderen, ofte pekbar

 Provokasjon ved kroppsbevegelser: Ta handen over til motsatt skulder (cross-body)

 Smerte ved overhead: Særlig i enden av bevegelsen

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Svake fåtter: RotÅrsaken de fleste overser.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hvor lang tid tar det å styrke fåttene?

 Merkbare forbedringer ses typisk etter 4-8 uker med konsekvent trening. Liverpool-studien viste 57% styrkeØkning etter 6 måneder med minimalistsko. Fottrening bør ses som vedlikehold - akkurat som annen trening.

 

 
 Er barfotgåing trygt?

 For de fleste er gradvis barfotgåing trygt og gunstig. Start innendØrs på myke underlag, og Øk gradvis. Personer med diabetes, nevropati eller nedsatt følelse i fåttene bør våre forsiktige og konsultere helsepersonell først.

 

 
 Kan jeg trene fåttene selv om jeg har plattfot?

 Ja, absolutt. Forskning (Huang 2022 meta-analyse) viser at fottrening kan Øke buestyrken og forbedre funksjon selv hos personer med flate fåtter. Fleksibel plattfot responderer ofte godt på styrketrening.

 

 
 Bør jeg kaste innleggssålene mine?

 Ikke nødvendigvis. Hvis du har diabetes, alvorlige deformiteter eller spesifikke medisinske indikasjoner, kan ortoser fortsatt våre viktige. For uspesifikke plager kan gradvis nedtrapping kombinert med fottrening våre et godt alternativ. Diskuter med en fagperson.

 

 
 Kan kiropraktor hjelpe med svake fåtter?

 Ja. Kiropraktorer vurderer hele bevegelsesapparatet og kan identifisere om fotplagene skyldes lokale forhold eller kompensasjoner fra hofter, bekken eller rygg. Behandlingen inkluderer ofte leddmobilisering, bløtvevsarbeid og veiledning i målrettet fottrening.

Lovende resultater fra kasuistikker

 
 En 33 Ør gammel mann med Straight Back Syndrome oppnådde 10 graders bedring over 36 behandlinger (PMC, 2017)

You are a clinical documentation assistant for chiropractors. Generate professional medical documentation.
Describe treatment options for Meralgia Paresthetica.

Treatment

 

 Conservative treatment (first choice)

 85% recover with simple measures targeting the triggering cause.

 
 First measures:

 
 Avoid tight pants and belts

 Weight loss if overweight

 Avoid prolonged standing

 Remove heavy tool belts

 Adjust car seat and seat belt

 
 

 For persistent symptoms

 
 Nerve mobilization - gentle exercises to "free" the nerve

 Soft tissue treatment - around the inguinal ligament and hip flexors

 Hip flexor stretching - reduces tension on the nerve

 Medications - painkillers or neuropathic agents

 

 During pregnancy

 Meralgia paresthetica in pregnancy often resolves after delivery. Measures:

 
 Avoid standing too long

 Use support belt high (not on the hip bone)

 Rest with slightly bent hips

 Symptoms usually disappear after delivery

 

 Injection treatment

 For persistent symptoms, injection with local anesthetic and cortisone can provide relief. This can be
 both diagnostic and therapeutic.

 Surgery

 Considered only when conservative treatment over several months has not helped. Options:

 
 Neurolysis - freeing the nerve from surrounding tissue

 Neurectomy - cutting the nerve (results in permanent numbness)

Forklar Hodepine og svimmelhet for en pasient.

Hodepine og svimmelhet er hver for seg blant de vanligste plagene folk oppsøker helsevesenet for. Når de opptrer samtidig, handler det sjelden om tilfeldigheter.

 En studie fra 2010 viste at 51,1% av personer med residiverende cefalalgi også rapporterer vertigo som ledsagersymptom (Lempert & Neuhauser 2009). Kombinasjonen forekommer tre ganger oftere enn man skulle forvente hvis tilstandene var uavhengige av hverandre.

 Problemet er at kombinasjonen har mange mulige årsaker - fra helt ufarlige muskulære spenninger som ved spenningshodepine til alvorlig patologi som krever øyeblikkelig hjelp. Derfor er grundig utredning avgjørende.

Hva forårsaker Svimmelhet - Komplett guide?

Årsaker til svimmelhet - fra vanligst til sjeldnest

 

 Her er de viktigste Årsakene, sortert etter hvor ofte de forekommer:

 
 
 Krystallsyke (BPPV)

 17-42% av tilfellene
 

 Gå til full artikkel om krystallsyke (BPPV) →

 Krystallsyke er den vanligste Årsaken til svimmelhet som utredes i klinikker (Bosner, BMC Fam Pract, 2018). Tilstanden oppstar når små kalsiumkrystaller løsner fra sin plass i balanseorganet og havner i buegangene.

 Kjennetegn:

 
 Korte, intense spinnanfall (10-60 sekunder)

 Utløses av bestemte hodebevegelser - snu seg i sengen, se opp, bøye seg ned

 Kvalme under anfallene

 Symptomfri mellom anfallene

 
 

 
 
 Vestibular migrene

 ca. 1-3% av befolkningen
 

 Gå til full artikkel om vestibular migrene →

 Livstidsprevalens på rundt 1%, men nyere amerikanske data antyder opptil 2,7% (Formeister, Otol Neurotol, 2018). Barany Society har identifisert dette som "den desidert vanligste Årsaken" til kombinerte nakkesmerter og Vestibulære symptomer. Kan forekomme med eller uten hodepine.

 

 
 
 Vestibularisnevritt

 3-10% i svimmelhetsklinikker
 

 Gå til full artikkel om vestibularisnevritt →

 Årlig insidens på 3,5-7 per 100 000 (Iwasaki, Auris Nasus Larynx, 2024). Utgjør 3-10% av diagnosene i spesialiserte svimmelhetsklinikker. Viral betennelse av balansenerven som gir plutselig, intens svimmelhet over flere dager. Hørselen påvirkes ikke. 10-15% utvikler BPPV etterpå.

 

 
 
 Ortostatisk hypotensjon

Describe Why Is This So Difficult? for Back, Hip or Sciatica?.

Why Is This So Difficult?

 

 
 
 44%
 of hip patients are initially given the wrong
 diagnosis
 

 

 Back, hip and sciatica share overlapping symptoms and pain patterns. Leg pain can come
 from the hip joint, from the back via the nerves, or from both places simultaneously.
 Research shows that almost half of all patients with hip problems are first given a
 wrong diagnosis - often treated for back problems they don't have.

 This article helps you understand the most important differences and why a thorough
 examination is so important.

Differential diagnoses for Morning Headache?

Sleep apnea

 Very common cause 

 Obstructive sleep apnea causes repeated breathing stops at night. This leads to oxygen deficiency and carbon dioxide buildup that dilates blood vessels in the brain.

 Typical: Pressing, bilateral headache upon awakening

 Usually improves within 30-60 minutes

 Often accompanied by snoring, daytime fatigue, dry mouth

 Treatment of sleep apnea (e.g., CPAP) often eliminates the headache

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

 Grinding or clenching teeth at night strains jaw muscles and can cause headache upon awakening.

 Often tension headache character (pressing, bilateral)

 Pain in jaw, temple and/or chewing muscles

 Dentist can see wear on teeth

 Bite guards and muscle relaxation can help

Poor sleep position and pillow

 Wrong position at night can cause muscle tension in neck and head.

 Especially stomach sleeping with head turned to the side

 Pillow too high or too low

 Neck in unnatural position all night

 Often gives cervicogenic headache or tension headache character

Medication overuse headache (MOH)

 Regular use of painkillers can paradoxically cause daily headache - often most pronounced in the morning.

 Headache present upon awakening most days

 Temporarily improves with painkillers, but returns

 See separate article on medication overuse headache

Migraine and tension headache

 Primary headache disorders can start at night or early morning.

Provide a structured clinical overview of Chronic Dizziness and PPPD.

What is PPPD?: PPPD stands for Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness. The condition was formally defined by the Barany Society in 2017 and is now included in the WHO's International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11 code AB32.0).

The Five Diagnostic Criteria (Barany Society, 2017): Dizziness, unsteadiness or non-rotational vertigo present most days for at least three months

Why the Brain "Forgets" to Turn Off the Alarm: Imagine a burglar alarm in your house. After an actual break-in (an acute dizziness episode), you adjust the sensitivity to maximum. Suddenly the alarm goes off every time the wind blows. This is how PPPD works.

Symptoms and Characteristics: 60% of PPPD patients have clinically significant anxiety and 45% have depression, but 25% have no psychiatric condition at all. This underscores that PPPD is a neurological condition - not "just anxiety." Similar mental health challenges are also seen in other chronic dizziness conditions like Meniere's disease and MdDS .

Treatment: Treatment rests on three pillars. Recent research shows that the combination gives the good results.

Prognosis: Studies show that 60-80% of patients with PPPD experience significant symptom reduction with proper treatment. Complete symptom freedom is not always achieved, but functional improvement - where dizziness no longer controls your life - is realistic for most.

 Hodepine fra muskulære årsaker diagnostiseres primært gjennom klinisk undersøkelse . Bildediagnostikk som MR eller CT er sjelden nødvendig ved typisk spenningshodepine og gir ofte funn som slitasje eller degenerasjon som ikke forklarer plagene.

 Holdningsvurdering inkludert fremoverlent hodefremskutt

 Nevrologisk screening for å utelukke alvorlige årsaker

 Kraniovertebral bevegelighet og nakkeleddsfunksjon

 ICHD-3 klassifisering av spenningshodepine
 Sjelden episodisk: Mindre enn 1 dag/måned

 Hyppig episodisk: 1-14 dager/måned

 Kronisk: 15 dager eller mer/måned i over 3 måneder

Explain treatment for Calcific Tendinitis: Everything You Need to Know.

Treatment

 Treatment of calcific tendinitis depends on symptom intensity and phase. Because the condition is
 self-limiting, the goal is to relieve symptoms while the body takes care of the calcium itself.

 Conservative treatment (first choice)

 What can the chiropractor/physiotherapist do?

 Manual therapy: Mobilization of shoulder and thoracic spine

 Soft tissue treatment: Work on tight muscles around the shoulder

 Exercise guidance: Tailored exercises to maintain mobility and strength

 Ergonomic advice: Adaptation of work tasks during acute phase. See ergonomics and shoulder problems 

 Shockwave Therapy (ESWT)

 ESWT (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Therapy) has Level I evidence for treating calcific
 tendinitis. Shock waves are sent toward the calcium deposit to stimulate resorption and relieve pain.

 The KALK Study (BMJ 2023)

 A Norwegian study (the KALK study) compared ESWT with placebo. Interestingly, the study showed no
 significant difference between groups at 4 and 12 months. This may be because patients with shorter
 symptom duration were included - where the condition might have resolved anyway.

 Other studies with longer symptom duration have shown better effect of ESWT. The treatment may be
 most useful for patients with long-term symptoms that show no signs of spontaneous improvement.

 Other treatment options

 Ultrasound-guided barbotage (needling)

 A needle is inserted into the calcium deposit under ultrasound guidance. Calcium slurry is aspirated
 and flushed out. Can be effective, especially in the resorptive phase when the calcium is soft and
 liquid.

 Cortisone injection 

 Can provide good short-term pain relief, especially in the acute phase. Does not affect the calcium
 deposit itself, but reduces the inflammation around it.

 Medications

 NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, diclofenac) can help with pain and inflammation in the acute phase. For
 severe pain, short-term use of stronger painkillers may be necessary.

Describe treatment options for BPPV (Crystal Disease).

Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Treatment consists of specific repositioning maneuvers that move the loose crystals out of the semicircular canal and back to the utricle where they belong.

 
 Epley Maneuver

 The most used and studied treatment for posterior canal BPPV. A meta-analysis showed symptom relief in 74-75% of patients after one treatment - over six times better than the control group. With repeated treatments, over 90% achieve improvement.

 

 Other Maneuvers

 
 Semont Maneuver: Alternative to Epley, especially useful for cupulolithiasis

 Gufoni Maneuver and Barbecue Roll: Used for horizontal canal BPPV

 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 Once the diagnosis is confirmed and you have learned the correct technique, you can perform repositioning maneuvers at home during new episodes. Other measures that can help include vitamin D supplements if blood tests show deficiency, avoiding rapid head movements in the acute phase, and continuing normal activities as soon as possible.

 Treatment Course

 Most patients need 1-3 treatments. Median duration of symptoms is 2 weeks. Early treatment often leads to faster improvement.

Patient asks: "Can temple headache come from the teeth?"

Yes, trigger points in the temporalis muscle can refer pain to the teeth, especially the upper front teeth and molars. This can be confused with dental problems. At the same time, dental problems like teeth grinding (bruxism) can strain the temporalis and contribute to headache.

Patient asks: "Do I need an X-ray?"

Not necessarily for adults with typical injury mechanism and uncomplicated course. All adolescents should get X-rays to rule out avulsion fractures. Adults should get X-rays if symptoms persist >2 weeks or if fracture is suspected.

Vurder røde flagg for Røde flagg ved Ryggsmerter.

Cauda equina-syndrom - akutt nådsituasjon

 

 Cauda equina-syndrom (CES) oppstar når nervebunten nederst i ryggraden blir klemt, vanligvis av en stor skiveprolaps. Tilstanden rammer omtrent 1,6 per 100 000 per Ør - sjelden, men svært alvorlig.

 
 
 1,6
 per 100 000 per Ør
 

 
 48t
 kritisk tidsvindu
 

 
 84%
 har blåresymptomer
 

 

 Symptomer å våre oppmerksom på

 
 Cauda equina-symptomer

 
 Blærefunksjonsforstyrrelser (84%): Vansker med å starte vannlating, svak stråle, følelse av at blåren ikke tØmmes, eller urinlekkasje

 Ridebukseanestesi (71%): Nummenhet eller endret følelse rundt endetarm, kjénnsorganer og innside av lærene

 Avforingsforstyrrelser (62%): Endret kontroll over tarmfunksjon

 Bilateral beinsvakhet: Svakhet i begge bena som utvikler seg raskt

 
 

 
 Hvorfor haster det?

 Forverring kan skje med omtrent 1% per time. Forsinkelse over 48 timer var forbundet med 9,6 ganger Økt dødelighet. Det finnes ingen "trygg" ventetid.

Explain treatment: the police protocol for Ankle Sprains.

Treatment: The POLICE Protocol

 In 2012, Bleakley and colleagues published a paradigm shift in acute treatment: The POLICE
 protocol replaces traditional RICE . The main difference is that "rest" is replaced with
 "protection" and "optimal loading".

 A randomized study from 2023 showed that POLICE provides faster and better functional recovery than
 PRICE.

 The POLICE Protocol

 P 
 
 Protection

 Use elastic bandage or aircast for support

 OL 
 
 Optimal Loading

 Gentle movement within pain limits from day 1

 I 
 
 Ice

 15-20 minutes with ice pack in towel, 3-4 times daily

 C 
 
 Compression

 Elastic bandage (not too tight)

 E 
 
 Elevation

 Keep the foot higher than heart level when resting

 What can the chiropractor do?

 Manual therapy and joint mobilization have moderate evidence for ankle sprains.
 Systematic reviews show improved dorsiflexion and reduced pain perception.

 Assess the severity of the injury

 Rule out fractures using Ottawa Ankle Rules

 Provide manual treatment to improve mobility

 Guide through a tailored rehabilitation program

Hvordan diagnostiseres Horisontal Kanal BPPV?

Diagnostikk

 

 Supine roll-test (gullstandarden)

 Pasienten ligger på ryggen med hodet hevet 30 grader. Hodet dreies raskt 90 grader til en side og holdes i 30-60 sekunder mens Øyebevegelser observeres. Deretter gjentas testen til motsatt side. Testens sensitivitet er rapportert til 89,5% (Barany Society Guidelines).

 
 Ved geotropisk variant

 Øynene slær mot bakken på begge sider, men sterkest på den affiserte siden.

 

 
 Ved apogeotropisk variant

 Øynene slær bort fra bakken, og den svakeste responsen er på den affiserte siden.

 

 
 Viktig rekkefølge

 Supine roll-testen bør ideelt utføres får Dix-Hallpike-testen, da Dix-Hallpike kan flytte krystaller og påvirke resultatene.

 

 
 Røde flagg - kontakt lege umiddelbart ved:

 
 Svimmelhet som varer kontinuerlig over 2 minutter (BPPV gir korte anfall)

 Plutselig hØrselstap eller kraftig Øresus

 Dobbeltsyn eller andre synsforstyrrelser

 Kraftig hodepine ulikt tidligere opplevd

 Ansiktslammelse, nummenhet eller taleforstyrrelser

 Koordinasjonsproblemer eller ustå gange

Describe causes and triggering factors for POTS and Orthostatic Dizziness.

Causes and Triggering Factors

 POTS has no single cause, but is often triggered by an "immunological stressor." The most common triggering factors are
 Viral Infection (most common)

 About 50% of POTS cases start after a viral infection - especially mononucleosis (glandular fever), influenza and COVID-19. Among patients with long COVID, 2-14% report POTS symptoms.

 Physical Trauma

 Whiplash injuries , concussion and other trauma to head and neck are known triggers. There is a documented connection between neck injuries and POTS development.

 Associated Conditions

 POTS often occurs together with other conditions: Hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (25% of POTS patients), mast cell activation syndrome (MCAS), migraine (40%), irritable bowel (30%), and ME/CFS (21%).
You are a medical safety advisor for chiropractic. Provide differential diagnosis based on symptoms and clinical findings. Always prioritize patient safety.
Describe symptoms for Persistent Symptoms After Concussion.

Symptoms

 Physical Symptoms (Most Common)

 Headache: 78%

 Often located in the back of the head, worsens with bending or exertion.

 Fatigue: 91%

 Mental tiredness after just 20-30 minutes of concentrated work.

 Dizziness: 50-84%

 Both spinning dizziness and feeling of unsteadiness.

 Sleep Problems: 70%

 Difficulty falling asleep and poor sleep quality.

 Cognitive Symptoms

 Concentration difficulties: about 64%

 Reduced memory: 73%

 Delayed mental processing: Feeling of "thinking through cotton"

 Sensory Symptoms

 Light sensitivity: 55% - computer screens and bright lights are especially problematic

 Sound sensitivity: 40% - background noise that previously went unnoticed becomes bothersome

 Blurred vision: 30% - difficulty focusing, especially when reading

 Vestibular Symptoms

 The vestibular system - meaning the balance system in the inner ear and its connections to the brain - is particularly vulnerable to head injuries. Pressure waves from the impact can damage the delicate structures in the inner ear.

 Dizziness that worsens with head movements

 Difficulty focusing vision during movement

 Balance difficulties especially on uneven surfaces or in darkness

 Increased sensitivity to visual stimulation like escalators or busy environments

Provide a structured clinical overview of Minimalist Shoes and Barefoot Training: What Does the Research Say?.

What Are Minimalist Shoes?: Minimalist shoes are designed to mimic barefoot walking as much as possible while providing basic protection. They are characterized by several key features
What Does the Research Say?: The most comprehensive study on minimalist shoes and foot strength was published in Scientific Reports (Nature) in 2021. Researchers followed participants who transitioned to minimalist shoes for everyday use
Why Do Minimalist Shoes Strengthen the Feet?: There are four main mechanisms that explain why minimalist shoes result in stronger feet
Benefits of Barefoot Walking and Minimalist Shoes: The study published in Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise showed that minimalist shoe use led to significant strength increases in the foot's intrinsic muscles, measured with MRI.

Risks of Too Rapid Transition: The greatest danger with minimalist shoes is not the shoes themselves, but too rapid transition . Feet that have been "protected" in cushioned shoes for decades have weak muscles and are not prepared for the increased load.

Safe Transition Protocol: Never increase minimalist shoe use by more than 10% per week. If you run 10 minutes in week 1, increase to maximum 11 minutes in week 2.

Who Should Be Careful?: Although minimalist shoes can be beneficial for most people, some groups should be extra careful or avoid them altogether
Combination: Minimalist Shoes + Foot Training: The well-documented approach combines minimalist shoes with targeted foot training
Red Flags - When to Stop: These symptoms may indicate stress fractures, tendon injuries, or other conditions requiring professional assessment. Do not "train through" pain - it only prolongs healing time.

Provide a structured clinical overview of IT Band Syndrome.

What is IT Band Syndrome?: IT band syndrome (ITBS) occurs when the iliotibial band becomes irritated where it crosses the lateral
 femoral condyle (bony prominence on the outside of the knee). This happens repeatedly with every step
 during running.

Causes - The Hip Connection: Research has clearly shown that hip weakness is a major factor in IT band syndrome
Symptoms: A hallmark of IT band syndrome is that pain appears at almost exactly the same distance in each run.
 This "threshold" distance increases as treatment progresses.

Treatment: Modern treatment focuses on hip strengthening rather than just stretching
Return to Running: Weeks 1-2: Rest from running, hip strengthening daily

Forklar prognose for Hodepine i bakhodet.

Prognose

 De fleste med hodepine i bakhodet har en god prognose. Spenningshodepine og cervikogen hodepine responderer ofte bra på behandling, særlig når pasientene også gjør egentiltak.

 Realistiske forventninger
 50-70% med cervikogen hodepine opplever klinisk meningsfull bedring ved behandling

 Korttidseffekter er ofte storre enn langtidseffekter

 Tilbakefall er vanlig - vedlikeholdsstrategier er viktige

 Kombinasjon av behandling og egentiltak gir best resultat

 Ved kronisk hodepine (over 12 ukers varighet) kan det ta lengre tid å oppna bedring. Tidlig behandling gir ofte raskere bedring - det er ingen grunn til å "vente og se" ved nye hodepineplager.

 Metatarsalgia (Forefoot Pain)

 5-36% prevalence
 

 Go to full article on metatarsalgia

 Collective term for pain in the forefoot. Accounts for 85% of all foot pain in middle-aged women.

 19% prevalence
 

 Go to full article on hallux valgus

 The big toe angles towards the other toes, and the joint protrudes on the inside. Affects approx.
 19% of the population, increasing to 36% over 65 years. Women are affected 2-3 times more often.

 Treatment: Conservative treatment focuses on pain relief: shoes with wide toe box, toe
 spreaders, strength exercises for foot muscles. Surgery is only considered with significant pain and
 functional impairment.

 

 
 
 Morton's Neuroma

 5-8x women

 Thickening of the interdigital nerve, typically between 3rd and 4th toe. Women are affected 5-8
 times more often. Accounts for approx. 40% of metatarsalgia diagnoses.

 Treatment: Stepwise: first conservative (wide toe box, metatarsal pads) for 3-6
 months. Cortisone injections if conservative treatment doesn't help (82% satisfied). Surgery as last resort.

Patient asks: "Can rib dislocation cause pain that feels like heart problems?"

Yes, the costovertebral joints can cause pain that radiates to the front of the
 chest and can resemble heart pain. This resembles the symptoms of costochondritis . A study from the Copenhagen Heart Study showed that
 18% of patients with suspected heart disease had musculoskeletal pain as the cause. With chest pain,
 heart problems should always be considered first.

Describe How to Distinguish Between the Conditions for Numbness in Fingers: Is It the Neck or the Hand?.

How to Distinguish Between the Conditions

 

 
 Points toward carpal tunnel:

 
 Do you wake up at night with numbness in your fingers?

 Does shaking your hand help?

 Do symptoms worsen with repetitive hand work?

 Is the little finger completely free of symptoms?

 
 

 
 Points toward the neck:

 
 Do you have pain or stiffness in your neck?

 Do symptoms worsen with certain neck positions?

 Does pain radiate down the arm?

 Does raising your arm overhead help?

 
 

 When both conditions are present - double crush

 In some cases, the patient actually has both conditions simultaneously. This is called "double crush syndrome", where irritation of the nerve at one level makes it more vulnerable to effects elsewhere.

 Prevalence varies from 14-26% depending on study design (Upton & McComas, 1973; subsequent studies). Practically, this means thorough examination of both neck and wrist is important in all patients with finger numbness.

Describe causes and risk factors for Rib Dislocation vs. Rib Fracture.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Rib Fracture - From Most Common to Rarest

 Motor vehicle accidents - account for approximately 60% of cases (European Journal
 of Cardio-Thoracic Surgery, 2003)

 Falls - make up about 22% of cases, especially in older adults

 Direct blows - sports, violence, workplace accidents

 Severe coughing - especially in people with osteoporosis 

 Stress fractures - in athletes, especially rowers (6-12% prevalence according to
 Sports Medicine Review, 2011)

 Risk factors: Age over 65 significantly increases the risk -
 older patients account for 50% of all rib fractures in the emergency room. Osteoporosis gives approximately double the risk. Previous rib fracture
 after age 45 gives 5.4 times higher risk for new fractures (NORA Study, 2011).

 Rib Dislocation - Typical Triggers

 Prolonged sitting - office position, driving, can contribute to stiff back 

 Sudden rotational movements - golf, tennis, throwing

 Heavy lifting - especially with twisting

 Sleeping position - waking up with pain after lying crooked

 Repetitive movements - painting, washing, gardening

 Women are affected 2.5 times more often than men, and the condition is most
 common in younger adults. The non-dominant side is most often affected, typically between T1 and T5
 (Frontiers in Pain Research, 2022).

Explain prognosis for Kyphosis and Poor Posture.

Prognosis

 The prognosis for functional kyphosis is generally good with active treatment. Meta-analyses show that
 structured exercise programs can reduce kyphosis angle by 5-13 degrees over 8-12 weeks. Younger patients
 show better response than older ones.

 Important to know: Improvements require maintenance. Without continued exercise, most
 will gradually return to previous posture patterns. Therefore, home exercises and awareness of daily
 habits are crucial for long-term results.

 With structural kyphosis ( Scheuermann's disease , osteoporosis ), the prognosis is more variable and depends on severity.
 These conditions cannot be reversed, but function and quality of life can often be significantly improved.

Describe What is stress neck? for Stress Neck and Trigger Points.

What is stress neck?

 

 Stress neck describes a condition where psychological stress manifests as physical tension in the neck
 and shoulder muscles. When we experience stress, the body activates the "fight-or-flight" response which
 increases muscle tension - especially in the neck, shoulders and jaw.

 
 The Stress-Tension-Pain Cycle

 Many get caught in a vicious cycle:

 
 Stress - increased muscle tension

 Tension - trigger points and pain

 Pain - more stress and worry

 More stress - even more tension

 
 Treatment often needs to address multiple links in this cycle for lasting improvement.

 

 What are trigger points?

 Trigger points are hypersensitive areas in muscle tissue that feel like hard knots when palpated. They
 have two important characteristics:

 
 Local tenderness: The point is painful when pressed

 Referred pain: Pressing the point can trigger pain in other areas - e.g., trigger
 points in the trapezius can cause headache

How is When Dizziness Doesn't Fit: Is It BPPV or Something Else? diagnosed?

Why Duration is Key to Diagnosis

 

 The simplest way to distinguish between different causes of dizziness is to ask: How long do the episodes last?

 
 Seconds (under one minute)

 Classic BPPV. Crystals in the ear trigger brief, intense dizziness with head movements.

 

 
 Minutes to hours (5 min - 72 hours)

 Vestibular migraine. About 30% have attacks lasting minutes, 30% hours, and 30% several days.

 

 
 20 minutes to 12 hours

 Meniere's disease. Attacks come with hearing loss, tinnitus, and pressure sensation in the ear.

 

 
 Days to weeks (constant)

 Vestibular neuritis. Acute inflammation of the balance nerve causes persistent dizziness that gradually subsides.

 

 
 Months (persistent daily)

 PPPD. Chronic unsteadiness worsened by movement and visual stimuli.

 

 
 Important rule

 If your dizziness lasts longer than one minute per episode, it's probably not classic BPPV.

Describe Variation and Breaks for Shoulder-Friendly Workspace: How to Set Up Your Workstation.

Variation and Breaks

 

 No matter how perfect the ergonomics are, the body is not made for prolonged stillness. Variation and
 breaks are more important than the "perfect" setup:

 
 Break structure

 
 Micro-breaks (30 sec - 1 min): Every 20-30 minutes. Straighten up, roll
 shoulders, look away from the screen.

 Short breaks (5-10 min): Every hour. Stand up, walk a few steps, stretch.

 Longer breaks (15-30 min): Lunch etc. Get away from the workstation completely.
 

 
 

 
 Sit-stand desk

 A sit-stand desk allows you to alternate between sitting and standing work. It's not about standing
 all day (that's not good either), but about variation.

 
 Start with short standing periods (15-30 min)

 Alternate between sitting and standing several times a day

 Remember that ergonomics must also be correct in standing position

 
 

 
 Tips to remember breaks

 
 Use app or timer to remind you of breaks

 Drink plenty of water - then you also have to get up more often

 Place the printer, coffee machine etc. so you have to walk

 Take phone calls standing or walking

Beskriv årsaker og risikofaktorer for Skulderbladssmerte og Cervikal Radikulopati.

2 Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 Hvorfor gir nakkeproblemer skulderbladssmerte?

 Nervene fra nakken (C4-C8) har forgreninger som innerverer muskulaturen og huden rundt skulderbladene. Når en nerverot irriteres, kan smerten oppleves der nerven ender - ikke der problemet sitter.

 Fra vanligst til sjeldnest

 Muskulær spenning/myofasiell smerte: Triggerpunkter i rhomboider og trapezius. Vanligst. Ofte relatert til kontorarbeid

 Cervikal referert smerte/radikulopati: Underdiagnostisert. Bør mistenkes når smerten forverres ved nakkebevegelser

 Brystryggdysfunksjon: Stivhet i brystrygg-segmentene og costovertebral-dysfunksjon

 Skulderpatologi: Scapulær dyskinesi, rotator cuff 

 Visceral referert smerte: Hjertesykdom (venstre skulderblad), gallesten (høyre skulderblad) - sjeldent, men viktig å utelukke

 Hvilke nakkenivåer gir skulderbladssmerte?

 Mizutamari et al. (2011) kartla smertmønstrene hos 180 pasienter
 C5: Over skulderbladstoppen (suprascapulært)

 C6: Fra skulderbladstoppen mot baksiden av skulderen

 C7: Mellom skulderbladene (interscapulært) - vanligst

 C8: Mellom og rundt skulderbladene

Hvordan diagnostiseres Isjias: Alt du trenger å vite?

Diagnostikk

 

 Klinisk undersøkelse

 Diagnostikken baseres primært på sykehistorie og klinisk undersøkelse. En grundig nevrologisk undersøkelse kan ofte lokalisere hvilket niva i ryggen som er affisert.

 Lasegues test (straight leg raise) er den mest prediktive testen for å identifisere kandidater for kirurgi. Testen er positiv når den reproduserer pasientens smerte ved et benløft under 45 grader med utstraling under kneet (StatPearls, 2023).

 Bildediagnostikk

 MR eller CT anbefales ikke rutinemessig. Danske nasjonale retningslinjer frarader rutinemessig bildediagnostikk ved nyoppstått isjias (European Spine Journal, 2018).

 
 Viktig å forstå

 Bildediagnostikk viser ofte normalfunn som slitasje og degenerative forandringer som ikke forklarer smerten. Studier viser at opptil 20-80% av symptomfrie personer har funn på MR som diskusbuling, degenerasjon eller protrusion (StatPearls, 2023).

 

 Bildediagnostikk er indisert ved:

 
 Mistanke om alvorlig patologi (røde flagg)

 Vedvarende symptomer etter 6-8 ukers konservativ behandling

 Ved vurdering av kirurgi

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Skuldersmerter – Komplett guide.

Hvordan kan kiropraktikk hjelpe?

 

 På TheBackROM kombinerer jeg manuell behandling med aktiv rehabilitering. Forskning viser at denne kombinasjonen gir best resultater for de fleste skulderplager.

 
 Manuell behandling

 Jeg bruker ulike teknikker for å forbedre ledd- og muskelfunksjon:

 
 Leddmobilisering for bedre bevegelighet

 Bløtvevsteknikker for spente muskler og triggerpunkter

 Behandling av nakke og brystrygg å mange skulderproblemer henger sammen med stivhet her

 
 

 
 Aktiv rehabilitering

 Øvelser er selve hjØrnesteinen i effektiv skulderbehandling. Forskning viser at strukturerte Øvelsesprogrammer er like effektive som kirurgi for mange tilstander (Kukkonen et al., 2014). Du får:

 
 Spesifikke styrkeøvelser tilpasset din diagnose

 Tøyninger og mobiliseringsØvelser

 HjemmeØvelser du kan gjøre selv mellom behandlingene

 Veiledning om ergonomi og aktivitetstilpasning

 
 

 Hva kan du forvente?

 
 Første konsultasjon (45 minutter)

 Jeg starter alltid med grundig undersøkelse:

 
 Samtale om symptomene dine og hvordan de påvirker hverdagen

 Fysisk undersøkelse av skulder, nakke og rygg

 Testing av styrke og bevegelse

 Klar diagnose og behandlingsplan

 
 

 
 Typiske behandlingstider

 
 Milde plager: 4-6 uker

 Moderate plager: 6-12 uker

 Frossen skulder: 12-24 måneder (men bedring kommer gradvis underveis)

 Kroniske plager: Kan kreve lengre oppfølging

 
 Du vil se gradvis forbedring, ikke plutselig kurering. De fleste trenger 8-12 behandlinger ...

4. Vestibular Neuritis (3.5-15.5 per 100,000/year)

 Acute inflammation of the balance nerve, often following viral infection.

 
 Sudden onset, severe dizziness

 Persists constantly for days to weeks (not attacks)

 Nausea and vomiting common in acute phase

 Worsened by head movements, but not triggered by specific positions

 Hearing unaffected

 
 BPPV can develop secondary to vestibular neuritis in approximately 10% of cases.

Patient asks: "Which pillow is best for the neck?"

The best pillow keeps the neck in neutral position aligned with the spine. Side sleepers need higher pillow than back sleepers. Memory foam or latex adapts better than down. The pillow should not be so high that the head is bent up, or so low that it falls down.

 Symptomene ved ICR syndrom varierer avhengig av underliggende Årsak:

 Lokale symptomer

 
 Ensidig halssmerte: Over carotisarteriens forløp

Explain glute exercises for Knee Exercises Home Program Complete Guide.

Glute exercises

 Hip strengthening is perhaps the most underrated part of a knee program. Research shows that combined hip and knee strengthening produces significantly better pain relief for patellofemoral pain than knee exercises alone (JOSPT 2018, Halabi 2025). Weak gluteus medius results in poor control over knee position.

 Clamshell

 Fundamental 

 Lie on your side with knees bent approximately 45 degrees and feet together

 Keep your feet together and open the top knee like a clamshell

 Hold for 23 seconds at the top

 Lower slowly

 Dosage: 3 x 15 repetitions per side

 Tip: Do not rotate through your back the movement should come from the hip. Place a hand on your hip to check.

 Side-lying hip abduction

 Lie on your side with legs straight and body in a straight line

 Lift the top leg approximately 3040 cm from the bottom leg

 Keep your toes pointing forward (not upward)

 Lower slowly

 Dosage: 3 x 10 repetitions per side

 Important: Avoid tilting your hip backward. Maintain a stable core throughout the exercise.

 Monster walk (band around ankles)

 Place a resistance band around your ankles or just above your knees

 Bend your knees slightly and lower your hips (quarter-squat position)

 Step sideways while maintaining tension in the band

 Take 10 steps to the right, then 10 steps to the left

 Dosage: 3 x 10 steps in each direction

 Progression: Start without a band, add a light band after week 12, increase to medium resistance.

 Why are hip exercises important for the knee?

 The gluteus medius controls hip rotation when you walk, run and jump. Weak glutes allow the hip to rotate inward, which pulls the knee into a valgus position (inward collapse). This increases the load on the patellofemoral joint and can contribute to runner's knee , IT band syndrome and meniscus wear .

Identify red flags for C5-C6 Disc Herniation: Thumb and Index Finger Numbness.

Red Flags: When Should You Contact a Doctor?

 

 Most cases of C5-C6 disc herniation are harmless and resolve on their own. But some symptoms require
 prompt medical evaluation. See our article on red flags for more
 information.

 
 Seek Medical Attention Immediately For:

 
 Myelopathy signs: Problems with balance and gait, "clumsy" hands, difficulty
 buttoning buttons

 Progressive weakness: Increasing muscle weakness in arm or hand over days

 Bladder/bowel disturbances: Difficulty urinating or controlling urine/stool

 Bilateral symptoms: Numbness or weakness in both arms

 Fever combined with neck stiffness: May indicate infection

 
 These symptoms are rare but require prompt evaluation.

 

 Cervical Myelopathy

 Myelopathy occurs when the herniation or degenerative changes press on the spinal cord itself, not just
 the nerve root. This is more serious than pure radiculopathy and requires faster evaluation.

 
 Signs of Myelopathy

 
 Unsteady gait, especially in the dark

 Difficulty with fine motor skills (writing, buttoning buttons)

 Lhermitte's sign: Electric shock sensation down the spine with neck flexion

 Hyperactive reflexes in the legs

Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Triggerpunkter i Arm og Underarm.

Hva er triggerpunkter?: Triggerpunkter er hypersensitive områder i muskelfibre - ofte beskrevet som "knuter" eller "strammer". Når du trykker på et triggerpunkt, gir det karakteristisk smerte, og ofte også referred pain - smerte som stråler ut til andre områder.

Hvorfor oppstår triggerpunkter?: Triggerpunkter utvikles når muskelfibre blir overbelastet eller skadet. De vanligste årsakene i arm og underarm
Referred pain - smerter på avveie: Det mest forvirrende med triggerpunkter er referred pain : smerten kjennes et helt annet sted enn der problemet sitter. Dette forklarer hvorfor mange får feil diagnose.

Symptomer på triggerpunkter: Slik gjenkjenner du triggerpunkter i arm og underarm
Viktige muskler i armen: Her er de musklene som oftest utvikler triggerpunkter i arm og underarm
Behandling av triggerpunkter: Triggerpunkter responderer godt på manuell behandling. De viktigste metodene
Hva kan du gjøre selv?: Du kan behandle mange triggerpunkter selv med enkle teknikker

Unsteadiness - Rocking or Swaying Sensation

 With unsteadiness, you feel off-balance without the room spinning. It can be described as standing on a boat deck or walking on an unstable surface.

 
 Typical description: "Like being on a boat", "I feel unstable"

 Often accompanied by: Neck pain, anxiety, worsening in crowds

Forklar Skiveprolaps i Korsryggen for en pasient.

Mellomvirvelskivene fungerer som stotdempere mellom ryggvirvlene. Hver skive har en hard ytre ring (annulus fibrosus) og en myk, geleaktig kjerne (nucleus pulposus). En prolaps oppstår når denne kjernen presses gjennom sprekker i den ytre ringen og kan irritere eller klemme på nerverotter.

 Skiveproblemer er likevel en sjelden årsak til ryggsmerter . WFNS Spine Committee (2024) fastslar at degenerativ skivesykdom kun star bak under 5% av alle korsryggsmerte-tilfeller. De fleste ryggsmerter skyldes muskulare og uspesifikke årsaker (80-90%).

Beskriv Hva er hallux rigidus? for Hallux Rigidus (Stiv Storta).

Hva er hallux rigidus?

 

 Hallux rigidus er artrose (slitasjegikt) i stortåens grunnledd - leddet der stortåen fester til mellomfoten. Dette leddet er helt avgjørende for normal gange, da det bøyes opptil 60 grader ved hvert skritt.

 Når brusken i leddet slites ned, oppstar betennelse, smerter og etter hvert beindannelse (osteofytter) rundt leddet. Disse beinpalsene begrenser bevegelsen ytterligere og kan gi en synlig kul på toppen av leddet.

 
 
 2,5%
 over 50 Ør rammes
 

 
 1 av 40
 voksne totalt
 

 
 80%
 har det i begge fotter
 

 
 50-60
 vanligste alder
 

 

 Graderingssystem

 Hallux rigidus klassifiseres vanligvis i fire stadier:

 
 
 
 Grad
 Bevegelse
 Røntgenfunn
 Symptomer
 
 
 
 
 Grad 0-1
 Lett redusert
 Minimale forandringer
 Periodiske smerter ved aktivitet
 
 
 Grad 2
 Moderat redusert (30-50 grader)
 Osteofytter, leddspaltereduksjon
 Smerter ved bevegelse, hevelse
 
 
 Grad 3
 Betydelig redusert (< 30 grader)
 Store osteofytter, betydelig artrose
 Konstante smerter, endret gangmønster
 
 
 Grad 4
 Minimal eller ingen
 Komplett artrose
 Alvorlig funksjonshemming

Explain prognosis - how does it go? for Tension Headache: Everything You Need to Know.

Prognosis - How Does It Go?

 Episodic tension headache generally has a good prognosis
 75% 
 continue only episodically 

 ~50% 
 remission over 3 years 

 15-25% 
 develop chronic form 

 Risk Factors for Chronification

 Medication overuse (strongest predictor)

 Concurrent migraine

 Sleep problems

 Depression and anxiety

 Sedentary lifestyle

 Realistic Expectations

 Relapse is common, especially with the chronic form. Treatment can provide significant relief and fewer headache days, but preventive measures (exercise, stress management, good habits) often need to be maintained to keep complaints in check.

Explain POTS and Orthostatic Dizziness to a patient.

POTS stands for Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome - a condition where the heart beats abnormally fast when you stand up from a lying or sitting position. POTS is one of many causes of dizziness , but differs from vestibular conditions in that the symptoms are primarily caused by disturbed blood pressure regulation.

 Normally, the pulse increases by 10-15 beats per minute when you stand up. In POTS, the pulse increases by 30 beats or more (40 beats for youth 12-19 years) within 10 minutes of standing up - without the blood pressure dropping significantly.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Jaw Exercises and Home Treatment for TMD.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How often should I do the exercises?

 Most protocols recommend 4-6 times daily. The Rocabado program uses 6 repetitions, 6 times daily. Short sessions spread throughout the day are more effective than one long session.

 

 
 Should it hurt during exercises?

 No. Mild discomfort or stretch is fine, but sharp pain means you're pushing too hard. Reduce intensity and talk to your practitioner if pain persists.

 

 
 Do bite splints help?

 Bite splints (stabilization splints) have about the same effect as exercises on pain according to research (Zhang et al., 2021). The advantage of exercises is that they are free and give faster improvement - on average 10 weeks earlier.

 

 
 Can I exercise with TMD?

 Yes, but avoid exercises that stress the jaw. Contact sports, swimming with lots of rotation and activities where you clench your teeth can temporarily worsen symptoms.

 

 
 How long must I continue with exercises?

 After symptoms are under control, maintenance exercises 1-2 times daily long-term are recommended. TMD has a high relapse rate, and prevention is easier than treatment.

 

 
 Should I get imaging (MRI/X-ray)?

 Usually not. Imaging often shows normal findings like wear and degeneration that don't explain the pain. Clinical examination is more important. Imaging is only relevant when serious pathology is suspected.

 

 
 Can stress alone cause TMD?

 Stress is one of the most important risk factors. Many tighten the jaw and ...

Describe symptoms and signs of Cervicogenic Dizziness (Neck-Related Dizziness).

Symptoms

 

 Typical Presentation:

 
 Diffuse unsteadiness or swaying feeling lasting minutes to hours

 Feeling that the head is "heavy" or "clumsy"

 Worsening with prolonged sitting, especially in front of a computer screen

 Neck pain or stiffness occurring together with the dizziness

 Headache starting in the neck and radiating forward

 Mild nausea (rarely severe vomiting)

 

 What Does NOT Fit with Cervicogenic Dizziness:

 
 Short, intense spinning attacks (10-60 sec): Suggests BPPV

 Hearing loss or tinnitus: Points to vestibular pathology like Meniere's disease or vestibular neuritis

 Severe attacks with light/sound sensitivity: Vestibular migraine

 Neurological symptoms: Double vision, speech difficulties - requires immediate evaluation

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Shoulder-Friendly Workspace: How to Set Up Your Workstation.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How high should the screen be to avoid shoulder pain?

 The top of the screen should be at eye level or slightly below. This means you
 look straight ahead or slightly down, which provides a relaxed neck and shoulder position.

 

 
 Can mouse use cause shoulder pain?

 Yes. If the mouse is placed too far out to the side or too high, you have to
 extend your arm and raise your shoulder. Over time, this can cause tension and pain in the shoulder
 and neck.

 

 
 How often should I take breaks from computer work?

 Ideally, you should take a micro-break (30-60 seconds) every 20-30 minutes, and
 a longer break (5-10 minutes) every hour. Movement and variation are key.

 

 
 Is a standing desk better for the shoulders?

 Variation is more important than whether you sit or stand. A sit-stand desk
 allows you to alternate between positions throughout the day, which is beneficial for both shoulder,
 neck and back.

 

 
 What exercises can I do at my desk?

 Good exercises include shoulder rolls, neck stretches, chest opening and
 shoulder blade squeeze. These only take a few seconds and can be done sitting at your desk.

 

 
 Does ergonomic equipment help?

 Ergonomic equipment (mouse, keyboard, chair) can help, but it's not magic. The
 most important thing is correct setup of what you have, and above all breaks and movement. Expensive
 equipment doesn't replace good habits.

Describe symptoms and signs of Cervical Foraminal Stenosis - Narrowed Nerve Canal in Neck.

Symptoms

 

 Typical Symptoms

 
 Radicular pain: Sharp, burning, or electric pain that radiates from neck to arm
 

 Numbness and tingling: Often in specific fingers depending on which nerve is
 affected

 Weakness: Reduced strength in specific arm or hand muscles

 Neck stiffness: Especially with movements that close the foramen (extension +
 rotation toward painful side)

 

 
 Spurling's Test

 A classic test for foraminal stenosis: The head
 is bent backward and rotated toward the painful side, then light pressure is applied downward. A
 positive test reproduces radiation to the arm. This "closes" the foramen and provokes symptoms.

Forklar kombinasjon: minimalistsko + fottrening for Minimalistsko og barfottrening: Hva sier forskningen?.

Kombinasjon: Minimalistsko + fottrening

 Den mest effektive tilnærmingen kombinerer minimalistsko med målrettet fottrening
 Synergistisk effekt

 Minimalistsko gir passiv stimulering gjennom hele dagen, mens fotøvelser gir aktiv, målrettet styrking . Sammen gir de raskere og bedre resultater enn hver for seg.

 Anbefalt kombinasjon

 Morgenen: 5-10 minutter fotøvelser (short foot, taespredning, haelhev)

 Hele dagen: Minimalistsko eller barfot så mye som mulig

 Kvelden: Lett taying av legger og fotbunn

Identifiser røde flagg for Nakkesmerter.

Røde flagg - når du må handle raskt

 Gå til full artikkel om røde flagg ? 

 OPPSØK LEGE ELLER LEGEVAKT UMIDDELBART

 Nakkesmerter etter traume (fall, ulykke) med nummenhet eller svakhet

 Feber kombinert med stiv nakke og hodepine (mulig infeksjon)

 Plutselig, intens hodepine som når maksimal styrke på under 1 minutt ("thunderclap hodepine")

 Økende svakhet i armer eller ben

 Problemer med vannlating eller avforing

 Klossete hender (problemer med knapper, mister ting) + gangvansker

 Dette kan være tegn på tilstander som krever rask utredning. 

 Cervikal myelopati - ryggmargskompresjon

 Cervikal myelopati oppstår når ryggmargen i nakken blir klemt. Selv om tilstanden er sjelden (ca. 4 per 100 000), er det viktig å kjenne til fordi tidlig behandling er avgjørende - ubehandlet kan det fore til permanent funksjonsnedsettelse.

 75%

 har "klossete hender" - vansker med knapper

 72-80%

 har gangforstyrrelser - usto, bredsporet gange

 82%

 har nummenhet i hendene, ofte bilateral

 Arteriedisseksjon - en sjelden men alvorlig årsak

 Disseksjon av halspulsarene er sjelden (3-5 per 100 000 Årlig), men er en viktig årsak til slag hos voksne under 50 år - opptil 10% av slag i denne aldersgruppen.

 Thunderclap hodepine: Plutselig, intens hodepine som når maksimal intensitet på under 1 minutt

 Horner's syndrom: Hengende oyelokk og liten pupill på en side (sees hos ca. 25%)

 Ensidig nakke-/hodesmerte: Smerten er typisk på samme side som disseksjonen
Du er en rask klinisk tekstassistent. Generer korte, presise kliniske oppsummeringer for kiropraktisk dokumentasjon.
Gi en strukturert klinisk oversikt over Skoliose – Skjev Rygg hos Barn og Voksne.

Hva er skoliose?: Skoliose defineres som en sidekurve i ryggraden med en Cobb-vinkel over 10 grader på stående røntgen. Tilstanden er tredimensjonal – i tillegg til sidekurven er det rotasjon av virvlene og ofte endret krumning i sagittalplanet.

Skoliose hos barn og ungdom: Idiopatisk adolescent skoliose (AIS) er den vanligste formen og rammer barn mellom 10 og 18 år. En global metaanalyse fra 2024 beregnet prevalensen hos barn og ungdom til 3,1 % (95 % KI: 1,5–5,2 %; BMC Public Health 2025).

Voksenskoliose og degenerativ skoliose: Skoliose hos voksne kan enten være videreføring av en ungdomsskoliose som aldri ble behandlet, eller helt nyutviklet degenerativ skoliose.

Årsaker og risikofaktorer: Rundt 20 % av de med idiopatisk skoliose har nær familie med tilstanden (Ogilvie et al. 2006). Arveligheten er kompleks – mange gener er involvert – men familiær opphopning er godt dokumentert.

Diagnostikk og måling: Gullstandarden for screening. Pasienten bøyer seg forover med rette knær og armene hengende. Undersøkeren ser etter asymmetri – særlig en «ribbepukkel» som skyldes virvelrotasjon. Testen er enkel og kan utføres av foreldre hjemme.

Behandling – korsett, øvelser og oppfølging: De fleste med mild skoliose lever helt normalt. Behandlingen handler om overvåking og forebygging
Kiropraktisk behandling ved skoliose: Kiropraktor kan ikke rette ut en strukturell skoliose. Det kan ingen manuell behandling. En systematisk oversikt fra 2023 konkluderte med at det er utilstrekkelig evidens for spinal manipulasjon alene som behandling for kurvekorrigering ved AIS (Sun et al. 2023, BioMed Research International).

Røde flagg – når du bør søke hjelp raskt: Ryggsmerter hos barn og ungdom med skoliose er uvanlig og bør utredes for andre årsaker. Idiopatisk skoliose i seg selv er sjelden smertefullt i ung alder.

Forklar behandling for Mal de Debarquement Syndrom.

Behandling

 Viktig å vite

 MdDS er en utfordrende tilstand å behandle. Forskningen er begrenset, og det finnes ingen standardbehandling som hjelper alle. En scoping review fra 2023 identifiserte forbedring med flere behandlingsmetoder, men understreket at evidensen fortsatt er begrenset.

 Spesialisert behandling - VOR-readaptasjon (Dai-protokollen)

 Den mest lovende behandlingen er optokinetisk VOR-readaptasjon, utviklet av Dr. Mingjia Dai ved Mount Sinai Hospital. Behandlingen innebører visuell stimulering med bevegelige striper i synsfeltet, samtidig passiv rulling av hodet fra side til side, over gjentatte sesjoner.

 Resultater
 ~70% oppnadde betydelig bedring umiddelbart etter behandling

 Etter 1 år var 52% av bevegelses-utloste tilfeller fortsatt betydelig bedre

 Pasienter behandlet innen 1 år fra symptomdebut hadde bedre prognose (62%) enn de med symptomvarighet over 3 år (30%)

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 Aerlig forventningsavklaring: Forskning viser at kiropraktisk og fysioterapeutisk behandling ikke har dokumentert effekt på selve MdDS-symptomene.

 Likevel kan kiropraktoren bidra med
 Grundig utredning - Mange med svimmelhet har andre årsaker som kan behandles

 Utelukke mekaniske årsaker - Nakkeproblemer kan gi svimmelhet , men dette er en annen tilstand enn MdDS

 Henvise til riktig spesialist - ONH-lege eller nevrolog for videre utredning

 Behandle assosierte plager - Nakke- og ryggsmerter som ofte følger langvarig MdDS

 Generell vestibulær screening - Avdekke andre balanseproblemer

What is the prognosis for Sciatica: Everything You Need to Know?

Prognosis - What Can You Expect?

 

 Here's the good news: the prognosis for sciatica is generally good, but it often takes longer than many
 think.

 
 The positive:

 
 The majority improve without surgery

 50% experience significant improvement within 4 weeks

 55-70% have recovered within a year

 Disc herniations can shrink and be reabsorbed over time

 
 

 
 The realistic:

 
 Median time to improvement is 10-12 weeks - not 6 weeks

 20-30% have persistent symptoms after 1-2 years

 Recurrence affects about 1 in 4 within a few years

Describe diagnosis for Ankylosing Spondylitis.

Diagnosis

 The diagnosis is made based on a combination of medical history, clinical examination, blood tests, and
 imaging. Unfortunately, it often takes 8-10 years from symptom onset to diagnosis,
 which underscores the need for increased awareness.

 Clinical examination

 Assessment of spinal mobility (Schober's test)

 Examination of SI joints

 Measurement of chest wall expansion

 Assessment of posture and gait pattern

 Blood tests

 HLA-B27

 90-95% positive 

 A gene found in most people with ankylosing spondylitis. However: 8% of the general population also
 has this gene without developing the disease. A positive test is supportive but not diagnostic alone.

 Inflammatory markers

 CRP and ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) may be elevated but are normal in up to 40% of patients.
 Normal CRP does not rule out ankylosing spondylitis.

 Imaging

 Pelvic X-ray

 Shows sacroiliitis (changes in the SI joints). Required for classic AS diagnosis according to New
 York criteria. May be normal early in the disease course.

 MRI

 Important for early diagnosis 

 Can show active inflammation (bone marrow edema) in SI joints and spine before X-ray changes occur.
 Crucial for diagnosing non-radiographic axial spondyloarthritis.

 When should you consider ankylosing spondylitis?

 Back pain that started before age 40, has lasted more than 3 months, is worst in the morning with
 stiffness over 30 minutes, improves with activity, and disturbs sleep - should lead to investigation
 for inflammatory spinal disease.

Describe Headache through the lifespan for Hormonal Headache and Menstrual Migraine.

Headache through the lifespan

 

 Hormonal headache changes throughout life in step with the major hormonal shifts:

 
 
 Menarche (first period)

 Migraine often debuts in puberty. Before puberty, migraine is equally common in boys and girls - afterward it becomes 3x more common in women.

 

 
 Fertile years

 Menstrual migraine is most common. Many experience that attacks are worst during the first days of the period. Birth control can both help and worsen.

 

 
 Pregnancy

 60-70% experience improvement, especially in the 2nd and 3rd trimester when hormone levels are stable and high. Some experience onset or worsening.

 

 
 After birth

 Rapid drop in estrogen can cause migraine relapse shortly after birth. Breastfeeding can provide protection due to stable hormones.

 

 
 Perimenopause

 Often a difficult period with unpredictable fluctuations. Many experience worsening of migraine during this phase.

 

 
 After menopause

 Many experience significant improvement or their migraine disappears when hormone levels stabilize at a lower level.

Patient asks: "What is cervical myelopathy?"

Cervical myelopathy is a condition where the spinal cord in the neck becomes compressed. The most common cause is degenerative spondylosis (wear and tear) of the cervical spine, accounting for over 85% of cases. It is a serious condition that can cause permanent neurological damage without treatment.

Forklar behandling for Hodepine i tinningen.

Behandling

 Behandlingstilnærmingen avhenger av underliggende årsak. Tidlig behandling kan ofte gi raskere bedring enn å vente og se.

 Ved cervikogen hodepine

 Her er evidensen sterkest. En systematisk oversikt av 20 RCT-studier fant moderat evidens for at manipulasjon gir betydelig korttidseffekt på smerteintensitet. En viktig studie viste at 72% av pasientene oppnådde minst 50% reduksjon i hodepinefrekvens ved 12-måneders oppfølging.

 Ved spenningshodepine

 Evidensen er svakere for manipulasjon alene. En metaanalyse fant at bløtvevsteknikker var bedre enn ingen behandling (lav evidens), mens manipulasjon ikke viste signifikant effekt sammenlignet med kontroll. Nålebehandling (dry needling) viste moderat evidens for effekt.

 Ved TMD-relatert hodepine

 Forskning tyder på at kombinert behandling av kjeve og nakke er mer effektivt enn nakkebehandling alene. Triggerpunktbehandling av temporalis og masseter kan redusere både lokal omhet og referert tinningssmerte.

 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 Selvundersøkelse av temporalis

 Plasser fingertuppene på tinningen, over og foran øret. Bit tennene sammen - du skal kjenne muskelen stramme seg. Trykk med moderat kraft i 2 sekunder på fremre, midtre og bakre del. Vurder omhet. Masser deretter med sirkulære bevegelser i 30-60 sekunder.

 Kjeveøvelser

 Kontrollert gaping med tungen avslappet mot ganen, sideveis kjevebevegelser, og avspenningsøvelser ("leppene sammen, tennene fra hverandre") har moderat evidens fra internasjonal konsensus.

 Nakkeøvelser

 Kraniocervikal fleksjonsovelse (dyp nakkefleksjon) har moderat til høy evidens for cervikogen hodepine. Ligg på ryggen, utfør forsiktig hakeknikk, hold 10 sekunder, 10 repetisjoner.

 Behandlingsforløp

 For cervikogen hodepine tyder forskning på at 8-10 behandlinger over 6 uker gir god effekt. Hyppigere behandling (3-4 ganger per uke) viser større bedring enn ukentlig behandling.

Red flags for When Orthotics Actually Help?

Seek medical attention immediately for
 Sudden, intense foot pain without obvious cause

Describe Common tests in the context of Proximal Hamstring Tendinopathy.

Common tests

 
 Palpation of sit bone - tenderness with pressure

 Bent-knee stretch - pain with stretching with bent knee

 Puranen-Orava test - active hamstring contraction

 Single leg bridge - often reproduces the pain

 
 

 Imaging

 
 MRI - can show tendon thickening and edema

 Ultrasound - useful for seeing tendon changes

 X-ray - can show bone deposits (enthesophytes)

 

 Imaging is not always necessary. Many are effectively treated based on clinical findings
 alone.

 Differential diagnoses

 
 Sciatica - from the spine

 Piriformis syndrome - pain higher in the
 buttock

 SI joint dysfunction - pelvic joint pain

 Stress fracture in pelvis - rare

 
 

 
 
 5
 Treatment

 

 Progressive strength training is key

 Research shows that heavy, progressive strength training is the well-documented treatment
 for PHT.

 
 Treatment principles:

 
 Start with isometric exercises (holding position)

 Gradually build up to heavier loads

 Focus on strength, NOT stretching

 Be patient - this takes time

 
 

 Phase 1: Pain control (weeks 1-2)

 
 Reduce compression - avoid prolonged sitting on hard chairs

 Use a cushion - relieve the sit bone

 Isometric exercises - hamstring activation without movement

 Avoid stretching!

 

 Phase 2: Strength building (weeks 2-8)

 
 Bridging progressions - from two-leg to single-leg

 Romanian deadlift - controlled hip flexion

 Nordic hamstring curl - eccentric strength

 Hip thrust - gluteal activation

 

 Phase 3: Functional training (weeks 8-12+)

 
 High loads - 80-90% of maximum strength

 Explosive training - jumps, sprints

 Running-specific training - gradual return

 

 Manual treatment

 
 Soft tissue treatment - can relieve muscle tension

 Pelvic and hip mobilization

 Nerve mobilization - for nerve irritation

 

 When is injection/surgery considered?

 
 Cortisone injection - can provide short-term relief, not first choice

 PRP injection - uncertain effect

 Surgery - rare, only for long-term failure of conservative treatment

 
 

 
 
 6
 Prognosis

 

 PHT is known to be a long-lasting condition, but most recover with patience and proper
 treatment.

 What can you expect?

 
 Weeks 1-4: Pain reduction with load management

 Months 1-3: Gradual strength building

 Months 3-6: Return to activity

 Up to 12 months: For long-standing cases

 

 Factors that affect prognosis

 
 Duration before treatment - early diagnosis gives better prognosis

 Compliance with strength program - necessary for recovery

 Avoiding stretching - many set themselves back by stretching

 Gradual return - too rapid progression causes relapse

 

 
 Relapses are common

 Many experience relapses, especially with too rapid progression of training. This is normal and does
 not mean treatment has failed. Adjust down, build up again - patience is key.

Identify red flags for Types of Dizziness: How to Tell the Difference Between Different Forms.

Red Flags - When Dizziness Is Serious

 

 
 Call emergency services immediately if you experience:

 
 Difficulty speaking (dysarthria)

 Facial weakness or numbness

 Double vision (diplopia)

 Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)

 Severe headache ("thunderclap headache")

 Weakness in arm or leg

 
 These symptoms may indicate stroke and require immediate evaluation.

 

 The five D's that warn of central problems: Diplopia, Dysarthria, Dysphagia, Dysmetria, Drop attacks.

What causes Hip Labral Tear?

Causes

 

 FAI (Femoroacetabular impingement)

 The most common cause of labral tear. With FAI (hip
 impingement), there is an abnormal shape of the femoral head (cam) or hip socket (pincer) that
 causes the labrum to be pinched during certain movements.

 Other causes

 
 Sports injuries - especially rotational sports like football, hockey, dance

 Acute trauma - falls, collisions

 Overuse - repetitive movements over time

 Hypermobility - overly mobile joints that increase wear

 Hip dysplasia - congenital shallow hip socket

 Degeneration - natural aging

 

 Risk factors

 
 Sports with deep hip flexion - yoga, martial arts, hockey

 Rotational sports - golf, tennis, football

 Dancers and gymnasts - extreme mobility

 FAI (cam/pincer) - structural abnormality

Describe What is Dizziness? for Dizziness - Complete Guide.

What is Dizziness?

 

 Dizziness isn't one thing. It's an umbrella term covering several different experiences:

 
 Three Types of Dizziness

 
 Vertigo: The sensation that you or your surroundings are rotating. The room spins,
 or you feel like you're spinning even though you're standing still. This almost always stems from
 disturbances in the balance organ.

 Unsteadiness: Often described as a swaying or rocking feeling - like standing on a
 boat deck. You don't feel quite stable on your feet.

 Light-headedness: A diffuse feeling of being "foggy" in the head. Some describe it
 as almost fainting.

 
 

 How Balance Works

 Three systems continuously send information to the brain:

 
 
 👂

 Balance Organ

 In the inner ear - registers the head's movements and position

 

 
 👁

 Eyes

 Tell the brain where you are in relation to your surroundings

 

 
 🦶

 Body Sense

 Sensors in muscles, tendons and joints report the body's position

 

 

 When all three systems send matching signals, you feel stable. When one system sends incorrect
 information - or the systems send conflicting signals - dizziness occurs.
