Beskriv Hva kan du gjøre selv? for Bihulehodepine eller migrene?.

Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 

 Ved migrene

 
 Hodepinedagbok: Registrer anfall, triggere, mat, søvn og menstruasjon. Dette hjelper deg å identifisere mønster.

 Regelmessighet: Hold faste tider for søvn, maltider og aktivitet. Migrenehjerner liker forutsigbarhet. Søvnproblemer kan også gi morgenhodepine.

 Triggerkontroll: unngå kjente triggere, men var oppmerksom på at "triggerjakt" kan bli overdrevet.

 Akuttbehandling: Smertestillende virker best når de tas tidlig i anfallet. Overforbruk (mer enn 10-15 dager per måned) kan føre til medikamentoverforbrukshodepine.

 

 Ved mistanke om bihulebetennelse

 
 Saltvannsskylling: Neseskylling med fysiologisk saltvann kan lindre symptomer.

 Fuktig luft: Dampinhalasjon eller luftfukter kan hjelpe mot tØrrhet.

 Nesespray: Slimløsende nesespray i korte perioder (maks 7-10 dager for avsvellende typer).

 Vent-og-se: De fleste virale bihulebetennelser går over på 7-10 dager uten behandling.

Describe Which Semicircular Canal Is Affected? for BPPV (Crystal Disease).

Which Semicircular Canal Is Affected?

 

 The inner ear has three semicircular canals on each side:

 
 Posterior Canal (80-90% of cases)

 By far the most common form. Diagnosed with the Dix-Hallpike test and treated with the Epley or Semont maneuver.

 

 
 Horizontal/Lateral Canal (5-30%, possibly up to 46%)

 May be underdiagnosed. Treated with Barbecue roll (Lempert) or Gufoni maneuver.

 

 
 Anterior Canal (1-3%)

 The rarest form. Crystals rarely fall upward due to anatomical position.

Forklar behandling for Tarsaltunnelsyndrom.

Behandling

 Moderat evidens for nervemobilisering

 To randomiserte kontrollerte studier (Kavlak 2011, El-Arahsy 2022) viser at tibialis nervemobilisering gir signifikant bedring utover standard konservativ behandling - i både nervefunksjon, smerte og funksjon.

 62% 
 oppnådde gode eller utmerkede resultater med konservativ behandling (Fortier et al. 2022, 384 pasienter)

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 1

 Nervemobilisering

 Kontrollerte bevegelser der ankelen føres gjennom dorsalfleksjon og eversjon for å la nerven gli fritt gjennom tunnelen

 2

 Biomekanisk vurdering og korreksjon

 Ganganalyse, fotstillingsvurdering og eventuelt innleggssåler ved overpronasjon eller plattfot

 3

 Manuell behandling av fot og ankel

 Mobilisering av subtalar- og ankelledd, bløtvevsbehandling av leggmuskulatur

 4

 Hjemmeøvelser og egenbehandling

 Nerveglidningsøvelser, leggstrekkøvelser og intrinsisk fotmuskeltrening

 Hva kan du gjøre selv?

 Nerveglidningsøvelser: 3 sett med 10-15 repetisjoner, 2-3 ganger daglig

 Leggstrekkøvelser: Hold 30 sekunder, 3 repetisjoner, 2-3 ganger daglig

 Riktige sko: Støttende sko som korrigerer overpronasjon

 Aktivitetstilpasning: Reduser provoserende aktiviteter i den akutte fasen

 Realistiske forventninger

 Evidensgrunnlaget for TTS-behandling er generelt av lav kvalitet . En scoping review fra 2024 fant at kun 1 av 30 studier var på evidensnivå 3. Omtrent 40% trenger videre tiltak utover konservativ behandling.

 Kirurgi

 Vurderes etter 3-6 måneder uten tilstrekkelig bedring. Kirurgisk dekompresjon gir 75,3% gode eller utmerkede resultater . Resultatene er best når en spesifikk årsak identifiseres, symptomene har vart kortere enn 12 måneder, og det er lite nervefibrose.

Beskriv symptomer og kjennetegn for Severs Syndrom.

Symptomer

 

 Symptomene utvikler seg typisk gradvis og forverres med aktivitet.

 Vanlige symptomer

 
 Smerter i haelen - typisk bak og under haelen

 Forverres ved aktivitet - spesielt loping og hopping

 Halting - spesielt etter trening

 Stivhet om morgenen eller etter hvile

 Omhet ved trykk på sidene av haelen

 Gang på ta - barnet ungår å belaste haelen

 

 
 Typisk mønster

 Smertene er ofte verst:

 
 Under og etter trening

 Ved loping på hardt underlag

 Ved bruk av fotbalsko eller andre sportssko med lav hælhøyde

 I perioder med rask vekst

 
 

 
 Diagnostikk

 Diagnosen stilles klinisk basert på sykehistorie og undersøkelse. Den klassiske "squeeze-testen" (smerter ved å klemme på sidene av haelen) er typisk positiv.

 Røntgen er vanligvis ikke nødvendig, men kan tas for å utelukke andre tilstander.

Describe causes and risk factors for Fat Pad Atrophy in the Forefoot.

2 Causes and Risk Factors

 Aging - most common cause

 This is a natural process that accelerates after age 50-60. Collagen and elastic fibers break down, the fat capsule loses volume, and you lose the natural cushioning under the forefoot.

 Other causes

 Cortisone injections: Can cause local fat cell death and permanent thinning - an important reason to be cautious with repeated forefoot injections

 Diabetes: Changes collagen properties through glycosylation and can cause intrinsic foot muscle atrophy (Bus et al. 2009)

 Rheumatoid arthritis: Damages fat pad structure through chronic inflammation

 Shoes and loading: Prolonged use of thin-soled shoes, high heels or extensive running on hard surfaces

Beskriv hva forårsaker nakkesmerter? for Nakkesmerter.

Hva forårsaker nakkesmerter?

 Uspesifikke nakkesmerter (80-90% av tilfellene)

 Gå til full artikkel om stressnakke ? 

 Mellom 80 og 90 prosent av alle nakkesmerter har ingen spesifikk årsak som kan påvises på røntgen eller MR (Kazeminasab et al., 2022). Det betyr ikke at smertene er innbilt - tvert imot kan de våre sværtplagsomme.

 Typiske kjennetegn: Stivhet, omhet og tyngdefølelse i nakke og skuldre. Smertene kommer ofte gradvis og kan henge sammen med stillesittende arbeid, stress, dårlig søvn eller ensidig belastning.

 Myofascielt smertesyndrom og triggerpunkter (88,9% har minst ett triggerpunkt)

 Gå til full artikkel om triggerpunkter ? 

 Stramme muskler med triggerpunkter - omme knuter i muskulaturen - er sværtvanlig ved nakkesmerter. En studie fant at hele 88,9% av pasienter med kroniske, uspesifikke nakkesmerter hadde minst ett triggerpunkt (Ezzati et al., 2021).

 De vanligste musklene som rammes er trapezius, infraspinatus og scalene-musklene. Triggerpunktene kan gi både lokal smerte og utstråling til hodet, skuldrene eller ned i armene.

 Facettleddsmerter (54-60% av kroniske tilfeller)

 Gå til full artikkel om facettledd og slitasje ? 

 Facettleddene er de små leddene på baksiden av nakkevirvlene. Ved kroniske nakkesmerter viser studier at facettleddene er smertekilden hos 54-60% av pasienter (Manchikanti et al., 2006).

 Typisk for facettleddsmerter er at de forverres ved bevegelse - særlig ved å bøye nakken bakover eller rotere hodet. Morgenstivhet er også vanlig.

 Tekst-nakke og fremoverlent holdning

 Gå til full artikkel om tekstnakke ? 

 Moderne smarttelefonbruk kan gi betydelig belastning på nakken.

Describe symptoms for Shoulder Osteoarthritis: Everything You Need to Know.

Symptoms

 Symptoms of shoulder osteoarthritis usually develop gradually
 Typical symptoms

 Pain: Deep, aching pain in the shoulder. Often worse with activity.

 Stiffness: Reduced mobility, especially rotation

 Crepitation: Creaking or grating during movement

 Night pain: Can wake you up or make it difficult to find a sleeping position. Read
 more about sleep and shoulder pain 

 Activity-related pain: Worsens with use, improves with rest

 Movements that often provoke symptoms

 Putting on a jacket or sweater

 Reaching behind the back (bra clasp, wallet)

 Lifting the arm out to the side

 Rotational movements

 Difference from frozen shoulder

 Shoulder osteoarthritis vs. frozen shoulder

 Shoulder osteoarthritis: Gradual stiffness over years, pain with loading,
 crepitation

 Frozen shoulder: Relatively rapid stiffness development (weeks-months),
 pronounced movement restriction in all directions, often resolves on its own

Identify red flags for Red Flags for Neck Pain.

The Chiropractor's Role with Red Flags

 When arterial dissection or myelopathy is suspected, the chiropractor's most important task is early
 recognition and rapid referral. I do not treat patients where there is suspicion of these conditions.

 At all new patient encounters, I conduct a thorough medical history and neurological screening. If you
 have symptoms as described above, I will assess whether you need acute medical evaluation - either via
 emergency room, emergency services, or direct referral to imaging and specialist.

 Measures that may be safe while awaiting specialist evaluation

 Soft tissue mobilization of thoracic region (avoiding deep pressure on neck)

 Patient education on posture and activity modification

 Gentle isometric neck exercises

 Contraindicated Measures

 HVLA neck manipulation

 Neck mobilization with end-range movements

 Mechanical neck traction

 Aggressive mobility exercises for the neck

Describe FAQ for De Quervain's Tenosynovitis: Complete Guide.

FAQ

 

 
 How long does it take to recover?

 With proper treatment, most experience significant improvement within 4-6 weeks.
 Complete healing may take 3-6 months.

 

 
 Does cortisone help?

 Yes, for De Quervain's, cortisone has good effect (unlike tennis elbow). Combined with splinting, this is gold standard according
 to JAMA 2023.

 

 
 Can I continue using my phone?

 You should significantly reduce thumb use on phone during treatment period.
 Consider using index finger or voice functions.

 

 
 Do I need surgery?

 Rarely. Most recover with conservative treatment. Surgery is only considered for
 prolonged symptoms without improvement from 1-2 cortisone injections.

Pasient spør: "Har jeg EDS, eller er jeg bare smidig?"

De fleste smidige mennesker har ikke EDS. Vanlig hypermobilitet er ufarlig. EDS mistenkes forst nar hypermobiliteten gir symptomer — kroniske smerter, gjentatte subluksasjoner, utmattelse — og nar det finnes systemiske tegn som myk hud, striae eller familiehistorie. Beighton-skaren er et utgangspunkt, men diagnosen krever en helhetlig vurdering.

Describe Supine Roll Test in the context of BPPV (Crystal Disease).

Supine Roll Test

 The patient lies flat on their back and the head is quickly rolled from side to side. Tests for horizontal canal BPPV.

 

 Do I Need MRI or CT?

 In the vast majority of cases, clinical examination is sufficient. Imaging is only relevant if symptoms do not match BPPV, you have red flags (headache, neurological symptoms), or treatment fails repeatedly without explanation.

 

 
 
 6
 Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Treatment consists of specific repositioning maneuvers that move the loose crystals out of the semicircular canal and back to the utricle where they belong.

 
 Epley Maneuver

 The most used and studied treatment for posterior canal BPPV. A meta-analysis showed symptom relief in 74-75% of patients after one treatment - over six times better than the control group. With repeated treatments, over 90% achieve improvement.

 

 Other Maneuvers

 
 Semont Maneuver: Alternative to Epley, especially useful for cupulolithiasis

 Gufoni Maneuver and Barbecue Roll: Used for horizontal canal BPPV

 

 What Can You Do Yourself?

 Once the diagnosis is confirmed and you have learned the correct technique, you can perform repositioning maneuvers at home during new episodes. Other measures that can help include vitamin D supplements if blood tests show deficiency, avoiding rapid head movements in the acute phase, and continuing normal activities as soon as possible.

 Treatment Course

 Most patients need 1-3 treatments. Median duration of symptoms is 2 weeks. Early treatment often leads to faster improvement.

 

 
 
 7
 Prognosis

 

 BPPV is a benign condition with very good prognosis. Repositioning maneuvers provide immediate improvement for most.

 Residual Dizziness After Treatment

 31-61% of patients report persistent mild dizziness or unsteadiness after successful treatment, even though nystagmus and positional vertigo are gone. This residual dizziness usually lasts a median of 10 days and typically resolves within 3 months. In some cases, this can develop into PPPD (Persistent Postural-Perceptual Dizziness).

 Recurrence Is Common

 
 Approximately 15-23% experience recurrence within the first year

 5-year recurrence rate is around 40%

 Up to 50% may experience a new episode within 5 years

 

 Prevention of Recurrence

 Vitamin D supplementation in patients with documented deficiency can reduce the risk of new episodes. A meta-analysis showed significant reduction in recurrence rate (relative risk 0.37).

 

 
 
 8
 Red Flags - When to See a Doctor

Describe Important to Understand for Nociplastic Pain: When the Nervous System Becomes Oversensitive.

Important to Understand

 

 
 THIS IS IMPORTANT

 
 Your pain is real. Nociplastic pain is not imaginary, psychosomatic, or "just in your head."

 It's not your fault. You haven't "chosen" to have this type of pain.

 It can get better. The nervous system has the ability to change back (neuroplasticity).

 Treatment takes time. This is a gradual process, not a quick fix.

 
 

 Common Misconceptions

 
 "The doctors can't find anything, so it must be psychological"

 Wrong. Nociplastic pain is a neurological condition. That the MRI is "normal" only means the cause of the pain isn't visible on the images - not that the pain is imaginary.

 

 
 "I just need to find the right practitioner who can fix me"

 With nociplastic pain, there's nothing to "fix" in the traditional sense. Treatment is about helping the nervous system function differently, and this requires active participation from you.

 

 
 "I need to rest until the pain goes away"

 Wrong approach. Prolonged rest and avoidance often reinforce sensitization. Graded, safe movement is necessary for improvement.

Describe diagnosis for Superior Canal Dehiscence Syndrome.

Diagnosis

 Clinical Questions That Can Reveal SCDS

 When SCDS is suspected, the following questions can be revealing
 "Can you hear your eyes moving?"

 "Do you get dizzy when straining or having a bowel movement?"

 "Does blowing your nose give you a spinning sensation?"

 "Do you hear your own voice abnormally loud in one ear?"

 Diagnostic Criteria (Barany Society, 2021)

 For the diagnosis of SCDS, all three of the following are required
 A. At Least One Characteristic Symptom

 Bone conduction hypersensitivity (autophony for internal body sounds), sound-induced dizziness/oscillopsia, pressure-induced dizziness/oscillopsia, or pulsatile tinnitus.

 B. At Least One Physiological Finding

 Nystagmus in the plane of the superior canal triggered by sound or pressure, negative bone conduction thresholds on audiometry in low frequencies, or enhanced VEMP responses.

 C. High-Resolution CT

 Showing dehiscence with 0.5-0.63 mm slice thickness or less and reformatted images in Poschl and Stenvers planes.

 Red Flags - When to Contact an ENT Specialist

 Dizziness triggered by loud sounds

 You hear your own eye movements, footsteps or heartbeat abnormally clearly

 Dizziness when straining, coughing or blowing your nose

 Pulsatile tinnitus combined with balance problems

 Hearing loss with preserved acoustic reflexes

 Position-triggered dizziness that doesn't respond to Epley maneuver

Describe red flags and differential diagnoses for Biceps Tendinopathy: Everything You Need to Know.

Red flags and differential diagnoses

 It is important to rule out other conditions that can cause similar symptoms.

 Seek medical attention if
 Sudden "pop" followed by severe pain and visible lump on upper arm (may be rupture)

 Significant loss of strength in the arm

 Swelling, redness and warmth (may be infection)

 Pain that does not subside with rest over several weeks

 General symptoms such as fever, weight loss

 If you suspect complete rupture of the biceps tendon (seen as "Popeye arm"), you should
 seek medical attention promptly, although the condition itself is rarely dangerous.

 Conditions that can resemble or occur simultaneously

 SLAP lesion 

 Injury to the labrum where the biceps tendon attaches. Often difficult to distinguish from biceps
 tendinopathy. MR arthrography is the gold standard for diagnosis.

 Rotator cuff tendinopathy

 Often present simultaneously. Supraspinatus tendinopathy causes pain more on the outside of the
 shoulder but can overlap.

 AC joint osteoarthritis 

 Pain localized more to the top of the shoulder. Worsens with cross-body movements (cross-body
 adduction).

 Subscapularis injury

 Can cause pain at the front of the shoulder and affect the biceps tendon secondarily (subscapularis
 stabilizes the biceps in the groove).

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Text Neck: From Mobile Use to Neck Pain.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 What is text neck?

 Text neck is a collective term for neck pain and problems that arise from prolonged mobile phone use
 with head bent forward. When head is 60 degrees forward, load on neck increases from about 5 kg to 27
 kg.

 Can text neck cause headache?

 Yes, text neck is a common cause of cervicogenic headache. The constant load on neck muscles and joints
 can cause tension headache that starts in neck and radiates to forehead and temples.

 How long does it take to get rid of text neck?

 With the right measures, most see improvement within 2-4 weeks. Key is to change mobile habits, do
 regular exercises, and possibly get treatment. Long-standing cases may require longer rehabilitation.
 

 Which exercises help with text neck?

 The most important exercises are chin tucks (double chin), chest stretches, and shoulder blade
 squeezes. These counteract forward head posture and strengthen muscles that hold head in neutral
 position.

 Is text neck dangerous?

 Text neck is not dangerous in itself, but prolonged strain can contribute to earlier degenerative
 changes in neck. It's important to address the problem early to avoid it becoming chronic.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Tennis Elbow (Lateral Epicondylitis).

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How long does it take for tennis elbow to heal?

 Most people (89%) experience significant improvement within 12 months with
 conservative treatment. With active rehabilitation and eccentric exercises, improvement can be seen as
 early as 6-8 weeks.

 

 
 Should I use an elbow brace/bandage?

 A tennis elbow brace can provide symptomatic relief and make it easier to function
 in daily life. It should be placed about 2-3 cm below the elbow, not over the tender spot. Use it as a
 supplement to training, not as the a key treatment approach.

 

 
 Does cortisone help with tennis elbow?

 Cortisone often provides short-term relief (2-6 weeks), but studies show a 72%
 recurrence rate. Patients who receive cortisone often have worse long-term results than those who choose
 active rehabilitation. I recommend avoiding cortisone.

 

 
 Can I continue to exercise?

 Yes, but avoid exercises that provoke pain. Pull exercises and gripping can be
 problematic. Focus on eccentric rehabilitation exercises and temporarily modify strength training.

 

 
 What's the difference between tennis elbow and golfer's elbow?

 Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) causes pain on the outside
 of the elbow and affects the extensor muscles. Golfer's elbow (medial
 epicondylitis) causes pain on the inside and affects the flexor muscles. The treatment
 principles are similar.

 

 
 Do I need surgery?

 Rarely. Only 5-10% with prolonged problems (over 12 months) without...

Describe Pressure-Induced Dizziness (Hennebert Sign) in the context of Superior Canal Dehiscence Syndrome (SCDS).

Pressure-Induced Dizziness (Hennebert Sign)

 Affects 37% and is triggered by Valsalva maneuver (straining), coughing, sneezing, heavy lifting or nose blowing.

 

 Chronic unsteadiness and balance problems affect many, and up to 50% report mental fatigue and brain fog.

 Auditory Symptoms (Hearing Disturbances)

 
 Autophony

 The most characteristic symptom, affecting 42-60% of patients. Patients describe their own voice as sounding distorted or "metallic," and many hear their own body sounds abnormally loud - such as eye movements, footsteps, heartbeat and even bowel sounds. This is almost diagnostic for SCDS when present.

 

 
 Pulsatile Tinnitus: Occurs in 20-50% and is experienced as a "whooshing" sound synchronous with pulse

 Hearing Loss in Low Frequencies: Affects approximately 40%, typically in the 250-1000 Hz range

 Fullness Sensation in Ear: Reported by over 60%

 
 

 
 
 4
 Differential Diagnoses - What Can It Resemble?

 

 SCDS is called "the great imitator of the ear" because symptoms can resemble several other conditions:

 
 Meniere's Disease

 Also causes hearing loss and dizziness, but attacks come spontaneously and last 20 minutes to several hours. In SCDS, symptoms are temporally related to specific sound or pressure triggers.

Explain treatment - what helps? for Spondylosis.

Treatment - what helps?

 The most important thing: Stay active

 Movement is the best medicine for a back with spondylosis. The discs in the spine receive nutrition through movement - they have no blood supply of their own. Sitting still is the worst thing you can do. Exercise therapy has strong evidence for chronic back pain (Hayden 2005, Cochrane).

 Good exercise plan

 Phase 1 (weeks 1-4): Gentle mobility exercises (cat-cow, knee-to-chest), daily walking 15-30 minutes

 Phase 2 (weeks 4-8): Core muscles (plank, bird-dog, bridges), general strength

 Phase 3 (weeks 8+): Maintenance program 3-5 times per week - strength, mobility, cardio

 Chiropractic treatment

 Spinal manipulation has moderate to strong evidence for chronic back pain (Rubinstein 2019, BMJ). For spondylosis, a chiropractor can help with
 What the chiropractor can do

 Mobilization of stiff segments to improve range of motion

 Soft tissue therapy for tight paraspinal muscles

 Pain education: Helping you understand what the findings mean and do not mean

 Exercise program tailored to your symptoms and functional level

 Lifestyle advice on activity, weight, and ergonomics

 Most people experience good improvement within 4-8 weeks with combined manual therapy and exercise.

 Lifestyle measures

 Move daily: Walking, swimming, cycling - it all counts

 Weight management: Excess weight increases loading and inflammation

 Quit smoking: Smoking reduces blood supply to the discs

 Vary your positions: Do not sit for more than 30-45 minutes at a time without getting up

 Sleep and stress management: Poor sleep and chronic stress lower your pain threshold

Explain treatment for Chronic Daily Headache.

Treatment

 Step 1: Identify and Treat Medication Overuse

 This is often the most important first step. In up to 80% of patients with chronic daily headache, medication overuse is present. Without addressing this, other treatment will have limited effect.

 Discontinuation of Painkillers

 Tapering or abrupt discontinuation of painkillers must occur under doctor supervision. Expect headache to worsen the first 1-2 weeks ("rebound headache") before improvement sets in. Most experience significant improvement after 6-8 weeks.

 Step 2: Lifestyle Interventions

 Lifestyle Measures With Documented Effect

 Regular sleep: Fixed bedtimes and wake times, even on weekends

 Regular meals: Don't skip meals

 Physical activity: Regular aerobic exercise has preventive effect

 Stress management: Mindfulness, relaxation, cognitive therapy

 Limit caffeine: Max 200 mg/day, keep intake stable

 Headache diary: Map triggers and medication use

 Step 3: Preventive Treatment

 With insufficient response to lifestyle measures, preventive medications may be relevant. This must be discussed with a doctor. Relevant medication groups include
 Beta-blockers (propranolol, metoprolol)

 Antidepressants (amitriptyline, venlafaxine)

 Antiepileptics (topiramate, valproate)

 CGRP inhibitors (for chronic migraine)

 Botulinum toxin (for chronic migraine)

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 Manual treatment can be part of a holistic approach, especially for
 Neck-related headache (cervicogenic component)

 Muscle tension in neck and shoulders

 Desire for non-drug treatment

 Honest About Evidence

 Evidence for manual treatment of chronic daily headache is limited. What works best is a multimodal approach that combines lifestyle changes, medication discontinuation when needed, and possibly preventive treatment. Manual therapy can be a useful supplement for some patients.

Describe causes and risk factors for Vestibular Migraine: When Dizziness Takes Over.

Causes and Risk Factors

 Pathophysiology - What Happens in the Brain?

 During an attack, CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) is released - a signaling molecule that plays a key role in migraine. CGRP is found both in the trigeminal system and in vestibular ganglia. When released, normal signal processing in the balance centers is disrupted.

 Risk Factors (from most to least common)

 Previous Migraine (most important)

 With or without aura - the most important risk factor. Many have had migraine in their youth that "disappeared."

 Female Gender

 3-5 times higher risk than men.

 Family History

 40-70% have a family history of migraine or vertigo.

 Anxiety and Depression

 Often concurrent conditions that can worsen symptoms.

 Previous Head Injury

 Significantly increases the risk.

 Triggers That Can Provoke Attacks

 Stress: Both acute stress and "let-down" stress (when you finally relax)

 Sleep: Too little, too much, or irregular sleep patterns

 Hormones: Menstrual cycle and menopause

 Food and drink: Red wine, aged cheese, chocolate, caffeine

 Sensory overstimulation: Bright lights, loud sounds, strong smells

Beskriv behandlingsalternativer for Horisontal Kanal BPPV.

Behandling

 

 Hva kan kiropraktoren gjøre?

 Behandling av horisontal kanal BPPV krever spesialiserte reposisjonsmanØvrer:

 
 BBQ-roll (Lempert-manåver)

 Pasienten roteres 360 grader i fire steg Ã  90 grader, med hodet hevet 30 grader. Hver posisjon holdes i 30-60 sekunder. En systematisk oversikt fra 2025 konkluderte med at BBQ-roll er en effektiv behandling. Studier viser 74% bedring etter en behandling og 85% innen tre behandlinger.

 

 
 Gufoni-manåver

 En systematisk oversikt fra 2024 med 10 studier og 1025 pasienter viste at Gufoni-manåveren er effektiv. For geotropisk variant ligger suksessraten på 71-92%, mens apogeotropisk variant har lavere respons på 63-78%. Fordelen er at den er lettere å utføre hos eldre pasienter.

 

 
 TRV-stol

 For komplekse tilfeller kan TRV-stol (en spesialisert behandlingsstol) benyttes. Denne metoden gir presisjonskontroll over hastighet, vinkel og amplitude.

 

 Behandlingsforløp - realistiske forventninger

 
 Best case (ca. 40-50%): Symptomfri etter 1-2 behandlinger. 75% er symptomfrie etter første konsultasjon

 Typisk case (ca. 30-40%): Krever 3-5 behandlinger over 2-3 uker

 Kompliserte tilfeller (ca. 15-20%): Bilateral involvering eller apogeotropisk variant kan kreve 6+ behandlinger

What is the prognosis for Fibromyalgia with Chest Pain?

Prognosis - What happens?

 

 Fibromyalgia is a chronic condition. A 10-year follow-up study (Wolfe et al., 1996) showed that 100%
 still had some symptoms, but 66% experienced improvement. Remission occurs in 17-47%
 after 1-2 years of active treatment.

 Factors that improve prognosis:

 
 
 Exercise
 The most important modifiable factor
 

 
 Early
 diagnosis and comprehensive treatment
 

 
 Sleep
 Treatment of depression and sleep problems
 

 

 For older patients, one should also be aware of osteoporosis as a
 possible additional diagnosis.

Describe causes and risk factors for Shoulder Impingement.

Causes and risk factors

 The cause of subacromial pain syndrome is usually multifactorial. Several factors play a role
 Overuse and repetitive movements

 Most common 

 Repetitive overhead arm movements are the most frequent trigger. This applies to both occupations (painters, electricians, plumbers) and sports (swimming, tennis, handball, volleyball).

 Muscular imbalance

 Weakness in the rotator cuff and scapular stabilizers (the muscles that control the shoulder blade) causes the upper arm bone to migrate upward, narrowing the subacromial space. This is one of the most important modifiable risk factors.

 Posture-related factors

 A forward-leaning posture with protracted shoulders (rounded upper back) alters shoulder biomechanics and can contribute to irritation of subacromial structures.

 Risk factors

 Overhead work/sports: Painters, swimmers, handball players

 Age over 40: Degenerative changes in tendons and bursa

 Poor posture: Protracted shoulders, increased thoracic kyphosis

 Previous shoulder injury: Altered biomechanics after trauma

 Diabetes and metabolic disease: Generally increased risk of tendon problems

 Overload as the main driver

 In most cases, the issue is that the load over time exceeds the tissue's tolerance threshold. This is why gradual progressive training and load management are so central to treatment.

Explain prognosis and recurrence for Lower Back Pain.

Prognosis and Recurrence

 For acute lower back pain, 39% are pain-free after 6 weeks, 73% after 1 year (Henschke, BMJ 2008). For chronic pain, 67.2% had the same pain level after 4 years (Peng, 2012).

 Recurrence is Common

 69% experienced recurrence within 12 months (da Silva, 2019). Lower back pain is therefore an episodic, long-term condition – prevention is important .

 What Does the Research Say About Treatment?

 JAMA 2017: Manipulation provides ~10 points improvement on 100-point scale – equivalent to NSAIDs

 BMJ 2019: High-quality evidence for effect in chronic pain

 CCGPP (2016) recommends 6–12 treatments over 2–4 weeks as a starting point

Beskriv symptomer for Kalkskulder: Alt du trenger å vite.

Symptomer

 Symptomene ved kalkskulder varierer betydelig avhengig av hvilken fase tilstanden er i
 Typiske symptomer

 Smerte: Lokalisert til utsiden av skulderen/overarmen. Kan stråle ned til albuen.

 Nattesmerte: Vanlig, særlig når man ligger på affisert side. Les mer om søvn og skuldersmerter 

 Bevegelsesinnskrenkning: Vansker med å løfte armen til siden og over hodet

 Plutselig forverring: Akutt, intens smerte ved overgang til resorpsjonsfasen

 Akutt presentasjon (resorpsjonsfasen)

 Plutselig debut av intense smerter, ofte om natten. Skulderen kan være svært om til å berore, og pasienten holder ofte armen helt stille for å unngå smerte. Tilstanden kan ligne på septisk artritt eller gikt.

 Kronisk presentasjon (hvile-/dannelsesfasen)

 Gradvis økende smerte over tid. Smerten forverres ved aktivitet, særlig bevegelser over skulderhøyde. Kan ligne på impingement-syndrom.

 Kliniske tester

 Ved undersøkelse finner man ofte
 Smertefull bue ved abduksjon (60-120 grader)

 Positiv Neer's og/eller Hawkins test

 Punktomhet over supraspinatus-feseet

 I akutt fase: Varme, hovelse, uttalt omhet

Beskriv symptomer og kjennetegn for Cervikal Foraminal Stenose - Trang Nervekanal i Nakken.

Symptomer

 

 Typiske symptomer

 
 Radikular smerte: Skarp, brennende eller elektrisk smerte som stråler fra nakke til arm

 Nummenhet og prikking: Ofte i spesifikke fingre avhengig av hvilken nerve som er påvirket

 Svakhet: Redusert kraft i spesifikke muskler i arm eller hand

 Nakkestivhet: Spesielt ved bevegelser som lukker foramen (ekstensjon + rotasjon til smertefull side)

 

 
 Spurlings test

 En klassisk test for foraminal stenose: Hodet bøyes bakover og roteres mot smertefull side, deretter trykkes lett ned. Positiv test reproduserer utstråling til armen. Dette "lukker" foramen og provoserer symptomene.

 Smerte: Skulder og overarm

 Svakhet: Skulderløft, albuebøy

 Nummenhet: Laterale skulder

 
 

 
 C6-nerven (C5-C6 stenose)

 
 Smerte: Underarm, tommel og pekefinger

 Nummenhet: Tommel og pekefinger

 
 

 
 C7-nerven (C6-C7 stenose)

 
 Smerte: Bakside av arm, langfinger

 Svakhet: Triceps, handleddsfleksjon

Hva forårsaker Golfalbue: Alt du trenger å vite?

Årsaker og risikofaktorer

 

 Over 90% av golfalbue-tilfeller skyldes arbeidsrelaterte faktorer - ikke golf. De vanligste Årsakene er:

 
 Repetitivt manuelt arbeid Vanligst

 Handverk som snekring, rØrlegging, maling. Repetitiv grep- og vridbevegelser over tid.

 

 
 Kontorarbeid

 Langvarig mus- og tastaturbruk, spesielt med dårlig ergonomi. Ofte kombinert med tennisalbue. Se var artikkel om musearm.

 

 
 Kastidretter

 Baseball, handball, spydkast. Repetitive kasebevegelser belaster innsiden av albuen.

 

 
 Golf (5-10% av tilfellene)

 Faktisk bare en liten andel. Vanligst hos nybegynnere med feil teknikk.

 

 Viktige risikofaktorer

 
 Repetitive grepbevegelser: Samme bevegelse tusenvis av ganger

 Tunge løft med bøyd handledd: Økter belastningen på innsiden

 Vibrasjon: Bruk av vibrerende verktøy (bormaskin, slipemaskin)

 Alder 40-60 Ør: Naturlig aldring av senevev

 Røykere: Dårligere blodtilførsel til sener

Describe treatment options for Thoracic Disc Herniation.

Treatment

 

 What Can the Chiropractor Do?

 The chiropractor's primary role in thoracic disc herniation is differential diagnosis -
 identifying the condition and assessing severity.

 
 Evidence Base

 There are no randomized controlled trials (RCTs) examining chiropractic or manual treatment
 specifically for thoracic disc herniation (ScienceDirect, 2006). Published case reports document serious
 complications after manipulation with known thoracic herniation (JAMA Neurology, 1987).

 

 For confirmed herniation without myelopathy, gentle soft tissue treatment and mobilization of surrounding
 areas may potentially relieve muscular compensation pain. High-velocity manipulation should be
 avoided when disc pathology in the thoracic spine is suspected.

 With signs of myelopathy or progressive neurological deficits, the patient should be referred
 immediately.

 
 Conservative Treatment Generally

 For patients without myelopathy, conservative treatment is recommended as first choice:

 
 Rest and activity modification: Short rest period (1-2 days) followed by gradual
 increase in activity

 Medication: Anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) after medical evaluation

 Physical therapy: Structured treatment for 4-6 weeks

 
 

 About 80% of patients return to previous activity level with conservative treatment
 (StatPearls, 2024). The classic study by Brown et al. (1992) followed 55 patients - 73% never needed
 surgery.

 Surgery

 Surgery is reserved for:

 
 Progressive myelopa...

What causes Cubital Tunnel Syndrome: Everything You Need to Know?

Causes

 

 The ulnar nerve is vulnerable at the elbow for several reasons:

 
 Bent ElbowMost Common

 When the elbow is bent, the ulnar nerve is stretched and compressed. Prolonged elbow flexion (sleeping,
 phone, keyboard) is the main cause.

 

 
 Leaning on the Elbow

 Leaning your elbow on armrests, tables, or car door armrests over time puts direct pressure on the
 nerve.

 

 
 Anatomical Factors

 Some people naturally have a narrow cubital tunnel or a nerve that "jumps" out of its groove when the
 elbow bends.

 

 
 Previous Injuries

 Elbow fractures, dislocations, or arthritis can narrow the tunnel and irritate the nerve.

 

 Important Risk Factors

 
 Office work: Prolonged keyboard use with bent elbows (see also mouse arm)

 Sleeping habits: Sleeping with arms under head/pillow

 Phone use: Long conversations with bent elbow

 Rheumatoid arthritis: Can cause swelling around the nerve

 Diabetes: Increases the risk of nerve problems in general

Forklar behandling for Nociplastisk smerte: Når nervesystemet blir overfølsomt.

Behandling

 Behandling av nociplastisk smerte krever en fundamentalt annen tilnærming enn tradisjonell smertebehandling. Målet er ikke å "fikse" noe i kroppen, men å hjelpe nervesystemet å dempe sin overfølsomhet.

 Smerteutdanning (Pain Neuroscience Education)

 Hvorfor forståelse er viktig

 Å forstå hvorfor smerten oppstår reduserer frykt og katastrofetenkning

 Kunnskap om at smerte ikke betyr skade gir trygghet til å bevege seg

 Endrer hvordan hjernen tolker signaler fra kroppen

 Studier viser at smerteutdanning alene kan redusere smerte og bedre funksjon

 Gradert aktivitet og eksponering

 Gradert øvelsestrening

 Sentralt i behandlingen 

 Kontrollert økning av fysisk aktivitet og eksponering for bevegelser som fryktes. Målet er å vise nervesystemet at bevegelse er trygt, slik at "alarmen" gradvis dempes.

 Start på et nivå som ikke provoserer betydelig smerteoppbluss

 Øk gradvis i små steg

 Fokuser på funksjon, ikke smertenivå

 Aksepter at noe ubehag er normalt og ikke farlig

 Psykologiske tilnærminger

 Kognitiv atferdsterapi (CBT)

 Hjelper med å identifisere og endre ugunstige tankemønstre og atferd knyttet til smerte. Reduserer katastrofetenkning og unngåelsesatferd.

 Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT)

 Fokuserer på å akseptere smerten uten å kjempe mot den, samtidig som man lever i trød med egne verdier. Reduserer kampens forsterkende effekt på smerten.

 Mindfulness

 Oppmerksomhetstrening kan dempe nervesystemets reaktivitet og redusere stressresponsen. Kan hjelpe med å "observere" smerte uten å forsterke den.

Isjias a nervesmerte ned i benet

 

 Gå til full artikkel om isjias ?

 Isjias å også kalt lumbal radikulopati å er smerter som stråler fra korsryggen ned i benet, forårsaket av irritasjon av en nerverot. Bare 3–5% av befolkningen har lumbal radikulopati (Medscape, 2024) å det er altså mye mindre vanlig enn folk tror.

 
 Vanligste Årsaker til isjias

 
 Skiveprolaps å vanligste Årsak (ca. 90%). Skivematerialet presser på nerveroten.

 Spinal stenose å tranghet i ryggkanalen, vanligere hos eldre

 Spondylolisthesis å glidning av virvel som kan klemme nerven

 Piriformissyndrom å muskel i setet som irriterer isjiasnerven

 
 

 Symptomer på isjias

 
 Utstråling under kneet å dette skiller isjias fra vanlig ryggsmerte

 Brennende, stikkende eller elektrisk smerte nedover baksiden av læret

 Prikking og nummenhet i benet eller foten

 Svakhet å vanskeligheter med å løfte foten

 Verre ved sitting a nerven strekkes i sittende stilling

 

 
 L4-L5 (L5-nerveroten)

 
 Smerte på utsiden av læret og leggen, nummenhet på fotens overside

 Svakhet ved å løfte stortåen, vanskelig å gå på hælene

 
 

 
 L5-S1 (S1-nerveroten)

 
 Smerte bak i læret og leggen, ned til lillefoten

 Svakhet ved å gå på tå, redusert akillesrefleks

 
 

 
 Prognose: 50% opplever betydelig bedring innen 6 uker. 75% er bedre innen 12 uker. 90% bedres innen 3–6 måneder uten kirurgi (PMC, 2019).

Describe Differential Diagnoses for Trigger Points in the Neck - Muscle Knots and Referred Pain.

Differential Diagnoses

 

 It's important to distinguish trigger points from other conditions that can cause similar symptoms:

 
 Cervical Radiculopathy (Nerve Root Involvement)

 Follows dermatomal patterns (specific skin areas), often with tingling/numbness and weakness. Trigger
 points follow muscle-specific radiation patterns.

 

 
 Fibromyalgia

 Widespread pain for more than 3 months, with tenderness in many areas of the body, often with fatigue
 and sleep problems.

 

 
 Cervical Facet Joint Arthrosis

 Pain from the joints between vertebrae, often with morning stiffness that improves throughout the day.

Patient asks: "Can the wrong sleep position cause back pain?"

Yes, sleep position can contribute to back and neck pain. Stomach sleeping increases lumbar loading and forces the neck into rotation. Research shows that back and side sleeping are generally more gentle on the spine (Cary et al., 2021). That said, sleep position is rarely the sole cause, and changing your position should be part of a broader approach.

Prognosis: What Can You Expect?

 Timeline

 Vestibular rehabilitation: Noticeable improvement after median 6 weeks

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Neck Pain - Complete Guide to Causes, Treatment and Red Flags.

7Frequently Asked Questions

 How long do typical neck pains last?
Most acute episodes resolve within 2-6 weeks. Improvement happens fastest in the first 6-12 weeks.

 Should I wait and see if it goes away?
No, early treatment often gives better results. Treatment within 4 weeks doubles the chance of significant improvement.

 Can neck pain cause dizziness?
Yes, 43% of patients with prolonged neck pain report dizziness. Treatment of neck problems often improves dizziness.

 Do I need an MRI of the neck?
For ordinary neck pain, MRI is rarely necessary. 88.5% of healthy people have degenerative changes without symptoms.

   - Ingen behandling og naturlig forløp

Describe diagnosis and assessment for Chronic Back Pain.

Diagnosis and Assessment

 In chronic back pain, the primary task is to rule out specific causes that require different treatment. Over 90% of chronic back pain is classified as non-specific (WHO, 2023), meaning no single structural change can explain the pain.

 Clinical Examination

 A thorough clinical examination forms the foundation of the assessment. The chiropractor evaluates
 Pain patterns, duration and distribution

 Neurological status (strength, sensation, reflexes)

 Range of motion and function

 Psychosocial factors (yellow flags)

 Red flags that may indicate serious underlying disease

 Central Sensitization

 An important aspect of chronic pain is central sensitization - the nervous system becoming more sensitive. Think of a fire alarm system: normally the alarm only goes off when there is a fire, but what if the sensitivity is turned up? Then the alarm might go off for cooking fumes, steam from the shower, or even for no reason at all.

 A longitudinal study from 2024 found that individuals with elevated measures of central sensitization (CSI score) had a greater risk of developing chronic back pain. The proportion who developed chronic pain increased from 26% to 32% among those with high CSI scores (PMC, 2024). The pain is not imaginary - the nervous system is overreacting to signals.

 Do You Need an MRI?

 MRI is not routinely recommended for chronic back pain without red flags. Studies show that structural changes such as wear and tear, bulging and degeneration are common findings even in completely pain-free individuals. Imaging can sometimes do more harm than good by creating unnecessary worry.

Describe Frequently Asked Questions for Ankle Sprains.

Frequently Asked Questions

 

 
 How long does it take for an ankle to heal?

 Grade I: 1-3 weeks. Grade II: 3-6 weeks. Grade III: 6-12 weeks or more. Healing
 time depends on the severity of the injury and how consistently you follow the rehabilitation program.
 

 

 
 Should I get an X-ray or MRI?

 In most cases, imaging is not necessary. Ottawa Ankle Rules have 97.6% sensitivity
 for detecting fractures. X-rays are only taken if there is bone tenderness over specific points or
 inability to walk four steps.

 

 
 Can I exercise with a sprained ankle?

 Modern treatment (POLICE protocol) recommends early, gentle movement within pain
 limits from day 1. Complete rest is no longer recommended. You can often continue with activities that
 don't load the ankle, such as cycling or swimming, relatively early in the process.

 

 
 How do I prevent new sprains?

 Balance training provides 35% reduction in risk of new sprains. Ankle braces or
 taping provide 69-71% reduction in previously injured athletes. Continue with strength and balance
 exercises even after the pain is gone.

 

 
 Do I need a referral to see a chiropractor?

 No, you don't need a referral. Chiropractors in Norway have had primary contact
 status since 2006, and you can book an appointment directly. If needed, the chiropractor can refer you
 for X-rays, specialist consultations, or other examinations.

 

 
 When should I seek help?

Describe diagnosis for Muscles and Trigger Points That Cause Headache.

Diagnosis

 Headache from muscular causes is diagnosed primarily through clinical examination . Imaging such as MRI or CT is rarely necessary for typical tension headache and often shows findings like wear or degeneration that do not explain the symptoms.

 The Examination Includes
 Palpation of neck and facial muscles to locate trigger points

 Assessment of whether pressure on the trigger point reproduces the patient's known headache

 Posture assessment including forward head position

 Neurological screening to rule out serious causes

 Craniovertebral mobility and neck joint function

 ICHD-3 Classification of Tension Headache
 Infrequent episodic: Less than 1 day/month

 Frequent episodic: 1-14 days/month

 Chronic: 15 days or more/month for over 3 months

Beskriv symptomer og kjennetegn for Ribbeinslasning vs. Ribbeinsbrudd.

Symptomer - hvordan skille dem?

 

 Begge tilstander gir smerte som forverres ved pusting og bevegelse. Men det er noen viktige forskjeller:

 
 
 
 Kjennetegn
 Ribbeinsbrudd
 Ribbeinslasning
 
 
 
 
 Traumehistorie
 Klar - husker nøyaktig når/hvordan
 Ofte vag eller ingen
 
 
 Smertestart
 Umiddelbart etter traume
 Gradvis eller plutselig uten traume
 
 
 Ved trykk
 Ekstrem omhet, mulig krepitasjon
 Moderat omhet, triggerpunkter
 
 
 Hevelse/blåmerker
 Ofte synlig etter 1-2 uker
 Ingen eller minimal
 
 
 Pusting
 Overfladisk, svært begrenset
 Kan ta dype pust (men det gjør vondt)
 
 
 Smerteintensitet
 Svært intens
 Moderat til sterk
 
 
 

 
 Hovedregelen: Ved ribbeinsbrudd husker pasienten nøyaktig når og hvordan smerten startet - det var et traume. Ved ribbeinslasning er historien ofte mer uklar: "Jeg bare vaknet med det" eller "Det kom etter at jeg hadde sittet lenge."

Describe symptoms of l5-s1 herniation for L5.

Symptoms of L5-S1 Herniation

 S1 Nerve Root (Most Common)

 With typical posterolateral herniation at L5-S1, the S1 nerve root is compressed. The symptom picture is characteristic and often causes sciatica
 Pain
 Starts in low back/buttock

 Radiates down the back of thigh and calf

 Often described as a "stripe" down the leg

 Continues to the outer foot and small toes

 Sensory Changes
 Numbness or tingling on outer foot

 Reduced sensation in fifth toe

 Altered sensitivity on back of calf

 Muscle Weakness
 Difficulty standing on toes (toe raise)

 Weakened plantar flexion (pointing toes down)

 Reduced strength with hip extension

 Reflex
 Reduced or absent Achilles reflex

 This is an objective and reliable finding with 91% specificity for S1 involvement

Describe Risks of Too Rapid Transition for Minimalist Shoes and Barefoot Training: What Does the Research Say?.

Risks of Too Rapid Transition

 

 The greatest danger with minimalist shoes is not the shoes themselves, but too rapid transition. Feet that have been "protected" in cushioned shoes for decades have weak muscles and are not prepared for the increased load.

 
 Common Injuries from Too Rapid Transition

 
 Stress fractures: Especially in metatarsal bones

 Achilles tendinopathy: Overload of the Achilles tendon

 Plantar fasciitis: Overload of the arch's connective tissue

 Muscle soreness: Intense stiffness in calves and foot muscles

 
 

 
 Why Does This Happen?

 Years of cushioned shoes have led to:

 
 Weak foot musculature (up to 17% atrophy from orthotics alone)

 Shortened Achilles tendon (from high heels)

 Reduced bone mineral density in the foot

 Loss of proprioceptive sensitivity

 
 Suddenly removing all support is like going from a cast straight to running a marathon.

Differential diagnoses for Teeth Grinding?

Sleep Bruxism

 This is the classic "nighttime teeth grinding" most people think of
 Rhythmic movements: The jaw moves in repetitive patterns

 Occurs in light sleep: Especially in transitions between sleep stages

 Enormous forces: Can generate 50-80 kg pressure - far above normal chewing force of 10-15 kg

 Sound: Partner often hears loud grinding noise

 Morning symptoms: Headache, sore jaw, tired chewing muscles

 Important: Sleep bruxism is classified as a sleep-related movement disorder and is often linked to other sleep problems.

Awake Bruxism

 This type occurs while you're awake and is fundamentally different
 Static clenching: You press teeth together without movement

 Stress trigger: Triggered by concentration, stress , frustration

 Semi-conscious: You can learn to become aware of it

 Daytime symptoms: Jaw pain that increases throughout the day

 More common in women: Studies show higher prevalence

Vurder røde flagg: 70 år kvinne med kjent kneartrose, kommer for knebehandling. Under anamneseopptaket nevner hun ny hodepine over tinningen venstre side siste uken, og at det gjør vondt å tygge brødskorpe. "Det er sikkert bare kjeveledd."

HASTEGRAD: AKUTT — Oppstart behandling SAMME DAG

RØDE FLAGG IDENTIFISERT: Mulig kjempecellearteritt (GCA) - oppdaget tilfeldig under knebehandling.

Klinisk resonnering:
- Kneartrose er separat, uproblematisk tilstand
- MEN: ny UNILATERAL temporal hodepine hos kvinne >50 = GCA til det motsatte er bevist
- Tyggeclaudicatio (smerter ved tygging) er NESTEN PATOGNOMONISK for GCA
- Pasienten tror det er kjeveledd, men TMD gir BILATERAL kjevesmerte, IKKE temporal hodepine med tyggeclaudicatio
- GCA = risiko for PERMANENT BLINDHET uten behandling

HANDLING: Knebehandling kan vente. AKUTT blodprøver (SR, CRP). Kontakt fastlege UMIDDELBART for oppstart prednisolon SAMME DAG. Øyelegevurdering. Temporal arteriebiopsi innen 2 uker.

Beskriv Anatomien i kontekst av Occipital nevralgi.

Anatomien

 Det finnes tre occipitalnerver på hver side:

 
 Nervus occipitalis major (store occipitalnerven): Kommer fra C2-nerveroten. Passerer gjennom nakkemuskulaturen og forsyner den største delen av bakhodet. Mest vanlig involvert ved occipital nevralgi.

 Nervus occipitalis minor (lille occipitalnerven): Kommer fra C2-C3. Forsyner området bak Øret og laterale del av bakhodet.

 N. occipitalis tertius (tredje occipitalnerven): Kommer fra C3. Forsyner nedre del av bakhodet.

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Meralgia Paresthetica.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Er meralgia paresthetica farlig?

 Nei, meralgia paresthetica er ikke farlig. Det er en godartet tilstand som bare påvirker følelsen i huden - den gir aldri muskelsvakhet eller varige skader. De fleste blir bra med enkle tiltak.

 

 
 Kan meralgia paresthetica gå over av seg selv?

 Ja, mange tilfeller går over av seg selv når utløsende Årsak fjernes. For eksempel bedres symptomene ofte ved vekttap, løsere klær eller etter fødsel. Det kan ta uker til måneder.

 

 
 Hva er forskjellen på meralgia paresthetica og isjias?

 Meralgia paresthetica gir symptomer på fremsiden/utsiden av læret og kun følelsessymptomer. Isjias gir symptomer på baksiden av benet, kan gå helt til foten, og kan gi både smerter og svakhet. De er to helt forskjellige nerver.

 

 
 Kan jeg trene med meralgia paresthetica?

 Ja, de fleste kan trene. Unngå aktiviteter som gir mye hofteekstensjon (strekk bakover) eller langvarig standing. Sykling tolereres ofte godt fordi hoften er bøyd. Styrketrening for core og hofter kan våre nyttig.

 

 
 Må jeg opereres?

 Sjelden. 85% blir bra uten operasjon. Kirurgi vurderes først etter flere måneder med konservativ behandling uten effekt. De fleste trenger aldri kirurgi.

Describe 2. Cervicogenic Dizziness (neck-related) in the context of Headache and Dizziness.

2. Cervicogenic Dizziness (neck-related)

 Dizziness caused by neck problems affects 40% of patients with neck pain. Of these, 59.7% were related to myofascial pain syndrome (muscle tension with trigger points). This often overlaps with cervicogenic headache.

 The neck contains extremely many proprioceptors (position sensors) - especially in the small muscles at the top toward the skull. When these send incorrect signals, a conflict arises between what the neck "tells" the brain and what the balance organ in the ear registers.

 
 Dizziness with head movements

 Neck pain or stiffness

 Often triggered by positions or activities

 SCM trigger points can cause both headache and dizziness

Beskriv diagnostikk for Fremre Kanal BPPV: Den Sjeldne Varianten.

Diagnostikk

 Karakteristisk nystagmus

 Nedadstående nystagmus: Hovedkjennetegnet ved fremre kanal BPPV er en vertikal nedadstående (downbeat) nystagmus. Dette skiller seg fundamentalt fra bakre kanal BPPV som gir oppadstående nystagmus.

 Svak torsjonell komponent: I motsetning til bakre kanal BPPV hvor torsjonell komponent er fremtredende, er den ofte svak eller fraverende ved fremre kanal.

 Diagnostiske tester

 Supine Head Hanging Test

 Denne testen anses som mest sensitiv for fremre kanal BPPV. Pasienten ligger med hodet hengende 30 grader under horisontalplanet, holdt i midtlinjen. Observer for nedadstående nystagmus.

 Dix-Hallpike test

 Kan også provosere fremre kanal BPPV, men er mindre spesifikk. Nedadstående nystagmus på begge sider kan tyde på fremre kanal.

 Differensialdiagnostikk - kritisk viktig!

 SENTRAL å RSAK Må ALLTID VURDERES: Nedadstående nystagmus er et karakteristisk funn ved cerebellære lesjoner. En studie fant at 72% av pasienter med posisjonell nedadstående nystagmus hadde sentrale lidelser.

 Perifer årsak: Latens for nystagmusstart, habituering, varighet under 60 sekunder, respons på behandling

 Sentral årsak: Ingen latens, vedvarende nystagmus, ingen habituering, manglende respons på behandling

Patient asks: "Is a labral tear the same as hip osteoarthritis?"

No, but they can be related. Labral tear affects the cartilage rim around the
 hip socket, while osteoarthritis is wear of the joint cartilage.
 Untreated labral tear can over time increase the risk of osteoarthritis, but many with labral tears
 never develop osteoarthritis.

Patient asks: "What is snapping hip syndrome?"

Snapping hip is when you hear or feel a 'click' or 'pop' in the hip during movement. There are three types: internal (iliopsoas over the hip joint), external (ITB over trochanter) and intra-articular (inside the joint). Internal snapping from iliopsoas is the most common form in dancers and athletes.

Forklar prognose for GTPS.

Prognose

 GTPS er en tilstand som tar tid å behandle - typisk 6-9 måneder for full bedring. Men prognosen er god hvis du er tålmodig og følger et treningsprogram.

 Hva kan du forvente?

 Uke 1-4: Smertehandtering og belastningsreduksjon. Mange opplever at det blir verre for det blir bedre.

 Uke 4-12: Gradvis opptrapping av trening. Smertene begynner å avta.

 3-6 måneder: Fortsatt progresjon. De fleste merker tydelig bedring.

 6-12 måneder: Full eller nesten full funksjon. Vedlikeholdstrening anbefales.

 Plutselig kraftig smerte etter fall eller traume

 Nattesmerter som ikke bedres med stillingsskifte

 Uforklarlig vekttap

 Feber eller allmenn sykdomsfølelse

Describe How common is stress neck? for Stress Neck and Trigger Points.

How common is stress neck?

 

 
 Annual prevalence among office workers: 42-63% report neck pain

 Trigger points: 93% of patients with chronic neck pain have trigger points in upper trapezius

 Latent trigger points: 78.8% of healthy people have latent (sleeping) trigger points in upper trapezius

 
 Women are affected more often than men - nearly double the risk of neck pain in women.

Describe Stages of PTTD for Tibialis Posterior Tendinopathy.

Stages of PTTD

 

 Tibialis posterior tendinopathy is classified into four stages based on severity:

 
 
 
 Stage
 Tendon
 Foot
 Treatment
 
 
 
 
 Stage 1
 Inflammation, normal length
 Normal foot arch, flexible
 Conservative
 
 
 Stage 2
 Lengthened, degenerated
 Flat foot, still flexible
 Conservative/orthotics
 
 
 Stage 3
 Significantly damaged
 Rigid flat foot, not correctable
 Often surgery
 
 
 Stage 4
 Ruptured/non-functional
 Rigid flat foot + ankle arthritis
 Surgery
 
 
 

 
 Why early treatment is important

 Stage 1-2 respond well to conservative treatment. When the condition progresses to stage 3-4, the foot
 deformity becomes permanent and surgery is often necessary. Therefore, early diagnosis and treatment is
 crucial.

Evidensbasert behandling

 Det gode nyheten: 85-96% av pasienter med golfalbue blir bra med konservativ behandling (Amin et al., 2015). Kirurgi er sjelden nødvendig.

 Gullstandard: Eksentrisk trening

 Gradvis styrking av fleksorsenene

 Stimulerer kollagenproduksjon og seneoppbygging

 Eksentriske "wrist curls" med lett vekt

 3 sett x 15 repetisjoner, 2 ganger daglig

 Behandlingsplan hos . Grundig undersøkelse

 Vurdere om ulnarnerven er involvert, utelukke differensialdiagnoser, og kartlegge provoserende faktorer.

 2. Manuell behandling

 Bløtvevsbehandling av triggerpunkter i fleksormuskulaturen, mobilisering av albue og handledd, eventuelt nerveglide for ulnarnerven.

 3. Eksentrisk trening Viktigst 

 Strukturert treningsprogram med fokus på eksentrisk belastning av fleksorene. Reverse wrist curls med gradvis økt motstand.

 4. Ergonomisk veiledning

 Identifisere og modifisere provoserende aktiviteter på jobb og i fritid.

 Eksentrisk wrist curl for golfalbue

 Sitt med underarmen på et bord, handflaten opp, handleddet utenfor bordkanten

 Hold en lett vekt (0.5-1 kg) i handen

 Start med handleddet bøyd opp (fleksert)

 Senk vekten sakte ned (3-4 sekunder) til handleddet er strakt

 Bruk den andre handen til å løfte tilbake til start

 Gjenta 15 ganger, 3 sett, 2 ganger daglig

Describe Pregnancy and Lower Back Pain for Lower Back Pain – Complete Guide.

Pregnancy and Lower Back Pain

 

 Go to full article on pregnancy and back pain ?

 Approximately 50% of pregnant women experience lower back pain (Wu et al., European Spine Journal 2004). For some, the problems start early; for others, not until the last trimester.

 
 Why Do Pregnant Women Get Back Pain?

 Hormonal changes:

 
 Relaxin loosens ligaments and joints å provides less stability

 Muscles have to work harder to compensate

 
 Mechanical changes:

 
 Center of gravity shifts forward

 Increased curve in the lower back (hyperlordosis)

 Weight gain of 10–15 kg

 
 

 Types of Pain During Pregnancy

 
 Lumbar pain: Central in the lower back, similar to regular lower back pain

 Pelvic pain: Four times more common. Over the SI joints and/or pubic symphysis.

 Symphysis dysfunction: Pronounced pain over the pubic symphysis, difficulty walking

 

 
 Treatment During Pregnancy

 Chiropractic treatment is safe during pregnancy:

 
 Adapted joint treatment

 Soft tissue therapy

 Pelvic belts for pelvic pain

 Exercises and ergonomic advice

Beskriv RED-S og kvinnelig idrettstriade for Stressfraktur i Foten.

RED-S og kvinnelig idrettstriade

 

 Kvinner har 2-3 ganger høyere risiko for stressfrakturer. En viktig Årsak er RED-S (Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport), tidligere kalt den kvinnelige idrettstriaden.

 
 De tre komponentene

 
 Energimangel: For få kalorier i forhold til aktivitetsnivå

 Menstruasjonsforstyrrelser: Uregelmessig eller fravårende menstruasjon

 Lav beintetthet: Økt risiko for stressfrakturer

 
 

 RED-S kan også ramme menn, spesielt i vektfålsomme idretter. Ved gjentatte stressfrakturer bør man alltid vurdere underliggende Årsaker.

 
 Viktig å vite

 Uteblitt menstruasjon hos kvinnelige utøvere er ikke normalt, selv ved hard trening. Det er et tegn på energimangel og krever oppfølging for å forebygge alvorlige konsekvenser som osteoporose og stressfrakturer.

Hvordan diagnostiseres Hodepine på toppen av hodet?

Diagnostikk

 

 Klinisk undersøkelse er avgjørende

 Diagnostikk av hodepine på toppen av hodet baseres først og fremst på sykehistorie og klinisk undersøkelse. En kiropraktor vil vurdere nakkens bevegelighet, palpere muskulaturen for triggerpunkter, og undersøke Øvre nakkeledd for dysfunksjon.

 Bildediagnostikk

 MR eller røntgen av nakken er sjelden nødvendig ved typiske presentasjoner. Bilder viser ofte normalfunn som slitasje eller degenerative forandringer - funn som er like vanlige hos personer uten smerter og som derfor sjelden forklarer plagene.

Provide a structured clinical overview of When Orthotics Actually Help.

Orthotics Are Not Always Wrong: While many articles focus on the overuse of orthotics, it's important to acknowledge that there are legitimate indications. For certain patient groups, orthotics can be a valuable - sometimes lifesaving - aid.

Conditions With Strong Evidence: In diabetic neuropathy, the patient loses sensation in their feet and can develop foot ulcers that in the worst case lead to amputation. Custom pressure-relieving orthotics can prevent ulcer formation.

Conditions With Moderate Evidence: For acute injuries such as stress fractures, tendinitis or joint injuries, orthotics can be used temporarily to offload the injured area while it heals.

Conditions Where Evidence Is Weak: For the following conditions, evidence is weak or absent - despite orthotics being frequently prescribed
Checklist: Are Orthotics Right for You?: Orthotics are probably NOT right if
Custom vs. Prefabricated?: A common argument for expensive custom orthotics is that they are "better" than cheap prefabricated ones. What does the research say?

Red Flags - When to See a Doctor: These symptoms may indicate serious conditions such as infection, nerve damage, or systemic disease and require prompt medical evaluation.

Beskriv symptomer og kjennetegn for Vestibularisnevritt.

Symptomer

 

 Symptomene kommer typisk akutt over noen timer, når maksimal intensitet innen 24 timer, og avtar gradvis over dager til uker.

 Typisk symptombilde:

 
 Rotasjonssvimmelhet: Intens følelse av at rommet spinner kontinuerlig

 Spontan nystagmus: Ufrivillige, raske Øyebevegelser som slær mot det friske Øret

 Kvalme og oppkast: Kan vare så uttalt at sykehusinnleggelse er nødvendig

 Balanseproblemer: Tendens til å falle mot den syke siden

 Oscillopsi: Følelse av at synsfeltet "hopper" ved hodebevegelser

 

 
 Viktig diagnostisk poeng

 Vestibularisnevritt gir ikke Hørselstap. Har du svimmelhet kombinert med nedsatt horsel, kan det tyde på labyrinthitt eller andre tilstander som krever annen utredning.

 

 Tidsforløp:

 
 Akuttfase (0-3 dager): Intens svimmelhet, ofte sengeliggende

 Subakutt fase (1-2 uker): Gradvis bedring, kan gå oppreist men blir svimmel ved raske bevegelser

 Kompensasjonsfase (3-12 uker): Hjernen tilpasser seg og lærer å kompensere

 
 De fleste opplever betydelig bedring innen 10 uker.

Beskriv Ofte stilte spørsmål for Kortisoninjeksjon i skulder: Venn eller fiende?.

Ofte stilte spørsmål

 

 
 Hvor lenge varer effekten av en kortisonsprøyte i skulderen?

 Effekten varierer betydelig. Noen opplever lindring i uker til måneder, mens andre har kortvarig eller ingen effekt. Forskning viser at effekten ofte avtar etter 6-8 uker, og ved 3-6 måneder er det ofte ingen forskjell fra placebo.

 

 
 Er kortisoninjeksjoner farlige?

 Enkelte injeksjoner er generelt trygge, men gjentatte injeksjoner kan svekke sener og brusk. Studier viser Økt risiko for seneruptur og forverring av bruskskade ved mange injeksjoner. Anbefalt maksimum er vanligvis 3-4 injeksjoner per område per Ør.

 

 
 Når er kortisonsprøyte i skulderen riktig valg?

 Kortison kan våre nyttig ved akutt, intens betennelse som forhindrer rehabilitering, som et diagnostisk verktøy, eller som et kortvarig tiltak når andre behandlinger ikke har hjulpet. Det bør ikke våre førstevalg ved kroniske senetilstander.

 

 
 Kan kortison gjøre skulderproblemene verre?

 Ja, i noen tilfeller. Kortison kan svekke senevev over tid, og noen opplever en "kortison-flare" med forbigående Økt smerte de første dagene etter injeksjonen. Ved tendinopati kan kortison forstyrre den naturlige helingsprosessen.

 

 
 Hva er alternativene til kortisoninjeksjon?

 Alternativer inkluderer fysioterapi/kiropraktikk med Øvelser, manuell behandling, støtbølgeterapi (ESWT), og for noen tilstander PRP-injeksjoner. Ved mange skuldertilstander er aktiv rehabilitering mer effektivt på lang sikt. Les mer om ergonomi og ...

Beskriv Hvorfor så mange blir feildiagnostisert for Når svimmelheten ikke passer inn: Er det BPPV eller noe annet?.

Hvorfor så mange blir feildiagnostisert

 

 Feildiagnostisering av svimmelhet er utbredt. På akuttmottak blir 74-81% av perifere vestibulære lidelser (inkludert BPPV) oversett.

 Atypiske BPPV-presentasjoner

 37-41% av BPPV-pasienter har ikke klassisk "alt spinner rundt"-opplevelse. Mange beskriver heller:

 
 Nautisk eller vuggende følelse

 Tåkete tankegang ("brain fog")

 Generell ustadighet mellom anfall

 Vedvarende "lett i hodet"-følelse

 

 Diagnostiske tester har begrensninger

 Dix-Hallpike testen for BPPV har kun 48-88% sensitivitet. Negativ test utelukker ikke diagnosen.

 Overlappende tilstander

 Vestibulær migrene og BPPV kan eksistere samtidig. Migrenepasienter har tre ganger høyere BPPV-risiko, og 25% av vestibulær migrene-pasienter rapporterer posisjonssvimmelhet.

Red flags for Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome?

Realistic expectations

 The evidence base for TTS treatment is generally of low quality . A 2024 scoping review found that only 1 of 30 studies was at evidence level 3. Approximately 40% need further intervention beyond conservative treatment.

Patient asks: "Can Eagle syndrome be confused with TMD?"

Yes, Eagle syndrome can produce similar symptoms to TMD, including jaw pain, ear pain and headache. Important differences are that Eagle syndrome often causes pain with swallowing and head rotation, and a palpable hard mass in the tonsil area.

Patient asks: "How long does it take for C5-C6 disc herniation to heal?"

About 85% experience significant improvement within 8-12 weeks with conservative treatment. Most notice progress within 2-4 weeks. Full recovery can take up to 6 months, and the herniation can shrink and be reabsorbed over time.

Vurder røde flagg: 62 år mann med plutselig brystsmerte, dyspné og sinustakykardi etter langvarig sengeleie. SpO2 88%.

AKUTT: Mistanke om lungeemboli. Brystsmerte med dyspné og hypoksi etter immobilisering. Ring 113 umiddelbart. Sykehus for CT pulmonal angiografi, D-dimer, troponin. Oksygentilskudd umiddelbart. Antikoagulasjon ved bekreftet PE.
